text:
Yesterday, the Supreme Court of Belarus upheld Nasta Loika’s seven years imprisonment sentence for “incitement of racial, national, religious or other social enmity or discord”. Since her detention a year ago, she has been systematically denied the exercise of her rights in prison through bans on personal correspondence and inhumane treatment (including physical and psychological violence). They have also targeted her lawyers,  hindering her right to defense.

Nasta Loika, named as a woman human rights defender of 2022 by Belarus Human Rights House, works in human rights education. Her work includes addressing repressive “anti-extremist” laws and advocating for the protection of migrants and the rights of stateless people in Belarus.

Front Line Defenders condemns the decision to uphold her sentence, which reflects a wider trend of increased targeting of human rights defenders and civil society by Belarus authorities. 

Read more:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/supreme-court-belarus-upholds-woman-human-rights-defender-nasta-loikas-7-year-prison-sentence
#Belarus

text: On Micro-, Small and Medium-sized Enterprises Day, IESC highlights the Tourism Resilience Project’s (TRP) incubator program for MSMEs, which aims to provide high-quality training, mentoring, and advisory services to new and existing MSMEs in the tourism sector. TRP—funded by the European Union in collaboration with USAID and implemented by IESC—selected 112 MSMEs based on their commitment to refining their business models. After participating in a series of workshops, 70 businesses were shortlisted for the incubator program. TRP is implementing a three-month training and mentoring program for these MSMEs, covering topics such as customer service, marketing, cost control, and financial management. At the end of the program, IESC will hold a business showcase featuring the five businesses that have displayed the most innovation and overall success. Through these activities, IESC is bolstering the economic resilience of MSMEs across rural communities in Sri Lanka and increasing the number of quality businesses around The Pekoe Trail, a 300 km walking trail that spans Sri Lanka's central highlands and tea country. #MSMEDay #MSMEDay2023

ශ්‍රී ලංකාවේ එක්සත් ජාතින්ගෙන් හෝ එහි නිලධාරීන්ගෙන් හෝ ඒ වෙනුවෙන් යැයි කියනු ලබන වෙබ් අඩවියක, සමාජ මාධ්‍ය පිටුවක, සෘජු පණිවිඩයක, විද්‍යුත් තැපෑලක, ලිපියක හෝ දුරකථන සන්නිවේදනයක සත්‍යතාව පිළිබඳ සැක සහිත ඕනෑම අයෙකුට  විද්‍යුත් පණිවිඩයක් එවීමට උනන්දු කරනු ලැබේ rcs-unsrilanka@un.org

இலங்கை ஐக்கிய நாடுகளின் பெயர் மற்றும் இலச்சினையைப் பயன்படுத்தி மோசடியான அல்லது தவறாக வழிநடத்தும் வேண்டுகோள்கள் அடிக்கடி சமூக வலைதளங்கள், இணையத்தளங்கள், தொலைபேசி அழைப்புகள் மற்றும் தகவல் பரிமாற்ற சேவைகள் ஊடாக பகிரப்படுகின்றன. 

யாருக்கேனும் இலங்கை ஐக்கிய நாடுகள் அல்லது அதன் அதிகாரிகளிடம் இருந்து, அவர்களுக்காக அல்லது அவர்களின் சார்பாக இயங்கும் ஏதேனுமொரு இணையத்தளம், சமூக ஊடக பக்கம், நேரடி செய்தி, மின்னஞ்சல், கடிதம் அல்லது தொலைபேசி அழைப்பின் உண்மைத்தன்மை பற்றி சந்தேகங்கள் இருப்பின் rcs-unsrilanka@un.org.  க்கு மின்னஞ்சல் செய்யுமாறு வலியுறுத்துகின்றோம். 

மேலதிக விபரங்களுக்கு பிரவேசியுங்கள் https://bit.ly/44ofAJZ

text: IESC’s USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam assists small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in accessing new sources of financing and debt restructuring assistance post-COVID-19. Through this assistance, LinkSME has upskilled 50 SMEs to understand and interpret financial statements in preparation for applying for loans. Eleven of these SMEs have successfully applied for loans totaling 281 billion VND (nearly $12 million). The project has also developed a series of audio clips providing access to finance guidance for SMEs, specifically targeting those in the plastics, rubber, electronics, wood, and finance industries. These clips are available through the Ministry of Planning and Investment, ensuring they will be accessible beyond the life of the project. #MSMEDay
#ThrowbackThursday

A training on environmental justice and human rights, organised by the Centre for Justice, Governance and Environment Action (CJGEA) for the Uyombo community was disrupted by authorities in late September. 

Uyombo is a seaside community in Matsangoni, Kilifi County that has been designated to host Kenya's first nuclear reactor. The training was meant to inform them on energy policies, nuclear power, how the nuclear reactor could pose risks to their welfare and how to protect themselves, and more.

Armed police officers forcefully dispersed the training, removing equipment and informing the group that in future they must obtain permits for training. Members of the CJGEA have, in the past, also been subjected to police raids. 

Front Line Defenders is concerned for the safety of environmental human rights defenders and condemn the harassment of CJGEA and those attending the training.  

Read more: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/raid-human-rights-training-organised-centre-justice-governance-and-environment-action-cjgea?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

text:
Front Line Defenders and others have pulled out from the EU-ASEAN Human Rights Dialogue after Myanmar Junta Representatives were invited to participate: 

"We deeply regret the invitation of junta representatives, which contradicts the approach taken by both the EU and ASEAN in reaction to the February 2021 military coup in Myanmar that overturned the November 2020 general elections and the junta’s brutal crackdown on pro-democracy activists and ethnic minorities, as well as on civil society groups, human rights defenders, trade unions, journalists, and political opponents. We reject in the strongest possible terms any effort that may be perceived as legitimising the junta." 

The Junta continue to commit human rights violations and crack down on human rights defenders, and the invitation to participate in the human rights dialogue could be perceived as legitimising their actions. Front Line Defenders and others urge both sides to seriously reconsider this invitation and exclude the junta representatives from the EU-ASEAN human rights dialogue. 

Read the full joint letter: 
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/joint-civil-society-statement-opposing-myanmar-junta-representatives-participation-in-the-eu-asean-human-rights-dialogue
#Myanmar

Transparency International publishes Corruption Perceptions Index 2015: Sri Lanka ranked 83 out of 168 countries and territories, with a score of 37. 
A country or territory’s score indicates the perceived level of public sector corruption on a scale of 0 (highly corrupt) to 100 (very clean). A country's rank indicates its position relative to the other countries in the index

text:
Due to his participation in a peaceful protest in June this year,  Eduard Marikashvilli was charged with hooliganism and ordered to pay a fine last week. At the protest, he demonstrated alongside others who expressed their discontent with the Georgian government's foreign policy and Georgia’s growing alliance with Russian authorities. He was acquitted on a separate charge of disobeying a legal order from the police.

As a Georgian HRD and lawyer, Marikashvilli’s litigation focuses on juvenile justice, criminal law and accountability. He has been Chairperson of the human rights organisation “Georgian Democracy Initiative” since 2021, which is committed to defending human rights on a broad range of issues. 

Although the Court acquitted him of charges related to his alleged disobedience of a legal order from the police, Front Line Defenders urges the Georgian authorities to acquit Eduard of his remaining charges and to ensure a safe environment for human rights defenders in #Georgia. 

Read more:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/human-rights-defenders-eduard-marikashvili-charged-hooliganism-and-fined

At the Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) community of practice event in Washington, D.C., this month, two representatives from IESC’s F2F program spoke on panels to discuss their experiences providing and receiving volunteer technical assistance. Musa Kitoi (right, first picture) represented Amana Bank in Tanzania, a financial institution that has received five F2F volunteer assignments from IESC volunteer experts since 2020 focused on improving the bank’s agricultural lending processes and capacity to provide financing to smallholder farmers in Tanzania. Allyn Lamb (right, second picture), F2F volunteer, spoke about his experience working on over 16 F2F assignments focused on finance and farm credit since 2013, including with Amana Bank.

Ahead of tomorrow's hearing where community members affected by TRECSA (a subsidiary of Grupo Energía de Bogotá, an energy multinational) will demand justice, we join their efforts and also call for the protection of HRDs like Ana Laura Rojas, as well as denounce their systematic criminalization.

Ana Laura Rojas is a woman human rights defender and social communicator in #Guatemala and a member of the Coordinadora de Comunidades Afectadas por la empresa Trecsa (affected community members). As a result of her work in defense of territory and access to means of production, she has suffered death threats and persecution and has also seen her work in defense of territory criminalised.

Front Line Defenders condems the targeting of these defenders and calls for their safety and protection, especially in the context of the upcoming hearing. 

Read more about Ana Laura:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/profile/ana-laura-rojas
#Guatemala

IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Trade–Facilitating Agricultural Systems and Technology project (Proyecto T-FAST), together with implementing partner Kansas State University (KSU), trained 30 technicians from public institutions on the National Trade Facilitation Committee in Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HAACP). The HACCP course represents one element of the improvements highlighted by T-FAST for compliance with the World Trade Organization Trade Facilitation Agreement in Paraguay. IESC’s HAACP training supports regulatory and technical aspects of trade facilitation to reduce time and non-tariff costs and improve customer service.

Severely emaciated, pale, and weighing around 40kg, (significantly low compared to his normal weight of 70kg), Guo Feixiong’s hunger strike is taking a significant toll on his health and could result in him losing his life. Prison authorities have been tube-feeding him in order to keep him alive, yet no answer has come to pleas for his release and requests for better conditions.  

Guo Feixiong (郭飞雄), Front Line Defenders Awards’ 2015 laureate, is currently serving an eight-year sentence issued in May as punishment for “inciting subversion of State power” and has a travel ban that impedes him from seeing his children. He is a well-known HRD in #China for his work on democracy, anti-corruption and censorship, and has previously been imprisoned twice, totalling eleven years in prison.

Front Line Defenders is extremely concerned by his rapidly deteriorating health and urges the Chinese authorities to release him and ensure that he has prompt access to adequate medical care. 

Read more:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/human-rights-defender-guo-feixiong-risk-losing-his-life-prison

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program has partnered with the Georgian Mountain Guides Association to establish the Adventure Tourism School's regional branch in Western Georgia. This new regional branch will empower rural communities with in-demand skills and professions for high-value employment in Georgia's booming tourism sector. 

On June 7th, the Georgian Mountain Guides Association completed a comprehensive one-week Training of Trainers program on Course Delivery and Safety and Updated Practices for Summer Disciplines, equipping ten local trainers with new approaches for risk mitigation and management techniques in hiking and mountaineering disciplines. The Training of Trainers included practical and essential training elements, such as rocky and mixed terrains in the summer season, knots, and roping-up in rocky terrain.

This milestone marks an important step in developing a skilled workforce and ensuring safety standards within Georgia’s growing adventure tourism industry. #AdventureTourism #SkillsDevelopment #PartnershipsThatMatter #EmpoweringCommunities #TourismIndustry #GeorgiaTourism
Photos courtesy of the Georgian Mountain Guides Association

We will feature theatre-style story monologues based on the lives and work of some of the Human Rights Defenders featured at the monument, performed by Smashing Times.

IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovation (ATraCSI) project’s horticultural value chain assessment (HVCA) team traveled throughout El Salvador to collect primary data, conduct stakeholder interviews, and analyze findings. Napoleon Castillo, Deputy Chief of Party in El Salvador, and Bettina Balmer, HVCA Team Leader, met with Comercializadora 503, a Salvadoran company that produces and distributes nostalgic food products. Together they discussed opportunities and obstacles related to imports and exports to improve trade facilitation. These discussions will help IESC tailor ATraCSI’s interventions to the specific needs of project participants in El Salvador.

text:
Today, just a few days after the second anniversary of their arrest, the trial of Huang Xueqin and Wang Jianbing will begin. They were formally arrested on the charge of ‘inciting subversion of state power’ but their continued detention is believed to be related to their weekly gatherings organized to discuss the challenges activists face due to the shrinking space for civil society in the country. 

Sophia Huang Xueqin is a journalist who has been involved in several #MeToo campaigns to provide support and assistance to survivors of sexual assault and harassment. Also a prominent supporter of the #MeToo movement in China, labour activist Wang Jianbing has provided legal support for people with disabilities and workers with occupational diseases. 

Front Line Defenders, along with other civil society groups, call on the Chinese government for the immediate and unconditional release of these two human rights defenders and their unrestricted access to family, lawyers, adequate and necessary medical treatment, and protection from torture and other ill-treatment. 
#FreeXuebing 

Read the full joint statement: 
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/china-must-release-human-rights-defenders-huang-xueqin-and-wang-jianbing-now

🎉 Celebrating the Power of the People : A Historic Moment in Sri Lankan History 🇱🇰
Join us as we embark on a nostalgic journey down memory lane, commemorating the remarkable day in 2022 when the people of Sri Lanka showcased their unwavering determination and changed the course of history.!
In this exclusive video program, we bring the voices of the leading representatives who stood at the forefront of this extraordinary movement. Listen as they share their personal memories, struggles, and triumphs during the Aragalaya protests that lasted for over 100 days.
Witness the power of unity, resilience, and unwavering hope as these remarkable individuals recount how the people's relentless pursuit of change led to an astonishing victory. Together, we proved that when people come together, their voices cannot be ignored.
Join us as we celebrate this momentous occasion's legacy and reflect on its immense impact on Sri Lanka's future. Let us remember the sacrifices made and honor the triumph of the power of the people.!
Don't miss this captivating video that captures the essence of a historic movement. Like, comment, and share to spread inspiration and let the world know about the unstoppable power of the people..!

As the one year anniversary of the death of Mahsa Amini, and Iran's #WomanLifeFreedom movement approaches, we highlight emblematic cases of women human rights defenders who are still imprisoned, not only for their human rights work during the protests, but for their work defending human rights even preceding the protests.

Although one year has passed since the start of the protests in the wake of Mahsa Amini’s death, and the international community’s attention to the crisis has somewhat faded, human rights defenders remain at heightened risk and continue to endure human rights violations.

We stand with the human rights defenders that continue to face harassment, targeting, arrest and imprisonment and we call for the immediate release of those who are imprisoned on trumped charges.

Read more about the HRDs still being targeted:
https://zurl.co/GHOG 
#Iran #WomanLifeFreedom

පැවති පාලනය ජනතාව මත අධික බරක් පැටවීම, ආර්ථික අර්බුධය, අතවශ්‍ය භාණ්ඩ හිඟය, විදුලිය, ඉන්ධන ඇතුළු අතවශ්‍ය ද්‍රව්‍ය නොමැති වීම, අධි උද්ධමනය වැනි ගැටළු රැසකින් පීඩාවට පත්වූ ශ්‍රී ලාංකික ජනතාව එවකට පැවති පාලනයට සහ විශේෂයෙන් ජනාධිපතිවරයාට එරෙහිව විදියේ අරගල ආරම්භ කරා. 2022 මාර්තු 31 වැනිදායින් ආරම්භ කෙරුණු මේ පුරවැසි අරගලය ජූලි 09 වැනිදා ජනපතිවරයා ධුරයෙන් ඉවත්ව රටින් පලායන තෙක්ම අඛණ්ඩව පැවතුනා.

දින 100කට අධික කාලයක් පැවති අරගලයේ විවිධ අවස්ථාවන් වල නායකත්වය ගත්, ක්‍රියාකාරී වූ තරුණ කණ්ඩායම් නියෝජනය කරන තරුණ ක්‍රියාකාරීන් කිහිප දෙනෙක් "අරගල සමයේ මතක" නැවත සිහිපත් කරමින් සුහද කතාබහක නිරත වුනා. 

 Reflecting on the Remarkable "Aragalaya" : Memories of Sri Lanka's Historic Movement 🇱🇰

Step into the world of resilience, courage, and relentless determination as we bring you an exclusive conversation amongst the young activists who led the charge during the monumental struggle that captured the hearts of a nation!

Join us as these inspiring representatives from various youth groups delve into their memories, sharing stories of unity, solidarity, and unwavering commitment that fueled the movement against the existing regime. From the heavy burdens imposed by economic crises to the scarcity of essential goods, this conversation sheds light on the challenges faced by the Sri Lankan people and their unyielding spirit.

#ReflectingOnTheStruggle #YouthPower #srilankanpride #Aragalaya #SriLanka

Joint Press Release: Maryam Al-Khawaja prevented from boarding flight for visit to demand father’s release.

Maryam Al-Khawaja was barred from boarding a British Airways flight to Bahrain for a visit that she had publicly announced to pressure the Bahraini authorities to release her detained father, Danish-Bahraini human rights defender Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja, Amnesty International, Front Line Defenders, and ActionAid Denmark announced today.

She was being accompanied by a delegation of leading figures from three human rights organizations; Amnesty International’s Secretary General Agnès Callamard; Olive Moore and Andrew Anderson, who are current and former directors of Front Line Defenders; and Timothy Whyte, Secretary General of ActionAid Denmark, all of whom were also denied checking in for the flight.

Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja has been a prisoner of conscience since 2011, when Bahrain detained him for his role in spearheading political protests against the monarchy during the Arab Spring. His arrest was accompanied by torture, resulting in deteriorating health marked by chronic pain. Over the past two years, he has also suffered from glaucoma and cardiac arrhythmia. He is currently on hunger strike in protest of prison conditions and his family fears for his life. 

Read full press release: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/bahrain-maryam-al-khawaja-prevented-boarding-flight-visit-demand-fathers-release?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Trade–Facilitating Agricultural Systems and Technology project (Proyecto T-FAST) and implementing partner CIPE sponsored a Paraguayan delegation representing five trade-related ministries to attend the 5th Authorized Economic Operator (AEO) International Congress in Guatemala City on May 11, 2023. During the event, Guatemala signed onto the “OEA País” (AEO Country) initiative, making it the fourth country in Latin America to do so. The AEO program offers advantages to companies with security standards that guarantee the reliability of their import and export processes. Guatemala’s Customs Director acknowledged Paraguay’s role in implementing Guatemala’s AEO Country Program following a T-FAST-sponsored presentation about Paraguay’s AEO Program at the 8th International AEO Seminar in Sao Paulo in May 2022. The adoption of Guatemala’s AEO Country Program increases the number of AEO-certified companies throughout the region, further expediting international trade.
Ceylon Today - (07.10.2023)

As the one year anniversary of the death of #MahsaAmini and the #WomenLifeFreedom movement looms, human rights defenders continue to face harassment, targeting, arrest and imprisonment. 

The death of this young Kurdish woman while in custody of the morality police for allegedly not conforming with the country’s discriminatory veiling rules caused protests to erupt all around the country in September 2022. Although one year has passed since the start of the protests in the wake of Mahsa Amini’s death, and the international community’s attention to the crisis has somewhat faded, human rights defenders remain at heightened risk and continue to endure human rights violations. 

Read full statement here:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/one-year-woman-life-freedom-protests-human-rights-defenders-are-still-targeted?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

🎉 Celebrating the Power of the People : A Historic Moment in Sri Lankan History 🇱🇰

Join us as we embark on a nostalgic journey down memory lane, commemorating the remarkable day in 2022 when the people of Sri Lanka showcased their unwavering determination and changed the course of history.!

In this exclusive video program, we bring the voices of the leading representatives who stood at the forefront of this extraordinary movement. Listen as they share their personal memories, struggles, and triumphs during the Aragalaya protests that lasted for over 100 days.

Witness the power of unity, resilience, and unwavering hope as these remarkable individuals recount how the people's relentless pursuit of change led to an astonishing victory. Together, we proved that when people come together, their voices cannot be ignored.

Join us as we celebrate this momentous occasion's legacy and reflect on its immense impact on Sri Lanka's future. Let us remember the sacrifices made and honor the triumph of the power of the people.!

Don't miss this captivating video that captures the essence of a historic movement. Like, comment, and share to spread inspiration and let the world know about the unstoppable power of the people..! 

දින 100කට අධික කාලයක් තිස්සේ රටපුරාත් කොළඹ Galleface පිටියේත් පැවති පොදුජන අරගලය නිමාවී අදට හරියටම අවුරුද්දක් සම්පූර්ණ වනවා. මේ ඓතිහාසික සිදුවීම සැමරීම වෙනුවෙන් අරගලයට සක්‍රියව සම්බන්ධ වුනු, නායකත්වය ගෙන කටයුතු කළ තරුණ කණ්ඩායම් නියෝජනය කරමින් ඉන් කිහිපදෙනෙක් ඔවුන්ගේ පසුගිය මතක ආවර්ජනය කරමින් සුහද කතාබගාහක යෙදුනා.

මාර්තු 31 වැනිදා මිරිහානේදී සිදුවුයේ මොකක්ද..? අප්‍රේල් 09 වැනිදා සිදුවූයේ මොකක්ද..? ඉන් පස්සේ මාස තුනක් පුරා පැවති මේ අරගලයේ සිදුවූයේ කුමක්ද..? එය පවත්වාගෙන ගියේ කොහොමද..? මේ සියලු මතක පිළිබඳව ඔවුන් කළ කතාබහක්...

IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project worked with the Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) in Sri Lanka and private sector partners to create a national program to develop dairy farms that produce 100 liters of milk per day, the level of production identified by MOD as the ideal commercial model for sustainable dairy business. IESC supported DAPH to create dairy entrepreneur development training modules and train provincial staff to deliver the training content to dairy farmers. IESC, DAPH, and private sector partners finalized working arrangements for the national program and formed a monitoring committee to track the program’s progress and address issues that arise during implementation.

Zillur Rahman is a journalist, human rights defender, host of the popular late-night talk show “Tritiyo Matra”, and executive director of the Centre for Governance Studies (CGS).

Last month, the Bangladesh Financial Intelligence Unit (BFIU) requested all banks of Bangladesh to provide account details of the HRD and the CGS. This is the latest in a series of incidents of harassment; precluded by an ongoing smear campaign, police inquiries questioning Rahman’s relatives and neighbours regarding his political affiliation and work, a government-organised media boycott of CGS events coverage, cyber-attacks and surveillance, and more.

Front Line Defenders is seriously concerned for the wellbeing of the human rights defender and urges the authoritites in Bangladesh to immediately cease all further harassment of Zillur Rahman and colleagues at the Centre for Governance Studies.

 Read more: https://zurl.co/1IeL 
#Bangladesh

Join us in celebrating Pride Month....! 
In our latest episode of the LST Roundtable, we delve into an important conversation about the amendment of Sections 365 and 365A of the Penal Code in Sri Lanka. We address the pressing challenges faced by the LGBTIQ+ community in our country. Don't miss this thought-provoking discussion as we strive towards a more inclusive and accepting society. 

ලෝකය පුරා සිටින විවිධ ලිංගික අනන්‍යතා සහිත පුද්ගලයින් ජුනි මාසය "අභිමානි මාසය නැතිනම් Pride Month" විදිහට නොයෙක් ආකාරයෙන් සැමරීම් සිදුකෙරෙනවා. දණ්ඩනීති සංග්‍රහයේ 365 සහ 365A වගන්ති සංශෝධනය කිරීමට තිබෙන හැකියාව සහ එහි අවශ්‍යතාව පිළිබඳවත්, ලංකාව තුළ LGBTIQ+ ප්‍රජාව මුහුණදෙන අභියෝග පිළිබඳවත් සාකච්ඡා කිරීමට මෙවර LST Roundtable වැඩසටහන වෙන් කෙරුනා.

PRESS RELEASE: Front Line Defenders Director to join solidarity trip to Bahrain to free Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja

The imminent risk of death faced by prominent human rights defender and former Front Line Defenders employee Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja in prison in Bahrain has prompted our Interim Director, Olive Moore, to accompany Abdulhadi's daughter Maryam Al-Khawaja, on a trip to Manama this week to press the Bahraini authorities to release him. Abdulhadi has been imprisoned for 12 years and his life is in danger while on hunger strike, in protest of inhumane conditions in prison.

Other leading human rights figures have announced their participation in the trip, including Agnès Callamard, Amnesty International’s Secretary General; Tim Whyte, Action Aid-Denmark’s Secretary General; and Andrew Anderson, former Front Line Defenders Executive Director and Amnesty International staff member. 

See full press release for more info: https://zurl.co/JHFr 
#Bahrain #FreeAbdulhadiAl-Khawaja

Here are the highlights from the launch!

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program officially launched a new partnership with the Agricultural University of Georgia to establish improved training programs in food safety management, cooking and pastry, and culinary and restaurant management. This initiative will positively impact Georgia’s food industry by creating high-value jobs and career advancement opportunities for Georgians. Additionally, these programs will support the successful implementation of Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP), ensuring smooth operations of food service providers and establishing food safety and food quality sustainability standards in Georgia.

For 12 long years, we've urged Bahrain to free our friend & former colleague Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja and other unjustly imprisoned human rights defenders.

In solidarity, Front Line Defenders Interim Executive Director, Olive Moore, will join  Abdulhadi's daughter Maryam Alkhawaja on her upcoming trip to Bahrain in hopes of saving his life. We urge you to join the call for his and other imprisoned human rights defenders, who are on hunger strike, to be released immediately. 

Watch her message of solidarity and why we are joining this mission:

#FreeAlkhawaja

At least 4,450 human rights defenders–including their families, organizations, and communities–were affected by violations perpetrated by state and non-state actors across 22 monitored Asian countries in 2021 and 2022. 
Such findings are based on ‘Defending in Numbers: Rising Together Against All Odds,’ a biennial publication by the Asian Forum for Human Rights and Development (FORUM-ASIA), which identifies the patterns of harassment experienced by defenders in Asia. 
The publication analyses evidence captured by FORUM-ASIA’s Asian HRD Portal, a database for documenting violations against defenders in the region. It also provides recommendations for governments, UN agencies, and corporations on better-supporting defenders. FORUM-ASIA has organized a media briefing event with Law & Society Trust to launch the report they have done and that event was held in Colombo recently.

IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project is supporting Sri Lanka’s efforts to develop a national dairy development policy and strategy. This strategy will address upstream value chain activities to increase the production of quality fresh milk to meet national demand. As part of this effort, interested stakeholders, including the Ministry of Agriculture – Livestock Development Division, the Department of Animal Production and Health, the Sri Lanka Standards Institute, the Ministry of Health, and the All Island Dairy Association, are exploring pathways to improve milk quality and upgrade existing standards. The recommendations, formalized through public-private dialogue, are currently being incorporated into existing milk quality standards. During implementation of the national dairy development strategy, practical measures will be introduced to improve handling of fresh milk on the farm, during transport, and at milk collection centers to ensure quality control and increase milk production. The strategies include setting the standards, testing protocols, infrastructure improvements, incentives and penalties, and an industry code of practice. #WorldFoodSafetyDay

text: Today, on World Food Safety Day, the Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic, funded by the USDA Food for Progress program and implemented by IESC, commends the invaluable contributions of Dominican women in key roles within the phytosanitary field. Their dedication ensures the safety of food through the preservation of plant and vegetable health in the Dominican Republic. By upholding stringent phytosanitary standards, agricultural products are safeguarded for consumption both domestically and in foreign markets, including the U.S. Please join us in recognizing their efforts. #WorldFoodSafetyDay #ProyectoTraSa #ProyectoTradeSafe #TraSa Ministerio de Agricultura de la República Dominicana

text:
Given the National Human Rights Commission of India's (NHRCI) disappointing stance on grave human rights violations in the country in the recent past, Front Line Defenders and others are highly concerned that they have been chosen as the hosts of the Asia-Pacific Forum Conference of national human rights institutions of 26 countries, scheduled to take place in New Delhi on September 20-21, 2023.

The NHRCI being provided the platform to host this event amounts to an endorsement of its sub-par performance in protection and promotion of human rights, and their disregard for concerns regarding its functioning, appointment procedure, lack of pluralism, independence and transparency.

We urge the forum's Secretariat to reconsider the decision in hopes of demanding accountability "rather than providing [India] an opportunity to whitewash its disregard and non-compliance with international human rights standards."

Read the full joint letter to the Asia Pacific Forum Secretariat:
https://zurl.co/alrH

text: With support from IESC’s USAID LinkSME Project, small and medium enterprises (SMEs) can more easily identify reputable digital transformation (DX) suppliers in Vietnam. The Yellow Pages of DX solutions, featuring more than 30 pre-screened providers, were launched last month with the participation of 300 representatives from SMEs, DX solution providers, experts, and Government of Vietnam representatives. The Yellow Pages were developed by the Agency for Enterprise Development (AED) with assistance from the project as part of a national effort to modernize and promote the digitalization of SMEs. Facilitating SME access to reliable DX providers will accelerate their transformation and promises them a more sustainable support system. Click the link to access the Yellow Pages on AED’s National Business Portal: http://ow.ly/eLki50OxVFI

Without being shown a warrant or being given a reason for her arrest, Imaan Mazari was arrested by the Islamabad Police from her house at 3:30am on 20 August. The woman human rights defender was not even allowed to change her clothes before she was taken away, and the CCTV camera in her house was broken and her residence was raided. 

Although we welcome the fact that she was released last week, we condemn the wrongful arrest and prolonged imprisonment of Imaan Mazaari as a reprisal for her human rights work documenting military abuse and human rights violations in Pakistan

Read more:
https://zurl.co/HBMY

#Pakistan

text: IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project conducted an assessment of the financial viability of smallholder dairy farmers in Sri Lanka, evaluating their profitability and ability to weather economic shocks. The assessment found that farmers producing 100 liters of milk or more per day are more likely to generate sufficient income to make profits, build savings, make capital expenditures, and build sustainable businesses. Farmers implementing MOD’s best practices can generate above-average profits by increasing efficiencies in feeding and herd composition and improving cost management, even with lower production levels. IESC is working with private and public sector partners to develop their own extension services to mentor, monitor, and support farms to reach the 100L target, creating a sustainable model that will last beyond the project.

On 4th October 2023, CEJ facilitated the second training program conducted under the GGF project. The training program was conducted for a selected group of physically challenged people at Agriculture Department Gannoruwa, Kandy. The focus of the program was on plant production, issues related to plant maintenance and natural fertilizer. Later, the participants were taken on a field visit to the vegetable garden of the Agriculture Department to give them an opportunity to gain a first-hand experience in natural composting methods.

Government of Vietnam (GVN) COVID-19 assistance programs have proven difficult to implement. To improve the effectiveness of these programs, the GVN needs well-trained implementers to connect the small and medium enterprises (SMEs) eligible for assistance with service providers. On May 25 and 26, IESC’s USAID LinkSME project brought together more than 70 officials from provincial governments and business support organizations from 16 northern provinces. The event focused on assessing the eligibility of SMEs, especially women-owned SMEs, for GVN assistance. These officials will make up a substantial portion of the anticipated implementation team.

“Disturbing the public order” and “insulting the prison authorities” are the newest charges faced by these Iranian HRDs who are currently detained for other charges such as “gathering and colluding with the intention of acting against national security” and “propaganda activities against the state.” 

Their following transfer to another prison means that Kamyar Fakour will no longer be in the same prison as his also detained wife, and may not be able to meet with her weekly, and that Jafar Ebrahimi, who has lost eight kilograms due to an inflammatory disease and is diabetic, will continue to lack proper medical attention. 

We are extremely concerned by the failure of the authorities to respond effectively to Jafar Ebrahimi’s deteriorating health and condemn the ongoing judicial harassment faced by the human rights defenders.

On April 26th and 28th, USAID’s youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, hosted two Career Guidance Fairs in Mannar and Badulla in collaboration with the Uva Provincial Council, the District Secretary of Mannar, ADRA Sri Lanka, and Voice Area Federation. This guidance provides unemployed youth with knowledge and skills to help them find suitable jobs.

IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovation (ATraCSI) project’s horticultural value chain assessment (HVCA) team is traveling throughout El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras to collect primary data, conduct stakeholder interviews, and analyze findings for horticultural value chain assessments. On May 15, Bettina Balmer, HVCA Team Leader, and Napoleon Castillo, Deputy Chief of Party-El Salvador, traveled to Choluteca, Honduras, to meet with Agroindustrias Alpha and tour the facilities at San Esteban Farms. FORUM-ASIA will be launching Defending in Numbers: Rising Together Against All Odds, a biennial publication that identifies the main patterns of harassment and challenges that defenders confront within the region and displays emblematic case studies and information from Human Rights Defenders (HRDs). 

As part of the launch of Defending in Numbers, FORUM-ASIA is pleased to announce its collaboration with the Law & Society Trust to shed light on the situation of HRDs in South Asia, focusing on SriLanka. Even a year after the countrywide protest that resulted in the resignation of former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, HRDs in Sri Lanka still face targeted attacks and ongoing challenges such as judicial harassment, prolonged pre-trial detention, and surveillance. This collaborative effort aims to delve deeper into the issues faced by HRDs in the region, specifically in Sri Lanka, providing a platform for a comprehensive and specific discussion of their circumstances.

Live streaming - https://www.youtube.com/@lawsocietytrust8867

#lawandsocietytrust #forum_asia #defendinginnumbers #humanrights #HumanRightsViolations #SriLanka

Front Line Defenders and 8 other international human rights organizations, express grave reservations about the Sri Lankan government’s proposed National Unity and Reconciliation Commission:

With a long history of convening similar bodies, none of which has provided justice, truth or reparation to the many people who have engaged with them, Sri Lanka's latest initiative risks repeating the mistakes of the past, exposing victims to renewed security threats and re-traumatization without any realistic chance of a different outcome. 

"Any successful transitional justice process requires inclusive consultation with stakeholders, including with victims and civil society organizations, and substantial confidence-building measures to ensure that victims can participate without fear. It must have credibility among affected communities."

We urge the Sri Lankan government to approach transitional justice as a holistic process that includes truth-seeking, investigation and prosecution of international crimes, and effective remedies such as reparations, redress and guarantees of non-recurrence. 

Read the full statement here: https://zurl.co/xXD8

In collaboration with the Business and Technology University (BTU • ბიზნესისა და ტექნოლოგიების უნივერსიტეტი), The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program in Georgia has successfully established eight training centers across six regions for the Coding School for Women, utilizing equipment provided by USAID. These centers aim to provide enhanced accessibility to high-quality training programs for rural women, complete with computers and high-speed internet connectivity. The training program, which BTU commenced in all eight locations on May 1, offers six courses via partnerships with industry leaders to the 500 rural women and girls currently enrolled. The training opportunity has been extensively promoted, resulting in high demand from women near the centers who aspire to access industry-led training with excellent employment prospects.

Today marks 2000 days since the killing of woman human rights defender Marielle Franco, together with her driver Anderson Gomes. Marielle was a community activist for many years before becoming a city councillor in 2016. As an Afro-Brazilian, woman human rights defender, she advocated for housing rights for some of the city’s poorest and most marginalised residents, defended women’s and LGBT rights and worked against systemic racism. She had become an expert on policing and was outspoke in her criticism of the violence that often accompanied the military and police presence in Rio’s favellas.

Marielle and Anderson Pedro Gomes, a colleague who was driving her car, were shot dead by two assailants on Wednesday, 14 March on Joaquim Palhares Street, in the Central Region of Rio de Janeiro. It is suspected that this was a targeted killing meant to silence Marielle for the work she had been carrying out. 
 
Marielle is honored at the HRD Memorial in the Iveagh Gardens in Dublin City. Her daughter Luyara, a human rights defender herself, spent the last few weeks in Dublin and visited the memorial, honoring her moth. Luyara and her family, as well as her mothers friends and community allies are still looking for justice and for truth about who ordered the killing of Marielle Franco. 

Today we reaffirm our support to the family and our call for justice. Visit and support the work of the Marielle Franco Institute: https://zurl.co/bZhu

சுதந்திரம் என்பது வரையறைகளை தகர்த்தெறிவது - ஏஞ்சல் (Angel Queentus)

யாழ்ப்பாணம் எப்படியும் இருக்கமான சட்டங்களைக் கொண்ட மாகாணம்.
ஒரு சாதாரண பெண் கூட மாலை ஆறு மணிக்கு மேல் வெளியே செல்ல வேண்டாம் என்று தான் சொல்வார்கள். நான் திருநர் என்பதால் நிலைமை இன்னும் மோசம்.

பள்ளிப் பருவத்திலிருந்தே எனது பால்நிலை பற்றி எனக்குப் பிரச்சனைகள் ஏற்பட்டது. இறுதியாக நான் அதை தைரியமாக, வலுவாக எதிர்கொள்ள முடிவு செய்தேன்.

பெண்ணாய் பிறந்தால் இப்படி இருக்க வேண்டும், ஆணாய் பிறந்தால் இப்படி இருக்க வேண்டும் என்று சமூக நியமங்கள் உள்ளன. இது அனைவரின் சுதந்திரத்திற்கும் ஓர் தடையாக உள்ளது.

நாம் முதலில் பொருளாதார ரீதியாக வலுவாகவும் சுதந்திரமாகவும் இருக்க வேண்டும். அதன் பிறகு, தங்கள் அடையாளத்திற்காக தாங்கள் வேலை செய்யத் தொடங்க வேண்டும். அதுவே இப்போதைக்கு சிறந்த தீர்வு.

Transform Sri Lanka

Through the USDA Food for Progress-funded Trade–Facilitating Agricultural Systems and Technology project (Proyecto T-FAST), IESC has established fruitful partnerships with public and private institutions to facilitate trade in Paraguay. After three years of successful collaboration and achieving results, the National Institute of Technology and Standardization (INTN) and the Paraguayan Industrial Union (UIP) have extended their partnership with the T-FAST project. IESC supported INTN’s digital development by donating software and hardware and creating an online payment portal, applications, monitoring, and historical procedures related to scale verification. Through a new working group, T-FAST also collaborated with UIP to conduct a mapping study of Paraguay’s air import and export processes to address proposals for areas of improvement. #TFAST

දේශපාලන ක්ෂේත්‍රයේ කාන්තාවන්ගේ ජයග්‍රහණ සහ ඉදිරි සැළසුම් මෙන්ම අත්දැකීම් පිළිබඳව සාකච්ඡා කිරීමේ අරමුණින් නීතිය හා සමාජ භාරය විසින් නවතම වීඩියෝ වැඩසටහන් මාලාවක් නිෂ්පාදනය කළා. දේශපාලන ක්ෂේත්‍රය තුළ තම සලකුණු සටහන් කළ / කරමින් සිටින කාන්තාවන්ගේ ධෛර්යය, ආත්ම විශ්වාසය සහ ඔරොත්තු දීමේ හැකියාව සහ නායකත්ව ලක්ෂණ වඩාත් හොඳින් කැපී පෙනෙන ලෙස පොදු සමාජය වෙත ගෙනයාමේ අරමුණින් මෙම වැඩසටහන් මාලාව ආරම්භ කොට තිබෙනවා.

කාන්තා දේශපාලඥයින් සමග කෙරෙන සම්මුඛ සාකච්ඡා, බාධක මතින් ඔවුන් දේශපාලනය තුළ මෙතෙක් ආ ගමන පිලිබඳ ඔවුන්ගේ කතාවන්, වඩා යහපත් හෙට දවසක් වෙනුවෙන් දේශපාලන ප්‍රවාහය තුළ ඔවුන් ඉදිරිපත් කරන යෝජනා සහ අදහස් මෙන්ම ඔවුන්ගේ ප්‍රතිපත්ති, නායකත්ව හැකියාවන් සහ එකිනෙකට වෙනස් නායකත්ව ලක්ෂණ, වැනි කරුණු සම්බන්ධයෙන් මෙම වැඩසටහන් මාලාව ඔස්සේ කතාබහට ලක් කෙරෙනු ඇති.

The last time El Niño affected Sri Lanka, between 2016 and 2017, more than 2 million people were affected—first by flooding and landslides, and then by a severe drought. Currently in its development phase, is forecasted to peak towards the end of 2023 in the Asia Pacific region. If the situation continues, we must be ready to embrace a similar, if not worse, scenario that will have direct impact on communities, especially in the availability of water. 

Today is a particularly opportune time to bring this issue to the limelight as Sri Lanka hosts the fifth Forum of Ministers and Environment Authorities of Asia Pacific, with the aim of contributing to the outcome of the sixth session of the UN Environment Programme Assembly happening in 2024. 

The Green Climate Fund financed, Climate Resilient Integrated Water Management Project (CRIWMP) implemented by the Government of Sri Lanka together with United Nations Development Programme - UNDP in Sri Lanka, offers a blueprint to reviving Sri Lanka’s cascade system for water resilience, incorporating modern technologies and climate resilient infrastructure, climate information services and agro-met advisories to create a more sustainable dry-zone eco-system and enhance climate resilience. 

READ MORE: https://bit.ly/46CrmSx
Ministry of Environment United Nations Sri Lanka UNDP in Asia and the Pacific

On May 18th, at Making Cents International's Global Youth Economic Opportunities Summit in Silver Spring, Maryland, IESC’s USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship program, YouLead, led a presentation in partnership with ACDI/VOCA and Chemonics on the approaches, tools, successes, and challenges of building alternative pathways to get youth into the IT sector. The presentation, The Leaky Pipeline – Alternative pathways for youth in the digital economy, featured the YouLead Future Careers Bridge program as well as Chemonics and ACDI/VOCA’s IT Women – Karakalpakstan activity in Uzbekistan. In addition to best practices, the session acknowledged some of the programs' unanswered structural and systemic challenges, such as effectively encouraging rural female participation in the ICT workforce and incentivizing private sector ownership for hiring rural youth. Through the presentation, IESC and partners tapped the collective expertise of program attendees to brainstorm solutions to these and other critical questions. #GYEOSummit #YEO2030

Law and Society Trust in partnership with Young Researcher Network has conducted joint learning and research planning workshop in Jaffna recently. The purpose of the workshop was to identify possible collaborative research projects on the rural economy and agrarian issues in Sri Lanka. Debt restructuring and its impact on the rural economy, credit, indebtedness, dispossession, and social security, and women's role in agriculture value chains and in fisheries, land, and labor in the plantation economy were among some of the possible areas of research that were discussed. 

Group also visited a number of cooperative-based industries initiated and supported by the North Cooperative Development Bank as part of the economic recovery of post-conflict North.

Smashing Times International Centre for the Arts and Equality, Front Line Defenders, and partners, present the fifth annual, international Dublin Arts and Human Rights Festival from the 13 to 22 October 2023. 

Check out the full festival program here and reserve your seats early for your favourite events:
https://zurl.co/YbiU 

The festival features exciting and innovative events that promote equality, human rights and diversity through the arts, taking place in Dublin, Kerry, Donegal and Cork, with artists and speakers in attendance from Ireland, Finland, Sweden, Italy, Spain, Portugal, the Netherlands, Greece, Belgium, Cyprus, Romania, Bulgaria and Ukraine. The aim of the festival is to showcase and highlight the extraordinary work of human rights defenders in Ireland and around the world, past and present, and the role of the arts and artists in promoting human rights today.

Two participants from the IESC-implemented USDA Food for Progress-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic (DR) attended a study tour in Nicaragua for the inaugural Latin American Regional Institute for Agricultural Protection and Health conference and outbreak simulation on Fusarium Wilt. FocR4T is the fungus responsible for the Fusarium wilt of bananas and plantains (Musaceae). An outbreak of this new Fusarium race is considered a serious threat to the region, as it would drastically impact food security and banana and plantain production. IESC’s TraSa team joined the DR delegation at the conference, which participants from 12 countries attended. The study tour included information sessions, field simulations, and mobile laboratory visits. OIRSA, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), Centro de Investigación Príncipe Felipe - CIPF, IICA Nicaragua, and other international organizations coordinated the conference.

30 August marks the International Day of the Disappeared/ the UN International Day of the Victims of Enforced Disappearances. 

Governments around the world use enforced disappearances to silence human rights defenders, placing them in detention or other horrific conditions with no information of their whereabouts. 

We denounce the impunity that characterises these cases, calling for accountability for those involved in this grave human rights violation and for support for those human rights defenders working to find the disappeared and bring the perpetrators to justice. 

#InternationalDayofTheDisappeared #EnforcedDisappearances

Sri Lanka Women Lawyers' Association (SLWLA), in partnership with the Support to Justice Sector Project (#JURE), funded by the European Union in Sri Lanka and the Maldives, jointly implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP #lka  and UNICEF Sri Lanka, and facilitated by the Ministry of Justice - Sri Lanka, successfully concluded a series of workshops that focussed on developing a new strategic plan for SLWLA, for the next five years. 

The workshops covered the North, Central, and Southern parts of the country, and were attended by the executive members, key office bearers, past presidents and the regional representatives of SLWLA. The series of workshops aimed to build and strengthen the capacity of women lawyers in Sri Lanka, ensuring that they are well-prepared to reach out and make a difference; especially in the lives of vulnerable women and girls in need of legal aid and #AccessToJustice.

text:
On 20 August Atekeh Rajabi learned of a summons to court scheduled to take place the following day. The woman human rights defender and her lawyer were denied full access to the content of the indictment issued against her. She was subsequently sentenced to 6 months in prison. She has faced judicial harassment and targeting before, being arrested and charged for her protest against the series of deliberate poisonings of school girls across Iran and terminated from her job as a primary school teacher because of her engagement in the Iranian September 2022 protests. 

We urge authorities to immediately and unconditionally drop all charges against Atekeh Rajabi, as we believe she has been targeted solely as a result of her legitimate human rights work.

Read more: https://zurl.co/2drq

With the Family Planning Association (FPA Sri Lanka), UNFPA Sri Lanka is conducting health education sessions for pregnant women in Nuwara Eliya on maternal danger signals. 

With Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade support, programme ensures everyone has equal access to sexual and reproductive health services & information & healthcare.

Making motherhood safer is a human rights imperative, and it is at the core of UNFPA’s mandate. UNFPA works around the world with governments, health experts and civil society to train health workers, improve the availability of essential medicines and reproductive health services, strengthen health systems, and promote international maternal health standards.

"From the Margins of War: The Post War Experience of the Palankudi Community", a policy brief by CEPA's Social Cohesion thematic was launched on 08.08.2022. The policy brief outlines structural and institutional issues faced by the Palankudi community, with emphasis on the need for institutional recognition for indigenous rights and the palankudi identity. The brief supplements the on-going "memories from the margin" photographic exhibition. We are hiring a full-time Research Writer!
Curious to uncover intriguing stories that are just waiting to be heard? We’re on the lookout for a go-getter who does their research and produces impactful stories! 
If this sounds like your calling, join our versatile team of creatives and see how far you can excel!
Send us your CV and portfolio to shout@pulse.lk!

Job Description
- Ideating and conceptualising content
- Producing insightful and impactful audiovisual content i.e. documentaries
- Producing comprehensive and engaging infographic content
- Producing in-depth research articles
- Engaging in fieldwork
- Coordinating with multiple in-house teams and external parties
- Fact checking
- Proofreading 

Requirements
- Academic qualifications in writing/ literature/ journalism/audiovisual media
- 2 years of experience in a similar capacity
- Outstanding portfolio of work
- Excellent command of English 
- Fluency in Sinhala and/or Tamil will be an added advantage
- Attention to detail 
- Ability to work in a fast-paced environment and be a team player

We are an equal opportunity employer.
All eligible applicants will receive equal consideration for employment. 
Females are encouraged to apply.

The 2023 Commercial Mediation Symposium dives into the world of mediation - the smart choice for resolving commercial disputes! Led by the Internation ADR Centre, powered by The Asia Foundation with support from United Nations Development Programme - UNDP & UNICEF Sri Lanka's European Union in Sri Lanka and the Maldives funded 'Support to Justice Reform (JURE)' project. 

Joining the #CommercialMediationSymposium2023 yesterday was H.E Ranil Wickremesinghe President of #SriLanka & Hon. Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, Minister of Justice Ministry of Justice - Sri Lanka, along with other notable attendees in the legal landscape, exploring the critical role of mediation towards #SriLanka's growth and recovery, while striving towards achieving the #SDGs. 

Speaking at the forum, Ms. Azusa Kubota, Resident Representative, UNDP Sri Lanka noted the transformative power of commercial mediation, noting the opportunities and challenges within the landscape and the pivotal role commercial mediation plays in promoting trade & attracting foreign investments.

Vindya Silva, Partnerships Director for USAID's youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, held a lunch and learn session today for IESC's home office staff in Washington, DC, on alternative career pathways for youth in the digital economy. During the session, Vindya discussed the Future Careers Bridge program, implemented in Sri Lanka by YouLead in collaboration with SLASSCOM, which assists youth without college degrees to secure jobs in the ICT sector. She discussed the importance of building soft skills, English language skills, and more technical ICT skills as critical avenues for getting youth employment-ready. Vindya also highlighted the difficulty of creating a mindset shift within the industry to employ youth without university degrees as long as they have the requisite baseline of skills for success.

නිසි දැනුවත් කිරීම්, සංවාද ගොඩනැගීම් මගින් සමාජයේ කතාබහට ලක්නොවන, තහනම් යැයි සැලකෙන එහෙත් කතා කළ යුතුම මාතෘකා ගැන කතා කිරීමේ වැඩසටහනක් ලෙස LST TABOO TALKS අපි ආරම්භ කරා. එහි දෙවන පියවර විදිහට Queer community සාමාජිකයින් වෙනුවෙන් වඩා හොඳ සේවා ස්ථානයක් / පරිසරයක් නිර්මාණය කිරීම පිලිබඳ කතාබහකට අපි එකතු වුනා. 

මේ අභිමානී මාසයේ සැබෑ අරමුණ වෙනුවෙන් ක්‍රියාත්මක කළ යුඋතු නිසි දැනුවත් කිරීම සහ සංවාද ගොඩනැගීමට අපි මේ මගින් උත්සාහ කරනවා. පවතින සමාජ සම්මතයන් සහ සාම්ප්‍රදායික රාමු බිඳ දමමින්, අවබෝදය සහ දැනුවත් කිරීම මගින් වඩා යහපත් සමාජයක් ගොඩනැගීමේ අපේ උත්සාහයේදී තවත් මෙවැනි තහනම් යැයි සම්මත මාතෘකා පිලිබඳ විවෘත කතාබහක් ගොඩනැගීමට TABOO TALKS ඔස්සේ ඉදිරියේදීත් අපි සූදානම්.

ජුනි මාසය දේදුනු වර්ණයෙන් යුතු මාසයකි. අභිමානී මාසය නැතිනම් Pride month, සියළු මනුෂ්‍යයින්ගේ අයිතීන් සහ අභිමානය වෙනුවෙන් වන අපගේ කොන්දේසි විරහිත සහයෝගය පලකිරීමට අවස්ථාවක් කරගන්නෙමු. නීතිය හා සමාජ භාරය (Law & Society Trust) ලෙස අප LGBTIQ+ ප්‍රජාව වෙනුවෙන් වන සමානාත්මතාව සහ ඔවුන්ගේ අයිතීන් තහවුරු කිරීමද මානව හිමිකම් ආරක්ෂා කිරිමේම එක පියවරක් වන බව තරයේ විශ්වාස කරමු.

අභිමානි මාසය සැමරීම, මෙම සුළුතර ප්‍රජාවගේ අයිතීන් තහවුරු කිරීම, ඒවාට ගරු කිරීම සහ සමානාත්මතාව තහවුරු කිරීම කෙරෙහි සියලු පුරවැසියන්ගේ  අවදානය යොමුකරවන්නකි. LGBTIQ+ ප්‍රජාවේ ඇති විවිධ අනන්‍යතා සහ අත්දැකීම් සැමරීමට මෙන්ම ඉදිරියේ ඇති අභියෝග පිලිබඳ යළි යළිත් සිතා බැලීමටද කාලයක් බව සිහිපත් කිරීමට කැමැත්තෙමු.

මේ අභිමානී මාසයේදී අපි, LGBTIQ+ ප්‍රජාව  නියෝජනය කරන අපගේ වෘත්තීය සගයින්, මිතුරන්, හිතවතුන් සහ ප්‍රජා සාමාජිකයින් වෙත අපගේ සහෝදරත්වයේ දෑත් දිගුකරන්නෙමු. මේ සැමරුම් සියල්ලම ප්‍රජාවේ එකමුතුකම, සාඩම්බරය, අභිමානය සහ සවිබලගැන්වීම තීව්‍ර කරන්නක් වේවා.! යැයිද අපි ප්‍රාර්ථනා කරන්නෙමු. සෑම පුරවැසියකුගේම අයිතීන්ට සහ අභිමානයට ගරු කරන සහ අගය කරන ලෝකයක් වෙනුවෙන් සටන් කරන මිත්‍ර පාක්ෂිකයින් ලෙස අපද ඔබ සමග එක්ව සිටගන්නෙමු. 

සමානාත්මතාව සඳහා වන දිගුකාලීන සටන වර්ණවත් උත්සව වලින් ඔබ්බට විහිදයන බවද මේ අභිමානවත් මොහොතේදී සිහිපත් කරන්නෙමු. අර්ථවත් සංවාද, දැනුවත් කිරීම්, බෙදාගැනීම්, ආදරය සහ ගෞරවය දැක්වීම් සමගින් යන ඒ දුෂ්කර ගමනේ කොටස්කරුවන් ලෙස අප සමග අත්වැල් බැඳගන්නැයි ඔබට විවෘත ඇරියුමක්ද කරන්නෙමු. අප සැම එක්ව, සෑම පුද්ගලයෙකුටම වෙනස්කොට සැලකීමෙන් තොරව අභිමානයෙන් ජීවත් විය හැකි ලෝකයක් ගොඩනගමු..

CEPA signs MOU with Janashakthi Foundation and YUMA | CEPA has signed an agreement with the Janashakthi Foundation and Yuma Foundation to produce a flagship publication on inequality.  This publication which will be called the Inequality Report (TIER) Sri Lanka, will take a multifaceted approach to understanding and addressing inequality which affects a majority of people in Sri Lanka. The project intends to deepen the understanding of the subject, bringing together research, policy and dialogue. This will evolve over the next three years intending to become a key reference literature on inequality for the country. 

From left to right Ramesh Schaffter, Managing Director / Group CEO of Janashakthi Group, Karin Fernando, Acting Executive Director of CEPA and Christoph Feyen, Director of YUMA Foundation.

As we enter the vibrant and empowering month of Pride, we want to take a moment to express our unwavering support for the rights of all individuals. At Law & Society Trust, we firmly believe in equity and equality for everyone, recognizing that LGBTIQ+ rights are, indeed, human rights.

Pride Month serves as a poignant reminder of the progress we have made in the journey towards inclusivity, acceptance, and understanding. It is a time to celebrate the diverse identities and experiences within the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, and gender-nonconforming communities, as well as an opportunity to reflect on the challenges that still lie ahead.

We extend our heartfelt wishes to our LGBTIQ+ colleagues, friends, and community members. May this Pride Month be a joyous and empowering time filled with love, unity, and pride in who you are. We stand beside you as allies and advocates, committed to fostering an environment that respects and values the rights and dignity of every individual.

Let us use this month as a catalyst for meaningful conversations, education, and awareness, ensuring that the fight for equality extends far beyond the colorful festivities of Pride. Together, let us create a world where every person can live authentically, free from discrimination and prejudice.

Happy Pride Month to all...!

The SOVA Centre for Information and Analysis, a Moscow-based human rights organisation is the latest Russian human rights organisation to be shut down after a court ruling on 17 August. They have carried out important work documenting and advocating against nationalism, xenophobia and racism as well as anti-extremism legislation, religion in a secular society, and political radicalism which will now cease.

We condemn all forms of judicial harassment against human rights organisations and human rights defenders and urge the Russian government to cease their restriction of  spaces for the defense of human rights.

Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja is a Danish-Bahraini prominent human rights defender and former Front Line Defenders Protection Coordinator for the Middle East and North Africa. He has been imprisoned since 2011, when he was detained, tortured and subjected to an unfair trial on fabricated charges that led to him being sentenced to life in prison because of his human rights activities.

In protest of his continued imprisonment and denial of access to adequate medical treatment, Al-Khawaja started a water-only hunger strike on 9 August 2023. He is now at imminent danger of losing his life.

Sri Lanka’s Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) and IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project are collaborating to expand the national coverage of artificial insemination (AI) services through private AI technicians. To improve private sector AI technicians’ skills, IESC supported two University of Florida (UF) trainers to deliver eight in-person refresher training programs to 282 participants, including 68 private technicians. As most of these technicians had not received any AI training in five years, they greatly benefited from the technical knowledge imparted by the trainers, which will improve AI success rates and the dairy herd in Sri Lanka. The MOD-TRADE app, a tool for booking AI services, monitoring, and follow-up, was introduced during these sessions.

''Two years after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan on August 15, 2021, we strongly condemn ongoing and escalating gross human rights violations by the Taliban especially against women and girls and the lack of an effective response from the international community, 10 international human rights organizations stated today.

Over the past two years, the Taliban have imposed increasingly abusive policies especially against women and girls and religious and ethnic minorities that clearly violate Afghanistan’s obligations under international human rights law. Policies that ban and restrict women and girls from education, work and other livelihood opportunities, free movement and access to public spaces and services have been widely condemned. In their joint report to the United Nations (UN) Human Rights Council, published in June 2023, the UN Special Rapporteur on the human rights situation in Afghanistan and the UN Working Group on Discrimination Against Women and Girls stated that the Taliban treatment of women and girls “may amount to gender persecution – a crime against humanity – and be characterised as gender apartheid”. 

Read full statement here:

https://zurl.co/Zf5V

Law and Society Trust (LST) collaborating with FORUM ASIA conducted a two-day capacity-building workshop on Strengthening Workers' Rights in Free Trade Zones in Sri Lanka during COVID-19 and Economic Crisis. The workshop was mainly targeted at worker representatives, trade union leaders, and activists from civil society organizations in FTZs (Katunayaka, Wathupitiwala, and Biyagama) in Sri Lanka. The objectives of the workshop were to Enhance the knowledge of worker leaders (CSO and TU leaders) on the current legal frameworks on workers’ rights, Increased understanding of worker leaders on the proposed labor law reforms and their impact on workers’ rights, Identify current forms of worker’s rights violations within FTZs and identify possible actions to address them.

නීතිය සහ සමාජ භාරය (LST) මානව හිමිකම් සහ සංවර්ධනය සඳහා වන ආසියානු සංසදය (FORUM ASIA) සමඟ එක්ව COVID-19 ව්‍යසනය සහ ආර්ථික අර්බුදය තුළ ශ්‍රී ලංකාවේ නිදහස් වෙළඳ කලාපවල කම්කරුවන්ගේ ගැටළු සහ ඔවුන්ගේ අයිතිවාසිකම් ශක්තිමත් කිරීම පිළිබඳ දෙදින වැඩමුළුවක් පැවැත්වූවා.  ශ්‍රී ලංකාවේ නිදහස් වෙළඳ කලාපවල (කටුනායක, වතුපිටිවල සහ බියගම) කම්කරු නියෝජිතයින්, වෘත්තීය සමිති නායකයින්, සිවිල් සමාජ සංවිධානවල ක්‍රියාකාරීන් ඉලක්ක කරමින් වැඩමුළුව සංවිධාන කොට තිබුනා. කම්කරු අයිතිවාසිකම් පිළිබඳ වර්ථමාන නීති රාමු පිළිබඳ කම්කරු නායකයින්ගේ (සිවිල් සමාජ සහ වෘත්තීය සමිති නායකයින්ගේ) දැනුම වැඩි දියුණු කිරීම, යෝජිත කම්කරු නීති ප්‍රතිසංස්කරණ පිළිබඳ කම්කරු නායකයින්ගේ අවබෝධය වැඩි කිරීම සහ කම්කරු අයිතිවාසිකම් කෙරෙහි ඒවායේ බලපෑම හඳුනා ගැනීම, වත්මන් දේශපාලන,ආර්ථික සහ සමාජ වටපිටාව තුළ සේවක අයිතීන් කඩකිරීමේ ආකාර සහ ඒවා විසඳීමට ගත හැකි උපායමාර්ගික ක්‍රියාමාර්ග හඳුනා ගැනීම මේ වැඩමුළුවේ අරමුණ වුනා.

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program officially launched a partnership with Swiss Agricultural School Caucasus (SASC) to establish an Agricultural Training Center in the Kvemo Kartli region of Georgia. This partnership aims to create opportunities for rural farmers and dairy processors to improve their employment and productivity by giving them access to high-quality, practical skills development programs based on the principles of Swiss dual education. The training center will provide courses on animal husbandry, dairy processing, farm animal feeding, animal health, crop production and agricultural mechanization, and pasture management and forage conservation.

Abdul-Hadi Al-Khawaja is a Danish-Bahraini citizen, a recognized human rights defender and a political prisoner who has been unjustly sentenced to life imprisonment, serving this sentence in Bahrain since 2011. He has been subjected to brutal arrest, physical, psychological and sexual torture and suffered severe medical neglect in prison.

On Wednesday, August 9, Al-Khawaja began a water only hunger strike in protest of his continued imprisonment and after facing serious and consistent denial of access to adequate medical treatment. His family has reported that Friday, August 11, he was rushed to the intensive care unit of a Bahraini hospital due to urgent heart problems. Al-Khawaja's family states that the attending doctor declared that Al-Khawaja's life was in danger. 

Al-Khawaja was given an intravenous injection, which stabilized his heart rhythm after two hours. He was then returned to his cell. The next few days may be fatal. We strongly urge his release to Denmark from Bahrain, as well as meaningful dialogue between Denmark and Bahrain in order to save Al-Khawaja's father’s life and get him released to Denmark.

What can you do?
1) Share this message with your network
2) Follow #FreeAlKhawaja on social media
3) Consider contacting your local politician, government official or the Danish Ministry of
Foreign Affairs to press the case.

September 15 Global Day of Action to End Fossil Fuels: Asia
=======================================

Earlier this year, international and regional networks working for a rapid, equitable and just transition out of fossil fuels decided to escalate globally coordinated campaigning efforts in view of; very weak outcomes of COP27 on the fossil fuel phase-outs, backtracking by the G7 and other wealthy countries from their earlier pledge to  phase out public financing of fossil fuels, continued low ambition and loopholes in the decarbonization policy of public and private financing institutions, the continuing  increase in fossil fuel production globally and the aggressive push for the expansion of the gas industry justifying gas as transition fuel and using the global energy crisis as an excuse, and increase in efforts of governments and corporations to promote false solutions in the form of abatement technologies that will serve to the extend of life of fossil fuel projects.

Today we organized a protest at Galle Fort to stand with Asian Peoples' Movement on Debt and Development and demand maximization of the key moments of the United Nations General Assembly and United Nations Secretary General Climate Ambition Summit to demonstrate the escalating global fight to end fossil fuels in Asia, to demonstrate to governments corporations and institutions, media and general public that the fight against fossil fuels has broadened and heightened in the Asia region, to assert, popularize and amplify our calls and demands to complement the push for a more aggressive anti-fossil gas narrative. 

End Fossil Fuels Now! Fast, Fair and Forever!

#EndFossilFuels #FastFairForever #dontgasasia

IESC through the USAID youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, recently reached a milestone in its entrepreneurship development program, as more than 4,000 women have formalized their businesses following completion of the program.

Priyanthi Konthasena attended one of the five-day entrepreneurship development programs and has since registered her tailoring business, hiring five women from her community as employees. She commented that the program allowed her to understand how to develop a business plan and manage her company more effectively. 

In partnership with the Department of Samurdhi Development, Sri Lanka’s poverty alleviation agency, the entrepreneurship development program provides the fundamentals of starting and running a business to rural communities where most people are engaged in micro-scale agriculture or daily wage work.
Blessed Easter.

You’re looking at a Christmas tree made with thousands of upcycled plastic bottles! 

This is an annual tradition brought to life by a group of Sri Lankan youths who fight for marine life conservation around Sri Lanka; The Pearl Protectors. 

Using PET bottles the group collected over the year at their beach clean-ups, they managed to build a  tree that’s over 12 feet tall – including its various ornaments. 

More importantly, what are the Pearl Protectors trying to tell us?
No matter the season, we're in a climate emergency, and festive seasons are when our plastic footprints go through the roof. The PET bottle Christmas tree reminds us of the impact of single-use plastic and inspires hope for a more sustainable 2024.

Interact Club of Ananda College

Members of IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovation (ATraCSI) team and a member of the project’s subpartner, Asociación Guatemalteca de Exportadores (AGEXPORT), met with Victor Hugo Guzman, Vice Minister of Guatemala’s Agriculture and Livestock Ministry to discuss priorities and potential project support. Together they emphasized the need for 1) licensing imports and exports, 2) supporting and promoting value chains with improved technologies and adherence to quality and food safety standards, and 3) accessing new markets. These cooperative efforts will strengthen IESC’s approach to improving the processes of commercialization and access of agricultural products to national and international markets.

🔊 NEW PODCAST: Salah Hammouri on the cost of his activism in Palestine and the recent revocation of his residency. 

Salah tells us about how his upbringing inspired his human rights work, what the revocation of his residency means and other tactics being used to silence human rights defenders in Palestine. He gives us insights to the inhumane tactics which Israeli authorities use to break the spirit of political prisoners, systemic neglect of healthcare in prison, his own experience of hunger strikes in prison and more.

text: On April 8, IESC’s USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam and the Department of Commerce of Thai Nguyen Province organized a workshop for 160 representatives of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) on financial management and business-to-business sales strategy. The workshop also provided an overview of Vietnam’s economic forecast for the remainder of 2023 and solutions for SMEs to manage economic difficulties. Participants expressed interest in learning about sound financial management and connecting with lead firms. The workshop is part of USAID LinkSME’s support to SMEs in rebalancing financial resources and increasing their access to finance as they recover from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program in Georgia officially launched a partnership with Kutaisi University Campus (KUCA) to establish a Cybersecurity Training Center at the University. With support from the Program and major partner Kutaisi International University (KIU), KUCA will address the skills gap by creating a high-value and economically competitive workforce in Georgia’s cybersecurity sector. KIU has partnered with the US-based International Council of Electronic Commerce Consultants (EC-Council), the world's largest cybersecurity technical certification body, to guarantee international certification of trainees.

Last month as part of its International Women’s Day celebration, IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic and the Ministry of Agriculture’s Department of Plant Health recognized 23 women professionals working in the phytosanitary sector. During the award ceremony, the honorees were recognized for their outstanding contributions to the sector related to plant quarantine inspections, pesticides, field inspection, and academic and laboratory work, among others.

“The women we are recognizing represent the forefront of defense against various phytosanitary threats to the Dominican Republic. The country has suffered quite recently from the entry of pests and exotic diseases such as the Mediterranean fly and African swine fever. With the increase of tourism and the efforts to convert the Dominican Republic into a regional logistics hub, threats have increased significantly. This underscores the importance of honoring these professional women today,” said Brian Rudert, TraSa’s Chief of Party. #ProyectoTraSa #ProyectoTradeSafe #TraSa #TradeSafe Ministerio de Agricultura de la República Dominicana

The US Ambassador to Sri Lanka recently visited the country’s largest dairy farm, Ambewela Farms. The visit was facilitated by the USDA Food for Progress-funded Market Oriented Dairy (MOD) project implemented by IESC. During the visit, Ambewela’s leadership team provided a walkthrough of their facilities and an overview of the dairy farm’s work to date with the MOD Project. Thanks to IESC and its partners from the University of Florida, Ambewela’s staff have received training on artificial insemination and technical guidance on food rationing, hoof care, and farm management practices. Senior staff even participated in a business exchange where they shared best practices and ideas with large dairy farms in Florida and Georgia. With better practices in place, their cows have better comfort, nutrition, and care, leading to higher milk productivity.

The Small and Medium Enterprise Development Fund (SMEDF) of Vietnam’s Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) provides loans with concessionary terms to SMEs. It has struggled to reach its target audience, however, mainly due to a lack of skills in assessing SMEs’ loan eligibility and potential lending risks. On March 16-17, IESC’s USAID LinkSME project trained 18 SMEDF credit officers on credit appraisal and risk control for Vietnamese SMEs. Enhancing the credit appraisal skills of SMEDF credit officers will help improve SME access to finance, bridging the gap between SMEs’ capital needs and capital on offer from mainstream banks and financial institutions.

On March 8 and 9, members of IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovations (ATraCSI) team observed import and export facilities at Puerto Barrios in Guatemala. ATraCSI Chief of Party Ray Waldron, Guatemala Deputy Chief of Party Isabel Gonzalez, and Director, Trade and Enterprise Gabriela Kliewer met with representatives from Empresa Portuaria Nacional Santo Tomás de Castilla (EMPORNAC) to discuss the project and tour the port’s enclosure. The team was able to discuss opportunities and obstacles to imports and exports and port operations to improve trade facilitation.

Front Line Defenders was devastated to learn about the passing of the woman human rights defender and writer Viktoria Amelina as a result of the injures she incurred in a Russian missile strike in the city of Kramatorsk, Ukraine, where she and her colleagues carried out their peaceful and non-violent human rights work. The organisation got to know Viktoria Amelina when she visited Front Line Defenders’ and Smashing Times' Dublin Arts and Human Rights Festival in October 2022, where she discussed her project “War and Justice Diary: Looking at Women Looking at War” and had a drawing workshop for Ukrainian children refugees. Front Line Defenders expresses sincere condolences to Viktoria Amelina’s family and loved ones.

Full statement: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/ukrainian-woman-human-rights-defender-and-writer-viktoria-amelina-killed-russian

Last week, IESC staff from the Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) Tanzania program joined USAID Tanzania to meet with the Minister of Agriculture in Dodoma, Tanzania, to discuss shared priorities. Together with the Ministry of Agriculture’s access to finance technical staff, IESC and USAID Tanzania shared details about F2F’s focus on alleviating barriers to accessing finance, particularly for rural farmers, women, youth, and other marginalized populations. They discussed how F2F and the USAID Mission’s activities could help advance the Ministry of Agriculture’s goals by enhancing rural access to finance throughout the country.

Olivier is a Congolese environmental rights defender and lawyer from North Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo. He has dedicated his life’s work to advocating for environmental rights, land rights and land justice; pushing for transparent, accountable, and sustainable governance of land tenure regimes for the country’s lands. In 2008, he co-founded the NGO ‘’Alerte Congolaise pour l’Environnement et les Droits de l’Homme’’ , through which he has actively supported and represented local communities, groups and individuals working on the environment for over 15 years.

Olivier has been persecuted and faced grave danger due to his human rights work, targeted by recurring death threats and an attempted assasination, which caused him to flee his home country and go into exile for his own protection. He has been severely beaten and tortured by security forces; once to the point of needing hospitalisation for 12 days. His organisation has also faced attempts of sabotage such as robbery and break-ins. Despite these harrowing circumstances, he is hopeful and inspired to continue securing justice for the victims of land and environmental injustices in the DRC, especially at-risk and vulnerable groups like women and children.
Olivier is known as the ‘’Green Lawyer’’ in North Kivu because of his defence of Virunga Park and its workers and people. The communities he has represented face economic expropriation and exploitation of their land and resources. In the context of the DRC, this has affected women and children most – many women have lost their husbands in the conflict and are left vulnerable. They are then driven off their land, which has plunged them into grave insecurity. Olivier has ensured that they, and other vulnerable victims, are not forgotten.
