On March 6, The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program officially launched a partnership with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) to advance Georgia’s EU Association agenda and support Government of Georgia reforms in the healthcare sector. The reforms aim to harmonize the nursing profession with the regulations and the country’s newly adopted Nursing Development Strategy.

Through this partnership, USAID and EBRD are joining forces to establish a Public-Private Dialogue platform to develop workable strategies for nursing professionals with a specific focus on advancing their skills, competencies, and career opportunities. This will streamline the adoption of Georgia’s upcoming regulatory framework on nursing.

The MOU signing event gathered, from left to right, USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program Chief of Party David Blood, USAID Mission Director John A. Pennell, Minister of Internally Displaced Persons from the Occupied Territories, Labor, Health, and Social Affairs Zurab Azarashvili, EBRD Regional Head for the Caucasus Catarina Bjorlin Hansen, and Deputy Minister Tamar Gabunia.

Last month, members of IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovations (ATraCSI) team visited the Chamber of Commerce and Industries of Choloma (CCICH) and the Chamber of Commerce and Industries in Puerto Cortes (CCIPC) in Honduras. ATraCSI Chief of Party Ray Waldron, Guatemala Deputy Chief of Party Isabel Gonzalez, and El Salvador Deputy Chief of Party Napoleon Castillo met with Alejandra Mejía from CCICH and Yolibeth del Cid from CCIPC. During the meeting, the ATraCSI team discussed the five-year project and potential areas of collaboration. Together they examined the production, processing, and marketing of horticultural products in Central America. These collaborative efforts will strengthen IESC’s approach to increasing the trade of horticultural goods and cultivating productive value chains in El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras.

In Sri Lanka, the USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project, implemented by IESC, has developed a unique climate-smart dairy model to enable small- and medium-scale dairy farmers to both mitigate climate impacts and adapt to the changing climate. In our initial tests with 27 dairy farmers, the tool has helped farmers to increase productivity and reduce their emissions rate while identifying key areas for on-farm improvements and informing future training efforts. This initiative has the potential to help achieve emissions reduction targets while improving farmer incomes and increasing national milk supplies. You can read more about the climate-smart dairy model in this article, which was recently published on Agrilinks: https://agrilinks.org/post/practical-tool-drive-climate-smart-dairy-production-sri-lanka

====================================

2023.09.08

පළමුවෙන්ම පැහැදිලි කල යුත්තේ අදාල වාර්තාව තුල සැසඳීම කර ඇත්තේ ශ්‍රී ලංකාව තුල නෛතික වශයෙන් අවසර දී ඇති පළිබෝධනාශක තුල අන්තර්ගත සක්‍රිය සංයෝග සහ 2022 පෑන් ලැයිස්තුව (PAN international consolidated list of banned pesticides, 6th Edition, May 2022) අතර සංසන්දනයකි. මෙම සංයෝග ලෝකයේ යම් යම් රටවල තහනම් කර ඇති අතර, වාර්තාවේ එම එක් එක් සංයෝගයට අදාලව තහනම් කරන ලද රටවල් සංඛ්‍යාවද දක්වා ඇත (https://pan-international.org/pan-international-consolidated-list-of-banned-pesticides/). මෙම හඳුනා ගැනීම ලෝක ආහාර හා කෘෂිකර්ම සංවිධානය  සහ ලෝක සෞඛ්‍ය සංවිධානය  විසින් අධි අන්තරායකර පළිබෝධනාශක නිර්වචනය කිරීම සඳහා ජාත්‍යන්තරව පිළිගෙන ඇති නිර්වචනයම නොවේ. PAN ලැයිස්තුවේ වර්ගීකරණයේ මෙම හඳුනාගැනීම් දෙයාකාරය පැහැදිලිව වෙන්කොට දක්වා ඇති අතර, එයින් පරිබාහිරව රටවල් 133ක් විසින් තහනම් කර ඇති පළිබෝධනාශක ක්‍රියාකාරී කාණ්ඩ මෙම ලැස්තුවේ දක්වා ඇත.  

කෘෂිකර්මාන්තයේ හෝ ගොවියාගේ අවශ්‍යතාවය මත හෝ ලෝකයේ ජීවත්වන රට මත රසායනිකයක විෂ සහිත බව වෙනස් නොවේ. වෙනස් වන්නේ ශරීරගතවන  මාත්‍රාව, නිරාවරණය වන කාලය සහ වාර ගණන, නිරාවරණය වන මාර්ග මත (ආහාර මාර්ගය හරහා, සම තුළින් අවශෝෂණය වීම හරහා, ආශ්වාස කිරීම හරහා, එන්නත් කිරීම හරහා) හෝ  පුද්ගල ස්වභාවය මත (ප්‍රතිශක්තිය; පෝෂණ ස්වභාවය; හෝමෝන; වයස; ස්ත්‍රී පුරුෂ භාවය; සෞඛ්‍ය තත්ත්වය; පෙර සිට පැවතෙන රෝගී තත්ත්වයන්) වැනි සාධක පදනම්වය. මේ නිසා රටක නෛතික පද්ධතියට වැදගත් විය යුත්තේ රසායනිකයක් සම්බන්ධ විෂ සහිත භාවය පිළිබඳ තොරතුරු බව අප විශ්වාස කරමු. සරලව ගත්කල, ග්ලයිෆොසේට් වැනි ලොවම පිළිගත් හානිකර රසායනික (https://pan-international.org/wp-content/uploads/Glyphosate-monograph.pdf) පිළිබඳ තීරණ ගැනීම, දේශපාලනික, සමාගම්වල අවශ්‍යතාවය හෝ ආර්ථික හානිය හුවා දක්වමින් සිදු කිරීම පිළිගත නොහැක.

මෙම වාර්ථාවේ ගෘහස්ථ පළිබෝධනාශක යන්නෙන් අදහස් කරන්නේ නොවැම්බර් 24, 2016  දින නිකුත් කල අතිවිශේෂ ගැසට් අංක 1994/71 තුල ගෘහාශ්‍රිත පළිබෝධනාශක උපලේඛනය හරහා අනුමත කරන ලද ගෘහාශ්‍රිත පළිබෝධනාශක ලෙස වර්ගීකරණය කර ඇති පළිබෝධනාශක වේ. අවශ්‍යතාවය මත ගෝවීන් මේවා වගාවේ කෘමි හානි වැළැක්වීමට භාවිත කිරීම (උදාහරණ වශයෙන් මල් වගාවේ කැරපොතු හානි වැළැක්වීමට භාවිත කිරීම )  ද්විතීයික කරුණකි. පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍රය මෙම අනාවරණයෙන් පැහැදිලි කිරීමට උත්සාහ කරන ලද්දේ ගෘහාශිතව මෙම රසායනික වලට නිරාවරණය වීමේ ඇති අවධානමයි.

අවසාන වශයෙන් පළිබෝධනාශක නිසි ලෙස ඇගයීමට ලක් කර සුදුසු විකල්ප නිර්දේශ කිරීම මත ප්‍රතිස්ථාපනය කිරීමට පලිබෝධ නාශක රෙජිස්ට්‍රාර් කාර්යාලය ගත් තීරණය අගය කරන  අතර, පලිබෝධ නාශක රෙජිස්ට්‍රාර් කාර්යාලය විසින් ලෝක සෞඛ්‍ය සංවිධානයේ වාර්තා කියවා ඇති බව පෙනෙන්නට තිබෙන බැවින් ඔවුන් විසින් අධි අන්තරායකර පළිබෝධනාශක සම්බන්ධයෙන් ගතයුතු ක්‍රියාමාර්ග පිළිබඳව පහත කරුණු සම්බන්ධයෙන්ද අවධානය යොමු කරනු ඇතැයි අපේක්ෂා කරන්නෙමු.
1. අධි අන්තරායකර පළිබෝධනාශක හඳුනාගැනීම සහ තවදුරටත් ලියාපදිංචි කිරීම වැළැක්වීම.
2. අධි අන්තරායකර පළිබෝධනාශක බෙදා හැරීම සහ අලෙවි කිරීම වැළැක්වීම
3. පාරිසරික කෘෂිකාර්මික භාවිතයන් දිරිමත් කිරීම මෙන්ම තිරසාර විකල්ප විසඳුම් ලබා දීම සඳහා ආයෝජනයන් සිදු කිරීම
4. ජෛව පළිබෝධනාශක සඳහා වෙළඳපොළක් ගොඩ නැගීම
5. නවෝත්පාදන සහ හරිත රසායනික සඳහා ආයෝජනය
6. පළිබෝධනාශක සහ පළිබෝධනාශක ආලේපිත බීජ සඳහා අවදානම් තක්සේරු ක්‍රියා පටිපාටි වැඩි දියුණු කිරීම ඇතුළු අනෙකුත් නිර්දේශ…
 
“PAN international consolidated list of banned pesticides, 6th Edition, May 2022” පළිබෝධනාශක පිළිබඳ වාර්තාව සඳහා සබැඳිය: (Consolidated List of Banned Pesticides (download) https://pan-international.org/pan-international-consolidated-list-of-banned-pesticides/

text: Following the delivery of in-depth surveys and strategy reports to 50 small and medium enterprises (SMEs), IESC’s USAID LinkSME project and the Agency for Enterprise Development (AED) in Vietnam finalized a list of 25 SMEs that will receive further support in developing digital transformation (DX) roadmaps. Over the last month, the project and AED met with and presented initial roadmaps to four of the SMEs on the shortlist located in central and southern parts of Vietnam. The roadmaps provided each SME with a master plan for their DX implementation over the next three years, along with detailed steps, timelines, and tentative DX solutions.

Today is Nelson Mandela International Day. 

Nelson Mandela has been described as the ultimate public servant.

“What counts in life is not the mere fact that we have lived. It is what difference we have made to the lives of others that will determine the significance of the life we lead.” 
Nelson Mandela

Today is more than a celebration of Nelson Mandela’s life and legacy. 

CPA Sri Lanka is proud to join the global movement to honour his life’s work and act to change the world for the better.

MAKE EVERY DAY A MANDELA DAY

The message behind Mandela Day is simple – each individual has the ability and the responsibility to change the world for the better.

If each one of us heeded the call to simply do good every day, we would be living Nelson Mandela’s legacy and helping to build a country of our dreams.

The baton of leadership has been handed over to us. It is in our hands now to make a positive difference.

IESC’s USDA-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic conducted a workshop together with MERCADOM (mercadom_rd) to present the results of their safety audit carried out at 35 locations selling meat and dairy products, as well as cafeterias and places where prepared food is sold. Food safety and meat inspection are critical to the improvement of the Dominican market for US exports. IESC and the TraSa team of veterinarians and food safety experts work with MERCADOM to keep staff up to date with the latest industry trends and insights. #ProyectoTraSa #ProyectoTradeSafe #TraSa #TradeSafe

In honor of International Women’s Day this month, the USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project in Sri Lanka, implemented by IESC, celebrates the women entrepreneurs who have expanded their businesses and discovered new revenue streams after attending MOD training sessions and applying MOD best practices. Through MOD’s efforts to advance women's economic empowerment in Sri Lanka’s dairy value chain, IESC has delivered technical training or entrepreneurial guidance to nearly 1,600 women dairy farmers and over 40 women input retailers. For instance, Ms. Pavithra, an input retailer, expanded her product range and multiplied her monthly sales volume by fifteen. Check out her story and the inspiring stories of other women here: https://youtu.be/ZThmxS7XUeg
#EmbraceEquity

USAID LinkSME, implemented by IESC, and the Agency for Enterprise Development (AED) finalized the 2022 Annual Report on Enterprise Digital Transformation (DX), which explores the readiness of Vietnamese enterprises to apply DX solutions. The report highlights key trends in DX readiness, summarizes milestones achieved in the Ministry of Planning and Investment’s (MPI) DX program, and features inspiring success stories from enterprises that have applied DX solutions. The report was formally announced in a February 16 workshop organized by USAID LinkSME and AED. It highlighted the availability and potential usefulness of information on DX for Vietnamese small and medium enterprises (SMEs) through the MPI.

Theater provides a creative avenue to engage with communities on their views on social issues.

Women In Need (WIN) with UNFPA Sri Lanka and the Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade conducted awareness sessions using forum theater to address issues that students face, especially in the online space. 

Technology and online spaces are increasingly being misused and weaponized against women and girls on the basis of their gender. Technology-facilitated gender-based violence takes many forms and carries significant consequences for women and girls, for their families and communities.

Digital Security Lab Ukraine (DSLU) was established in 2017 to address digital security concerns of human rights defenders and organisations in Ukraine. Civil society voices have always been strong in Ukraine, reaching a peak in 2013 with the EuroMaidan clashes, aimed at overthrowing a pro-Russian government. Russia’s war in Ukraine, that started with occupation of Crimea in 2014 and destabilisation and shadow support to the so-called separatist movement in Donetsk and Luhansk regions in eastern Ukraine, has posed a grave danger to human rights defenders in the occupied territories.

When Russia launched its full-scale invasion in Ukraine on 24 February 2022, human rights defenders and groups experienced blackouts and disruptions in communications due to Russia’s shelling of Ukraine’s critical infrastructure. There have been significant fluctuations in internet connectivity in many regions of Ukraine, impeding the ability to document and report on war crimes and human rights violations. DSLU’s work has been integral to rebuilding digital security infrastructure and documentation of war crimes, ensuring that organisations could continue to operate by providing and setting up satellite internet kits for teams working on documenting and reporting war crimes.
Despite the circumstances of the war, while many fled to safety, DSLU stayed on the ground, recognising the crucial digital needs of the context. This was not easy and came with significant safety and security challenges. They continue to work hard to combat online censorship and provide means of communication during the invasion to ensure that crucial information can be shared and exchanged despite the barriers. Despite growing physical security risks amid the ongoing conflict, they continue to provide digital security support to HRDs and HROs in Ukraine.

Segundo Ordóñez is an Afro-descendant human rights defender from Esmeraldas, Ecuador. His family migrated from Tumaco, Colombia when he was a child, due to the violence and poverty they experienced there. For most of his life in Ecuador, he lived and worked on abacá (Manila hemp) plantations with abacaleros (Manila-hemp worker), for the Japanese company ‘’Furukawa Plantaciones C. A’’ – a company which produces and exports abacá fibre. Abacá is formed from the stalks of banana trees, used and exported to the US and Europe for paper money, rope, teabags, cars and more. Ecuador is the second largest exporter of abacá fibre, yet those who farm the raw materials have done so under slavery-like conditions.

Abacaleros, including Segundo, united after years of discrimination, and took the company and the State of Ecuador to court, accusing them of plunging at least three generations of impoverished rural workers into conditions of modern slavery. With the support of the civil society solidarity committee “Furukawa Nunca Más”, constitutional and criminal proceedings were instituted against the company but so far they have not achieved justice or any type of reparation for the abacaleros. When the case became public in 2019, the company retaliated and demolished some of the camps where abacaleros and their families lived, and evicted hundreds of other families from the camps. Segundo, along with a group of abacaleros, resisted the evictions by remaining in two of the camps owned by the company – an occupation which continues four years on.
Inspired by his bravery and ability to maintain community cohesion, Segundo became the representative of his community in legal proceedings, playing a key role in confronting the company in court and in public, which has also come at a risk to his life.
As a result of his resistance, he has been targeted in a number of ways ranging from consistent harassment, ‘’SLAPP’’ and other lawsuits filed by the company to intimidate and discredit him, and more recently, death threats.

Jeany Rose Hayahay is an indigenous woman human rights defender based in Mindanao, Philippines. She advocates for indigenous peoples’ rights, focusing on children’s right to education. Rose played a significant role in uniting indigenous and community-based schools in Mindanao and coordinated with national groups on a campaign to stop militarisation, environmental plunder and land grabbing of ancestral lands. She has faced violence from different authorities many times during peaceful protests, yet she has persisted in her cause with courage, leadership, and dedication. She became the spokesperson of the Save Our Schools Network (SOS Network) in 2019, a network of child-focused NGOs, church-based groups and other stakeholders who bring attention to, and take action regarding the ongoing violation of children’s right to education, particularly in the context of militarisation and attacks on schools.

Rose’s journey began as a volunteer teacher for the Lumad communities in Mindanao, during which time she raised awareness on the human rights violations the Lumads were facing. Beyond basic education, Rose also taught practical skills such as agriculture that would help students enrich their environment, culture, and defend their ancestral lands. Rose helped build a communal farm in several schools for students to have hands-on experience with agriculture.
Rose was a part of the ‘’Lumad Bakwit school” from 2018 until 2021, where hundred of indigenous students from southern Philippines gather in main cities to protest against human rights violations of indigenous and minority groups. As the spokesperson of SOS Network, she is at the forefront of many public gatherings, protests and meetings, and is consistently red-tagged and monitored as a leader, facing reprisals and threats, both directly and indirectly. She is at high risk of being killed, arrested or imprisoned yet continues to lead at the forefront with determination and courage.

Hala Ahed is a Jordanian woman human rights defender and lawyer. Born in December 1971 in Kuwait, Hala moved to Amman, Jordan when she was 10 years old, and has lived there since. Hala has conducted significant work in the human rights landscape in Jordan, and is well recognised in civil society as a trusted leader and ally. The focus of her work has been women’s rights, but within the political context of Jordan, she has also worked across freedom of opinion and expression, labour rights, and trade union freedoms.

Despite her vital work and advocacy, Hala has endured various forms of intimidation and harassment, including being summoned multiple times by the Jordanian General Intelligence Directorate (GID). She has recieved threats from authorities who have gone as far as threatening her son in order to get to her. Hala grew her public legitimacy by increasing her visibility and public profile, and building a support network which has given her public credibility.
Most recently, Hala was a victim of NSO’s Pegasus digital hacking spyware initiated by the government. It was found that she was being surveilled when her mobile device was infected with Pegasus in March 2021. In other instances, Hala was targeted with online defamation campaigns where government-backed social media accounts would storm her account with harassment. Over the years as a lawyer, Hala represented and defended human rights defenders, activists, rights movements, civil society organisations and trade unions, making herself known as a strong ally for civil society in Jordan. She supported multiple unions with voluntary legal representation, including the Jordan Teachers’ Syndicate which represents more than 14,000 teachers; and the Agricultural Association. Her human rights work goes beyond the realms of her desk and books. Despite all the obstacles, dangers and restrictions she faces for her human rights work, Hala continues to be dedicated in her pursuit of improving the human rights situation in Jordan for all.

The United Nations in Sri Lanka is concerned that fraudulent messages regarding an application portal to register with the World Food Programme (WFP) are circulating via short message services and social media.

We urge anyone with doubts about the authenticity of a message purportedly from, for, or on behalf of WFP or other UN agencies to send an e-mail to rcs-unsrilanka@un.org or visit our global fraud alert network at www.un.org/en/aboutun/fraudalert.

Front Line Defenders is excited to announce a fellowship opportunity in our Communications & Events team - for recent graduates interested in developing a career in communications/events within the international human rights field. 

The Communications and Events Fellow will be based in Front Line Defenders’ office in Blackrock for 30 hours per week, and will:

-Provide support to the Visibility and Communications Officer, including but not limited to: administrative and substantive tasks around the creation, design, dissemination and monitoring of social media content and multimedia materials (e.g. videos and podcasts).
 -Assist with capturing and recording multimedia content at FLD events.
 -Provide support to the International Events and Promotions Coordinator, including with the creation and upkeep of guest and supplier lists, tracking visa applications and flights, and drafting of materials for events.
- Upload approved content (Urgent Appeals, Statements, human rights defender profiles, etc.) to the Front Line Defenders website.
- Assist in archiving images related to Front Line Defenders’ field work to protect human rights defenders.
- Assist in drafting and designing, as requested, media materials or content to support Front Line Defenders events.
-Carry out administrative duties as required.
 

See full details here:   
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/recruitment-volunteering?width=740&height=500&inline=true#job-40--description&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

Ananda College Old Boys' Association hosted the Olcott Oration of 2023 in memory of the yeaman services rendered by their founders. This event took place on 25 November at Kularathna Hall.

The annual Olcott Oration, a flagship event of the Ananda College Old Boys' Association (ACOBA), featured a distinguished speaker, Prof. Buddhima Indraratna, discussing "Advances in Sustainable Transportation Infrastructure" this year.

The oration, dedicated to the founders of Ananda College, honors Col. Henry Steel Olcott's contributions to Buddhism and education.

Embark on Fathima Aroosa's remarkable journey – a passionate innovator from Majma Nagar, Oddamavadi. Aroosa spearheads Project M Grow Agri Products, revolutionizing agriculture. For a decade, her family cultivated a diverse range of crops, blending tradition with modern techniques.

Aroosa, a Biosystems Technology scholar specializing in Agricultural and Environmental Technology, seamlessly merges innovation and tradition. Join us amidst Majma Nagar's lush fields, where Aroosa's dedication and inventive farming methods shine. Witness her empowerment of farmers and sustainable farming practices firsthand.

Let's celebrate her inspiring journey and amplify the transformative power of small agricultural businesses. Share and support to contribute to this vital agricultural revolution today!

In 2022, human rights defenders (HRDs) in the Americas continued to transform their societies and communities. Their long-standing role in defending land and territories, access to justice and building peace was fundamental to sustain creative responses to persisting challenges in the region. 

Despite the adverse context, women human rights defenders (WHRDs) and LGBTIQ+ groups continued to flourish and creatively build new leaderships. Although the region saw positive political changes as a result of important elections, the political will to protect HRDs continued to be largely absent. The criminalisation of defenders, including WHRDs, journalists and anti-corruption defenders was unrelenting during the year.

In addition to the threat of criminalisation, those defending indigenous peoples’, Afro-descendant communities’, land and environmental rights were exposed to persistent and alarming levels of violence by both state and non-state actors, including widespread killings. In the midst of a prevailing rhetoric of “gender ideology” that has become normalised in the region in recent years, the risks to LGBTIQ+ defenders and WHRDs remained particularly acute. 

Read more regional analysis on the #Americas in our #GlobalAnalysis22 from page 34: https://zurl.co/sPxc

A webinar on "Southern Perspectives on international assistance to Democracy and Human Rights: Is donor support fit for Purpose?"
 
It is scheduled for 27th April from 12 pm BST. The event will feature four representatives who have been at the forefront of efforts to nurture the quality of democratic governance working in different organisations in Ghana, Kenya, Pakistan and Sri Lanka, and they will also discuss their experiences working with donors and how donor support could be more effective.  

The link to register is here: https://twpcommunity.org/southern-perspectives-on-international-assistance-to-democracy-and-human-rights-is-donor-support-fit-for-purpose

***********************************************************
අලි මිනිස් ගැටුම ශ්‍රී ලංකාව තුළ ඉතා පුළුල් ලෙස පැතිර පවතී. එය දැනට රටෙන් අඩකට වැඩි ප්‍රමාණයකින් සහ මුළු වියළි කලාපයෙන්ම වාර්තා වේ. ගරු ජනාධිපතිතුමාගේ මඟපෙන්වීම මත ජනාධිපති ලේකම්වරයා විසින් පත් කරන ලද ජනාධිපති කමිටුව මගින් කෙටි කාලීන සහ දිගු කාලීන අලි මිනිස් ගැටුම අවම කිරීම සඳහා ජාතික ක්‍රියාකාරී සැලැස්මක් 2020 ජූලි 22 වැනි දින ඉදිරිපත් කරන ලදී.
Human-elephant conflict is very widespread in Sri Lanka. It is currently reported from over half the country and almost the entire dry zone. On the direction of His Excellency the President, the Presidential Committee to Prepare a National Action Plan for Human Elephant Conflict Mitigation was appointed by the Secretary to the President on the 22nd of July 2020. This Action Plan proposes activities providing results in the short, medium and long term.
Committee members
Dr. Prithiviraj Fernando, Chairman, Centre for Conservation and Research Secretary
Mr. Vernon Perera, Additional Secretary, Ministry of Environment & Wildlife Members
Dr. Sumith Pilapitiya, Former Director General, Dept. of Wildlife Conservation
Dr. U. K. G. K. Padmalal, Senior Lecturer, Open University of Sri Lanka
Dr. S. Wijeyamohan, Senior Lecturer, Vavuniya Campus, University of Jaffna
Mr. Chandana Sooriyabandara, Director General, Dept. of Wildlife Conservation

IESC’s Farmer-to-Farmer Access to Finance program celebrates International Women’s Day by promoting financial inclusion and ensuring that women in Tanzania have access to financial services. Working with Equity Bank Tanzania LTD, F2F volunteer experts have targeted the gender gap in accessing formal financial services – a significant barrier to achieving gender equity. F2F and Equity Bank trained 251 women from 12 village saving and loan associations (VSLAs) in Morogoro and Mvomero districts to build their budgeting, saving, and financial planning skills so that the women farmers can achieve their business goals. Equity Bank, in turn, developed a specific financial product called the Mwanamke Fanikisha loan product specifically geared towards women lacking material assets that would allow them to access finance in the traditional marketplace. Because of this intervention, more women farmers in Tanzania have access to bank accounts and financial services, enabling them to grow their agribusinesses. #IWD2023 #EmbraceEquity

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program's new grant partnership with Business and Technology University Georgia (BTU • ბიზნესისა და ტექნოლოგიების უნივერსიტეტი) Georgia will train 1,500 women across rural regions of Georgia in software development, user experience design, graphic design, and digital marketing. The regional outreach and preorientation campaigns aim to identify, educate, empower, and engage diverse groups of women and girls in the targeted communities, and increase enrollment in ICT training programs. The project aims to break gender stereotypes in the industry and raise awareness about women's career prospects in the ICT sector nationwide, thereby diversifying the country’s qualified ICT workforce. #IWD2023 
(Video posted with permission from BTU)

Fraudulent or misleading claims using the United Nations name and emblem are circulating on social media, websites, e-mails, phone calls and messaging services.

Recipients of such messages are advised to exercise extreme caution, and to not respond to requests for the transfer of funds or for the provision of private information. Anyone with doubts about the authenticity of a message purportedly from, for, or on behalf of the United Nations Sri Lanka or its officials, is encouraged to send an e-mail to rcs-unsrilanka@un.org  or to our global fraud alert network at www.un.org/en/aboutun/fraudalert/

உத்தேச புதிய பயங்கரவாத எதிர்ப்பு சட்டமூலத்தை திரும்ப பெறு.
தற்போதுள்ள பயங்கரவாதத் தடைச் சட்டத்திற்குப் (Prevention of Terrorism Act) பதிலாக புதிய சட்டத்தை கொண்டு வருவதற்கு தற்போதைய அரசாங்கம் நடவடிக்கை எடுத்து வருகிறது. ஒட்டுமொத்தமாகப் பார்த்தால், இந்தச் சட்டமூலம் மக்களின் அடிப்படை உரிமைகளுக்கும், இலங்கையின் சர்வதேச மனித உரிமைக் கடமைகளுக்கும், ஜனநாயகத்துக்கும் எதிரானது என்பது தெளிவாகிறது.
எனவே, இந்த சட்டமூலத்தை அரசாங்கம் உடனடியாக திரும்பப் பெற வலியுறுத்தி பொதுமக்கள் மனுவில் கையொப்பம் பெறும் முயற்சியில் சிவில் சமூக ஆர்வலர்கள் ஈடுபட்டுள்ளனர். கீழே உள்ள இணைப்பின் ஊடாக இந்த மனுவில் கையொப்பமிட்டு முன்மொழியப்பட்ட சட்டமூலத்திற்கு உங்கள் எதிர்ப்பை தெரிவிக்கவும்.

Withdraw the proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill
The incumbent government is working to bring a new Act to replace the existing Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). Taken as a whole, it is clear that this draft bill goes against the basic rights of the people, Sri Lanka’s international human rights obligations, and democracy. Therefore, civil society activists have come together to sign a public petition urging the government to withdraw this bill immediately. Express your opposition to the proposed bill by signing the petition at the link below.

Our #GlobalAnalysis22 showed that human rights defenders (HRDs) in Asia faced unprecedented challenges in 2022 as they pushed back against regressive states, including legal persecution combined with misuse and abuse of anti-terrorism frameworks and growing restrictions on the rights to privacy and freedoms of expression, assembly and movement. 

Over the years, state authorities across the region have regularly targeted and vilified HRDs with impunity, branding them as terrorists and exposing them to harm through legal and extra legal means. During the year, women human rights defenders (WHRDs), especially those with intersecting identities that are traditionally persecuted, were particularly affected. 

While indigenous peoples’ rights defenders and those protecting land and environmental rights against corporate and state interests faced heightened risks. Meanwhile, governments extended their extra-territorial reach to target defenders in exile and pursued increasingly sophisticated forms of digital surveillance of defenders and repression of freedom of expression online.

Despite this hostile context, HRDs persisted in challenging governments’ anti-rights
agendas and policies that harm and undermine citizens, while consistently speaking out
alongside the most marginalised communities. Defenders steadfastly countered negative
misinformation campaigns, exposing the increasingly unconvincing narratives depicting
HRDs and their communities as serious security threats. 

Read more regional analysis on Asia for 2022 from page 46:
https://zurl.co/PCkP

Our #GlobalAnalysis22 showed that HRDs in #Africa faced criminilisation and attacks for pushing for civic freedoms in the face of human rights violations, corruption and authoritarian governments.  

In several countries, counter-terrorism imperatives were used to justify the restriction of civil society operations and the brutal repression of protests, with security forces using excessive and in some cases lethal force.

Land, indigenous peoples’ and environmental rights defenders consolidated their networks, enhancing collective strategies of resistance, while denouncing companies responsible for human rights and environmental abuses. 

Authorities’ intolerance for those defending economic, social and cultural rights persisted as did impunity for attacks against them. Women, feminists and LGBTIQ+ defenders faced threats, violence and discrimination and dangerous while regressive legislation to criminalise LGBTIQ+ communities was pursued by several governments during the year.

HRDs working in contexts of conflict and crisis faced extreme risks and danger when conducting their human rights work. 

Read more regional analysis on #Africa from page 22 in our #GlobalAnalysis22:

https://zurl.co/Sqht

Prof A D V de S Indraratne honoured by the Organisation of Professional Associations of Sri Lanka (OPA)

We are very proud to announce that Prof Indraratne, member of our Advisory Council, has been awarded a National Apex Award for his outstanding contribution to the country in the field of economics at the 26th annual conference and National Apex Awards held by the Organisation of Professional Associations of Sri Lanka on September 24 and 25 in Colombo.

Prof Indraratne (pictured right) received his award from Mr. Maithri Sirisena, Minister of Health (pictured left).

The inaugural apex award ceremony highlights the talents and achievements of members of the affiliated professional associations in Sri Lanka and this year's annual conference focussed on the theme Human Capital Towards 2020.

text: IESC’s USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam is supporting the Administrative Procedure Control Agency (APCA), the Office of the Government (OOG), and the Management Information System (MIS) center to conduct field trips to three regions in Vietnam. They will survey the readiness of local information systems and the ability of localities to connect and provide data on proposed socio-economic indicators. Comments and feedback from these field trips will help the experts at the MIS center and APCA formulate the socio-economic indicator framework, in turn helping Government of Vietnam leaders make better decisions based on accurate and timely information concerning socio-economic issues, especially those related to the business environment.

Uththara was 14 when she was kidnapped by someone she knew from her hometown in Rathnapura. For almost two years, she was held captive somewhere in Colombo. While being abused by her captor, she was exposed to Colombo’s trafficking, drugs, casinos and nightlife culture. 

After she was let go, she went back home to her mother in Ratnapura, but quickly got tired of the village life. So, she came back to Colombo, using the last bit of her money. To earn money, she danced at different clubs in Colombo. That is when she met her boyfriend. 

For her, unprotected sex and abortions became a norm. But when she got pregnant because of her boyfriend, Uththara decided to keep the baby. But because of their differences, her relationship ended. Then she brought her mother to Colombo, who stuck by her through all her trials and tribulations. 

Now Uththara is a mother herself, navigating the world as she continues her trade as a sex worker, to give a better life for her daughter.

text: On February 15, 2023, The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program in Georgia and partner PMCG (Policy and Management Consulting Group - PMCG) hosted the 4th Business Leaders’ Council meeting. Leading Georgian business decision-makers and stakeholders met to discuss Georgia’s Development Strategy–2030, which emphasizes priority and high-growth economic sectors such as ICT, logistics, transport, and tourism. They also discussed the labor market, unemployment in Georgia, and the role of business in economic development. The group raised several important issues requiring special attention, such as employee working hours in specific sectors, the need to promote medical tourism, ICT sector development, and the need to train IT specialists to address worldwide tech industry trends.

Today, on the 12th anniversary of his detention,  we reiterate the call to free imprisoned HRD #Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja and drop all charges against him, including his life sentence. 

Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja is an internationally respected human rights defender who won the Martin Ennals Award for Human Rights Defenders in 2022, elected by a jury of ten of the world’s leading human rights NGOs. He has a long history of working to promote human rights in the MENA region and championing the protection of human rights defenders at risk, including working as the MENA Protection Coordinator for Front Line Defenders, serving as President of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights (BCHR) and Founding Director of the Gulf Centre for Human Rights (GCHR).

He was arrested on 9 April 2011; and was detained, tortured and subjected to an unfair trial on fabricated charges, that led to him being sentenced to life in prison because of his human rights work. That sentence was deemed arbitrary by the UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention as far back as 2012.

Throughout his detention, Mr Al-Khawaja has endured various forms of reprisals, including physical and mental torture. 

We will not rest in calling for his freedom. 

#Bahrain must #FreeAlkhawaja now.

Share the call.

Kamal Shrimp Farm in Wilathawa, Chilaw is a leading shrimp exporter with a farm that sprawls over 2 acres. The process of raising larvae into shrimp takes roughly 4 to 5 months but is an effort that has a high energy requirement. The shrimp ponds need to be aerated for at least 22 hours a day, which costs the farm over a million rupees each month. UNDP's intervention has provided Kamal Shrimp Farm with the capital to invest in solar aerators. This not only allows the farm to save on costs and increase its profits but also sets the groundwork for transitioning the entire industry towards renewable energy. 

To learn more about this #SouthSouthCooperation intervention  click on the link below and read the full article. 
https://undpsrilanka.exposure.co/paddling-towards-a-sustainable-future

On Tuesday, February 14, 2023, members of IESC’s USDA Food for Progress-funded Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovations (ATraCSI) team visited Puerto Cortes, the largest port and industrial center in Honduras. ATraCSI Chief of Party Ray Waldron, Guatemala Deputy Chief of Party Isabel Gonzalez, and El Salvador Deputy Chief of Party Napoleon Castillo met with Dr. Orlin Ramirez of the National Food Safety and Quality Service (SENASA). Together they analyzed export and import issues, visited cold chain facilities, and discussed sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) inspection measures and customs coordination. These efforts will support IESC in improving food safety, customs coordination, and overall trade facilitation in El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras.

WIF organized a series of COVID 19 relief support programmes for our women entrepreneurs. First being the psychological support sessions to provide help to those in need better face and manage the pandemic and resulting conditions. Then we organized a series of Leadership training sessions to better equip women entrepreneurs face the changing environment. These sessions presented a leadership model which the entrepreneurs can easily relate to and practice in their day to day life. 

Our third programme planned under the COVID 19 relief is a technical support and follow up programme where we will equip the women entrepreneurs with important knowledge and skill areas vital to survive in a crisis situation. Areas such as financial literacy, digital finance, taxation, law will be discussed in the programme. Also the programme will have a rigorous follow up support to ensure that you successfully connect with the entrepreneurial eco system. This programme will commence by early July and interested and committed women entrepreneurs are requested to connect with us to enroll with the programme. 

Thanks to our generous support organisations, donors and volunteers, all these sessions are conducted free of charge to help women entrepreneurs succeed and grow. 
These programme are currently limited to Sri Lankan Women Entrepreneurs. 

#womenentrepreneurs #covid19support #wif #support #survive #relief #Srilankacan

In 2022, the 3 most targeted sectors for HRDs were land, environmental and indigenous rights, freedom of assembly and freedom of expression.

🔴 Pervasive levels of impunity combined with limited access to justice enabled ongoing criminalisation, combined with other forms of violent attack, to be used to silence and derail the crucial work of indigenous peoples’, land, territory and environmental rights defenders. These defenders faced persistent and violent attacks as authorities, companies, landowners and farmers sought to further advance their commercial interests through the violent expropriation of land and ancestral territories. 

In the face of expanding extractive, agro-industrial and tourism projects, defenders and their communities were subjected to armed attacks, forced evictions and displacement, destruction of property, stigmatisation, surveillance, criminalisation, enforced disappearances and killings. 

🔴 Journalists and HRDs working on freedom of expression by documenting, collecting evidence of and exposing corruption and human rights violations during protests and in other contexts of serious repression were criminalised and targeted with office raids, intimidation, digital attacks and
surveillance. 

🔴 Around the world new waves of social protest erupted as citizens demonstrated against rising inflation, costs of living and fuel, and poor labour conditions, while also denouncing more fundamental grievances around corrupt and abusive governance. Crackdowns using disproportionate and brutal force were widespread, making the act of peaceful protest increasingly unsafe for demonstrators and defenders. Criminalisation of HRDs who led, mobilised or documented violations occurring in the context of protests was also commonplace during the year.

Read more here: https://zurl.co/B1Tc

Click to see recent examples of mass public #protests across the world with similar motivations to Sri Lanka’s current context. 

Protest is foundational to a functioning democracy. It is a tool that can be used to stand up to power and to challenge injustice and oppression. History has proven that protest is a powerful force for social change. However, as these recent examples have shown, change takes time, consistency in effort, political will and critical reforms.

CEPA’s recent study (https://bit.ly/3NrwFeP) investigates the majoritarian, populist rhetoric which materialised across the country in 2019. The close monitoring of the rhetoric in physical and virtual spaces show that current events have shifted the narrative, especially in relation to the notion of the “common enemy” which has changed from one community against the country to the public vs the state apparatus. This was evident in the mass circumvention of and disregard for the social media ban. In order to understand where we’re headed right now, it is imperative to understand the genesis. We continue to closely monitor the situation for a deeper understanding of what created this shift in the rhetoric and narrative, and the way forward in terms of implications for social cohesion. 

#SriLankaCrisis #EconomicCrisisLK #lka #SriLanka

text: With the support of IESC’s USDA-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic, a delegation of Dominican cold chain industry leaders attended a study tour in Veracruz, Mexico to observe best handling practices of perishable products. Led by IESC’s implementing sub-partner, the Global Cold Chain Alliance – World Food Logistics Organization (GCCA-WFLO), the observation tour included a visit to one of Mexico’s most important ports and strategic logistics connection centers. With IESC's support, study tour participants returned to the DR with knowledge of best practices and network sharing to improve their business models and resources. Through TraSa, Dominican ports are developing technology, systems, and processes to handle perishable goods in line with food safety standards that ensure quality and safety are maintained. #ProyectoTraSa #ProyectoTradeSafe #TraSa #TradeSafe

On January 27th, Ultramarathon runner Hyun Chang Chung became the first person to successfully run the entire 300 kilometers of The Pekoe Trail, a long-distance walking trail in Sri Lanka developed by the European Union-funded Tourism Resilience Program in collaboration with USAID and implemented by IESC, on behalf of Sri Lanka Tourism. Designed as a 22-day walk from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya, Chang averaged five kilometers an hour over the course of 59 hours to complete the trail in two and a half days. A veteran of many similar runs, such as the Hong Kong Four Trails race, Chang described The Pekoe Trail as being on par with some of the best trails in the world. Chalaka Gajabhu, Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotions Bureau, expressed his delight that Chang had chosen to run The Pekoe Trail. He believes that his amazing feat will help attract further interest from new traveler segments, such as adventure seekers. The Pekoe Trail will be open for visitors in Summer 2023. Read more here: http://ow.ly/oPPO50MTfKK 
Serendipity Trails #ThePekoeTrail #VisitSriLanka #TravelSriLanka #SerendipityTrails

Our #GlobalAnalysis22 showed that governments’ tactics of repression transcended digital spaces as they continued to extend their dominion over the online sphere including through a range of cybercrime legislation, collusion with social media companies, digital surveillance and internet shutdowns.

The reform or passing of new cybercrime legislation - often on the justification of counter-terrorism imperatives - further restricted one of the few remaining channels for dissent and access to information. This type of legislation enabled provisions ranging from prohibiting VPN use, permitting internet shutdowns, removal of  content critical of authorities, surveillance, censorship, interception of communications, retention of user data and penalties for tech and telecommunications companies that fail to cooperate, among other abusive provisions.

Read more here: https://zurl.co/c3fb

IESC’s USDA-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic produced the third episode of its podcast, which focused on food safety and the fight against African Swine Fever. It featured special guest Dr. Silvia La Osa Tortosa, veterinarian and TraSa’s Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) and Animal Health Specialist. ▶️Killings of human rights defenders as a result of their work around the world continued to increase in 2022, totally 401, with Colombia bearing almost half of these killings. 

HRD Memorial partner Somos Defensores recording a staggering 186 killings of
defenders to date. Limited state presence in remote territories continued to leave HRDs
exposed to violence, especially members of local civic structures and social organisations.

In the absence of the state, these HRDs have taken on a very visible role in the promotion
of the 2016 Peace Accords in their territories, including the implementation of some of the
provisions of the Accords and the protection of at-risk populations, but with limited state
support and protection. In 2022 alone, 72 defenders working with Community Action
Boards (Juntas de Acción Comunal22) were killed. 

Read more about this alarming reality here:

https://zurl.co/6z0N

USAID Farmer-to-Farmer program volunteers Deonath and Harris teamed up in Tanzania to support MUCOBA, a community bank that provides loans and other financial services to rural farmers outside of Iringa. Together, Deonath and Harris supported the community bank by re-evaluating their loan monitoring and recovery strategies to decrease its non-performing loans (NPL) ratio, which is the percentage of loans given that are never repaid. With IESC’s support, the volunteers trained community bank management and staff on risk management and other strategies they can employ to increase the likelihood of loans being repaid. Overall, this training supports the bank in expanding its ability to serve rural farmers in Tanzania, especially youth and women. Tanzanian volunteer Deonath (left) is pictured with an onion farmer who has benefitted from MUCOBA’s financial services.

IESC is excited to announce the launch of a new youth-focused USAID program in North Macedonia. The five-year, $7 million Youth Actively Create Opportunities (YACO) Activity will increase youth’s positive contributions to society and collective leadership by creating partnerships in support of economic opportunities attractive to youth; strengthening youths’ competencies for jobs, progressive careers, and civic life; and promoting values and experiences that underpin self-reliance such as responsibility, independence, lawfulness, strong ethics, and civic engagement. Read more about this exciting new program here: http://ow.ly/8nMY50MPtJk

Despite being one of the fastest growing industries in Sri Lanka, the ICT field is experiencing a shortage of workers. In collaboration with SLASSCOM, USAID’s youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, implemented the Future Careers BRIDGE program, a learning platform to assist youth without college degrees to secure jobs in the ICT sector, to tackle the problem. Over 23,000 youth, including 10,000 women, have enrolled in this program. To date, more than 100 of those youth have received jobs from BRIDGE partners, while others have found work in related fields or launched their own ICT ventures. 

A recent update to BRIDGE, known as 2.0, has added nine new learning streams, including networking, visual design, cybersecurity, and customer service, to help provide enrolled youth with additional skills vital to success in the ICT industry.  With the additional offerings, IESC is helping to further Sri Lanka’s digital transformation across all sectors while increasing youth employability and meeting industry needs for skilled workers.

🔊 Front Line Defenders Global Analysis 2022 on human rights defenders at risk out now:

The report details the variety of killings (data from HRD Memorial), risks, threats and attacks faced by HRDs around the world in 2022, and provides examples of HRDs continuing to defend and advance the rights of their communities and societies despite threats to their lives.  

2022 saw a significant increase in killings, threats, and criminilisation of HRDs, but despite an assault on human rights and the rule of law in many countries, human rights defenders showed remarkable courage and persistence in advocating for more democratic, just and inclusive societies in 2022.  

''Across nearly all countries, human rights organisations, networks and social movements pushed back against deepening authoritarianism and closing civic space, mobilising for change while expanding collective voices and responding to the needs of the most marginalised and targeted communities. Even in the most violent contexts, feminist, women and LGBTIQ+ defenders repeatedly stood up for their communities and against discrimination, while strengthening their networks and forming broader alliances. Nevertheless, this steadfast and courageous defence of human rights often came at significant cost to HRDs ''.

Read the full report now for in-depth analysis and data both globally and regionally:

https://zurl.co/9gu5  

#GA22 #GlobalAnalysis22

Jewelex Agri Kumaragama Pvt Ltd. is a mango orchard in Thanamalwila.  The company boasts 75 acres of mango trees and access to 300 acres of mango plantations in the country. They harvest 3000 to 4000 mangoes on average everyday. 

Once harvested, fruits need proper processing and cold storage. The lack of which results in 40% of the produce going to waste. 

The company consumes 2,500 kWh and spends close to Rs. 4 lakhs per month for electricity. A cost that directly impacts the profits they make. 

To learn how #SouthSouthCooperation has supported Jewelex Agri to become a #Sustainable and environmental friendly venture and in turn helped them increase their revenue, click on the link below and read the full article. 
https://undpsrilanka.exposure.co/fresh-green-and-sustainable

Due to the ongoing drought in Kenya, Wega Dairy Cooperative was on the brink of dissolving. With drastically reduced milk collection from its members and the inability to meet its debt obligations, the livelihoods of its 10,000 members and their families were at stake. IESC’s Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) volunteers supported the dairy cooperative in all areas - from developing a business plan and rebranding to training farmers on dairy herd reproduction. With support from IESC’s F2F volunteers, Wega successfully turned business around, growing its farmer membership base by 3,000, improving milk quality, and securing a better price for its farmers. Read more about Wega’s success here: https://iesc.org/f2f-weathering-the-drought/

Iran's "amnesty" of WHRDs is "aimed at deceiving" the world - Imprisoned Iranian WHRD Narges Mohammadi delivered a powerful statement to the UN Human Rights Council #HRC52 at a recent side event organised by Impact Iran and co-sponsored by Front Line Defenders.

Six WHRDs, on their release from prison following the Supreme Leader's amnesty, took off their scarves and shouted “Women, Life, Freedom” and “Death to Dictator”. They’ve been summoned and charged with gathering and collusion aimed at disrupting national security by the Branch Two of the Interrogation Unit of Evin’s Prosecutor’s Office.

The USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam, implemented by IESC, performs pre-evaluations of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to identify areas to improve their manufacturing and quality management capabilities. These evaluations often lead to additional project support in forging successful linkages with lead firms. On December 28, the project worked with a lead firm to pre-evaluate SME Cunmac in Binh Duong province. Cunmac produces roll-forming roof panel machines, which could meet the lead firm's demand for steel brackets. The project will complete the pre-evaluation report this month and follow up with the lead firm. (Photo by: Cunmac)

Front Line Defenders and partners presents its Annual Lecture for 2023. taking place from 29-31 March 2023:

Presented by Iranian feminist activist, journalist and writer Parvin Ardalan, join us for ''Jin Jian Azadi / Woman Life Freedom: A social vision for human dignity and human rights''

The government’s murder of Jina Amini in September 2022 rocketed Iranian society into a revolutionary moment where women emerged as a symbol of resistance at the intersection of all forms of discrimination. In this paradigm shift, the past and current protest movements are linked together through the celebrated slogan of “Jin Jian Azadi”. 

In her lecture, Parvin will unpack the current revolutionary moment in Iran. How and why did the government’s murder of Jina take us to this particular point? Join us as Parvin discusses the radical potential and meaning of ''Jin, Jian, Azadi'' (Woman, Life, Freedom). She will insist on the entangled relation of the three elements of this slogan and as such will argue that this slogan by linking the everyday and material necessities of life to the abstract notion of ‘rights’ opens a new horizon of feminist politics for Iran, in specific and the human rights discourse in general.  

More info and registration here:

https://zurl.co/UrZo?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

PRESS STATEMENT:

Irish Government should use St. Patrick’s Day diplomacy to urge protection of human rights defenders

Irish Government ministers visiting dozens of countries to mark St. Patrick’s Day should use the opportunity to ensure their counterparts protect human rights defenders (HRDs) and enable them to carry out their peaceful work unhindered, Front Line Defenders said today.

The call comes as Ireland’s Department of Foreign Affairs dispatches 36 representatives on diplomatic visits to 44 countries to mark Ireland’s national holiday – in what it describes as its “biggest ever” such initiative to promote “Global Ireland”. 

The Irish Government has repeatedly stated that it prioritises HRDs and their protection in its foreign policy. At Front Line Defenders’ biennial Dublin Platform event held at Dublin Castle in October 2022, Jack Chambers, TD, then-Chief Whip and Minister of State for Sport and the Gaeltacht said: “Human Rights Defenders are humanity’s best hope for justice and accountability.” 

Many more HRDs are at constant risk of a wide range of intimidation, including physical and online attacks, smear campaigns and arbitrary detention, as a result of their human rights work. Some are imprisoned unjustly for years on end. 

READ FULL STATEMENT HERE:
https://zurl.co/AEOZ?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

IESC is excited to announce that the 5-year, $30.8 million USDA Food for Progress-funded Horticulture Uplifting and Energizing Resiliency through Trade (La Huerta) project in Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador has changed its name to Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovations (ATraCSI). This new name demonstrates the program’s objectives to implement international and risk-based Sanitary and Phytosanitary Regulations (SPS) measures, implement measures under the existing World Trade Organization (WTO) Trade Facilitation Agreements (TFA), and assist in strengthening Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) through development and transfer of agriculture technologies that focus on effective, sustainable, and environmentally friendly use of agricultural resources. Read more about IESC’s newest program here: https://iesc.org/program/food-for-progress-atracsi/

STATEMENT: Harassment of human rights defenders in earthquake region must stop 

Front Line Defenders is deeply concerned about the reports of violence, legal harassment, arbitrary arrests and threats against human rights defenders in the regions affected by the devastating earthquake in Turkey and calls Turkish authorities to not obstruct their work. Human rights defenders who were perceived as criticising the government are specifically targeted by security forces on the ground. 

Read full statement here:
https://zurl.co/QuGO

"Covid 19 and Women in Sri Lanka". A comprehensive analysis into the current situation and its impact on Women published on today's Daily FT by Ms. Seroshi Nandasiri, Chair & Founder of WIF. 

Quote: 
At the forefront of the country’s health battle against COVID-19 are women. The nursing fraternity is dominated by women and a staggering 62% of health and social work jobs are also being held by women (Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, 2016). As indicated by the Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, in 2016 more than half of the medical students in Sri Lanka since 2000 have been women and around 70% of students enrolled in paramedics are also women. This is an indication of the level of representation and contribution women make in the battle against the pandemic, and also an indication as to how this important human capital generates return on investment (ROI). 
The most overlooked is the impact on women, an important resource which comprises 51.97% (World Bank, 2018) of the Sri Lankan population. 
Unquote. 
#covid19, #women #impact #battle #srilanka #empowerment

UNFPA #SriLanka & UNDP Sri Lanka launch a project supported by High Commission of Canada to Sri Lanka and Maldives with Ministry of Justice Sri Lanka & Ministry of Women, Child Affairs & Social Empowerment focusing on enforcement, services & prevention for #genderbasedviolence to ensure women, girls & gender minorities are empowered.

United Nations Development Programme - UNDP#lka's social innovation lab - Citra Lab, carried out the administration and analysis of a national citizen survey, to better understand the current socio-economic context and the nature of multi-dimensional #vulnerabilities affecting households in Sri Lanka. 

The National Citizen Survey 2022-2023, captures a snapshot of the socio-economic and #Governance impacts felt at the household level. The survey was administered to a nationally representative sample of 25,000 households across all 25 districts.

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

Ms. Houayheuang Xayabouly, also known as Muay, is a Lao tour guide and shop owner. She is also an environmental and woman human rights defender that contributes to the protection of the rights of the Lao people by highlighting the harms caused by business activities and corruption, as well as calling for solutions to redress this. 

As a result of Muay's human rights work, she was made an example of by the Lao PDR government. She addressed corruption, called out unfair practises by businesses and companies, and denounced the impacts which they had on the Lao people. 

As a result, she is currently imprisoned, facing a sentence of 5 years and a fine of 20 million Kip. Due process and standards were not followed in her pre-trial detention and summary trial. 

You can sign a petition calling for her release here:

https://zurl.co/GwuZ 
https://zurl.co/F158 

 #IWD2023 #IWD #InternationalWomensDay #whrds #iwd23

Under the Ministry of Industry and Trade, Paraguay’s National Institute of Technology, Normalization and Metrology (INTN) serves as the National Standards Body, overseeing the development and application of technical standards, such as certification, testing, and research for industries and enterprises. Through a series of planning sessions, IESC’s USDA-funded Trade–Facilitating Agricultural Systems and Technology (Proyecto T-FAST) project is supporting INTN to strengthen its financial planning and resource mobilization tools. Directors and officials of the INTN worked on a joint diagnosis to determine opportunities for improvement in the regulation of technical standards and to develop solutions for short, medium, and long-term implementation. With IESC’s support, INTN is achieving greater efficiency, increasing the overall quality of Paraguayan trade and supporting its position in global markets. #INTN #TFAST #USDA

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

The context for WHRDs in Iran is dire. Amidst the break out of protests in Iran in late 2022, a number of WHRDs were arrested as a means of silencing protesters and dissent. Additionally, there was also a crackdown on prominent WHRDs who were already active in human rights work before the protests.

We have highlighted below a few cases of Iranian WHRDs who are currently imprisoned on trumped up charges. We call on authorities to:

We call on authorities to:

- Release all WHRDs immediately 
- drop all charges against them 
- end the harassment against WHRDs for their peaceful human rights work
- guarantee the protection of their physical and psychological integrity 

   #IWD2023 #IWD #InternationalWomensDay #whrds #iwd23

ඊයේ දිනයේදී (09/08/2023), CEJ විසින් GGF ව්‍යාපෘතිය යටතේ පැවැත්වූ ගෙවතු සහ කාබනික පොහොර නිෂ්පාදනය සඳහා අදාළ පාරිසරික කෘෂිකර්මාන්තය පිළිබඳව පුහුණු වැඩසටහනට පහසුකම් සපයන ලදී. මෙමෙ පුහුණු වැඩසටහන පේරාදෙණිය උද්භිද උද්‍යානයේ, මල් වගාව සහ භූ දර්ශන උද්‍යාන පාසලේ දී පවත්වන ලදී. මහනුවර දිස්ත්‍රික්කයෙන් තෝරාගත් ආබාධිත සහිත පුද්ගලයින් පිරිසක් සඳහා කාබනික කෘෂිකර්මය පදනම් කරගත් ස්වයං රැකියා ප්‍රවර්ධනය කිරීම මෙම පුහුණු වැඩසටහනේ අරමුණ විය. මෙම පුහුණු වැඩසටහනේදී ස්වභාවික ගෙවතු වගාව තුළින් පැළ නිෂ්පාදනයේ යෙදිය යුතු ආකාරය සහ එය පවත්වාගෙන යන ක්‍රම, මල් පැළ සහ එළවළු වර්ග, පැළ නිෂ්පාදනය සඳහා වෙළෙඳපොළ අවස්ථා පිළිබඳව දේශන පවත්වන ලදී. ඉන් අනතුරුව පුහුණු වැඩසටහනට සහභාගිවුවන් උද්භිද උද්‍යානය වෙත ක්ෂේත්‍ර චාරිකාවක් සඳහා කැඳවා ගෙන ගොස් ඒකාබද්ධ ගෙවතු වගාව පිළිබඳ වැඩිදුර ඉගෙනීමට අවස්ථාව ලබා දෙන ලදී.

Yesterday (09/08/2023), CEJ facilitated a training programme on agroecological practices applicable to home gardening and organic fertilizer production under the GGF project. The training was held at the School of Floriculture and Landscape Gardening, Botanical Gardens Peradeniya. The aim of the training programme was to promote organic agriculture-based self-employment for a selected group of physically challenged people in Kandy District. The lectures were conducted on how to engage in plant production through natural gardening and the methods of maintaining it, flower seedlings and vegetable types, and market opportunities for plant production. The participants were then taken on a field visit to the Botanical Garden to give them an opportunity to learn more about joint gardening.

நேற்று (09/08/2023), CEJ ஆனது GGF திட்டத்தின் கீழ் வீட்டுத் தோட்டம் மற்றும் கரிம உர உற்பத்திக்கு பொருந்தக்கூடிய வேளாண் சூழலியல் நடைமுறைகள் குறித்த பயிற்சித் திட்டத்தை நடத்தியது. பேராதனை தாவரவியல் பூங்காவில் உள்ள மலர் வளர்ப்பு மற்றும் இயற்கை தோட்டக்கலை பள்ளியில் பயிற்சி நடைபெற்றது. கண்டி மாவட்டத்தில் தெரிவு செய்யப்பட்ட மாற்றுத்திறனாளிகள் குழுவிற்கு இயற்கை விவசாயம் சார்ந்த சுயதொழிலை ஊக்குவிப்பதே இந்த பயிற்சி திட்டத்தின் நோக்கமாகும். இயற்கை தோட்டம் மூலம் தாவர உற்பத்தியில் ஈடுபடுவது மற்றும் அதனை பராமரிக்கும் முறைகள், மலர் நாற்றுகள் மற்றும் காய்கறி வகைகள், தாவர உற்பத்திக்கான சந்தை வாய்ப்புகள் குறித்து விரிவுரைகள் நடத்தப்பட்டன. பங்கேற்பாளர்கள் பின்னர் தாவரவியல் பூங்காவில் ஒரு களப்பயணத்திற்கு அழைத்துச் செல்லப்பட்டு, கூட்டுப் பசளை பற்றி மேலும் அறிந்து கொள்ள அவர்களுக்கு வாய்ப்பளிக்கப்பட்டது.

#StoriesOfResettlement: Pushpakanthi sells fish with her husband. Without proper methods for storing fish and reduced demand for fish, they faced difficulties in earning a profit. UNDP provided a deep freezer and a digital scale and conducted a training programme on how to preserve and pack fish for the market, allowing the family to finally earn a profit. Keerthana, a budding seamstress received training through UNDP on how to improve her sewing and marketing skills. This has allowed her to expand her business. Sinthuja makes cement bricks for a living. The knowledge gained through UNDP's workshops has helped improve profits and allowed her family to construct a barrier wall and make much-needed repairs to the house. Priya, a textile shop owner, has expanded her business by utilising her learnings through UNDP's training programme and has now built a new building with proper showcases, and more clothes. 

The Support for Durable Resettlement (SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, sustainable livelihoods and income generation opportunities. 

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP in Sri Lanka together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the British High Commission Colombo, across 4 Districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee.

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

Spotlighting Floriane Irangabiye,  WHRD and journalist from Burundi who has been detained for over six months. In 2019, she co-founded Radio Igicaniro, a Rwanda-based online outlet established by Burundian exiles and expatriates. Her arrest is an attempt at silencing her and the work being done at Radio Igicaniro.

We call for her immediate release and for all charges against her to be dropped.

With assistance from the USAID LinkSME Project in Vietnam, implemented by IESC, the Administrative Procedure Control Agency (APCA) of the Office of the Government (OOG) gathered 90 participants from various People’s Committees and Tax and Social Insurance Departments from the northern provinces, as well as representatives of government ministries, to share their experiences in implementing administrative procedures through One Stop Shops (OSS). The OSS model is a key element of LinkSME’s support to digitize and streamline administrative procedures, such as business registration, export-import procedures, and tax payments. This support aims to make government-to-business interactions more predictable, accountable, and efficient.

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

Spotlighting Lesbia Artola from #Guatemala, a member of the CCDA (Campesino Committee of the Highlands) in Guatemala. She fights against sexism in all its forms, works to amplify the voices of women human rights defenders and promotes gender equality. Lesbia also fights for men and women’s equal exercise of the right to land, as well as for Campesino rights.

Lesbia has courageously and bravely resisted the extermination of native people in Guatemala, while fighting for access to land and labour rights for Mayan indigenous in Guatemala. Through her human rights work she has consistently been subjected to threats, intimidation and defamation shrouded in misogynistic and racist overtones. 

We call for:

- all charges + lawsuits against Lesbia to be dropped
- authorities to guarantee her protection and safety
- authorities to hold accountable those who are targeting and harassing her for her work 

https://zurl.co/hUBT  #IWD2023 #IWD #InternationalWomensDay #whrds #iwd23

A sustainable dairy sector is critical for Sri Lanka’s food security, health, and prosperity, all of which have suffered due to the ongoing economic crisis. The Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock Division requested that the USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project, implemented by IESC, support the development of a national dairy policy and strategy through a public-private dialogue. In November 2022, MOD brought together more than 100 dairy sector professionals from across the government and private sector to determine policy direction and strategic approaches required to meet the country’s fresh milk needs. Based on these discussions, MOD consultant Dr. Don Mitchell will draft the dairy sector policy document for the Ministry of Agriculture in early 2023.

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

Spotlighting Gulnara Dzhurabayeva, Klara Sooronkulova, Rita Karasartova, and Asya Sasykbayeva - #Kyrgyzstani women human rights defenders who have peacefully opposed the transfer of ownership of the Kempir-Abad water reserve from Kyrgyzstan to Uzbekistan.  On 24 October 2022, the WHRDs were arbitrarily arrested and detained for their peaceful protest against tranferring the ownership of the Kempir-Abad water reserve from Kyrgyzstan to Uzbekistan. They have remained in pre-trial detention since their arrest, now more than 4 months. 

We call on authorities to:

- Release the WHRDs immediately 
- drop all charges against them 
- end the harassment against them for their human rights work
- guarantee the protection of their physical and psychological integrity

The poor working conditions faced by garment workers in Sri Lanka's Export Processing Zones (EPZs) are concerning. Various human rights violations and safety concerns are faced by workers, particularly female and transgender workers, who are exposed to sexual harassment and abuse in the workplace. Most garment workers are women, yet they are primarily concentrated in low-paying and low-skilled jobs.
The contrast between the rapid growth of the Sri Lankan apparel sector and the need for more progress for workers is stark. Despite the sector's growth, workers have not received increased wages or improved working conditions.
Join FORUM-ASIA and Law & Society Trust in the report launch event tomorrow to talk about challenges and ways forward on labour conditions faced in EPZ in Sri Lanka.

The event will be live-streamed live ▶️ youtube.com/@lawsocietytrust8867

#humanrights #humanrightsevent #humanrights4all #womensrights #laboursrights

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society. 

Spotlighting He Fangmei today, a #Chinese woman human rights defender who advocates for vaccine safety and for access to remedies for victims of defective vaccines after her daughter was paralysed from one.

In October 2020, she was disappeared after conducting a protest in front of a local government office in Huixian, Xinxiang, Henan province. She was pregnant at the time. She remains in extensive detention indefinitely and the whereabouts of her children are still unclear. 

We call for her immediate release and for all charges against her to be dropped immediately. Read her full case here:

https://zurl.co/MsiQ

Joint Statement: 

FLD and other organizations bring light to the dire political situation in Bahrain in light of the 146th Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) Assembly. 

''The slogan of the IPU is “For democracy. For everyone,” and the theme for this year’s conference is “Promoting peaceful coexistence and inclusive societies: Fighting intolerance.”

The government of Bahrain, however, imposes restrictions on expression, association, and assembly that violate Bahrain’s international human rights obligations. Elections are neither free nor fair, and opposition voices are systematically excluded and repressed. ''

At IESC, private sector growth has always been at the heart of our work—work that helps people around the world to improve their lives. We have a storied history of contributing to sustainable economic development and job creation, including in the most challenging environments. 

We are excited to launch our new name, Improving Economies for Stronger Communities (IESC), which embraces our history while reflecting who we are and what we do in the present day. Thank you for being partners in our efforts to create economic opportunity around the world by catalyzing private sector growth and employment. We are privileged to continue this important work with you.

The ‘Understanding Multidimensional Vulnerabilities: Impact on People of Sri Lanka’ Policy Report launched by United Nations Development Programme - UNDP #lka together with OPHI - Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative marks #SriLanka’s first ever Multidimensional Vulnerability Index (MVI), derived using the National Citizen Survey (NCS) 2022-23.

It showcases the overlapping challenges faced by the population through a set of indicators that capture #vulnerabilities beyond traditional income-based measures, looking at three dimensions: #education, health and disasters, and living standards.

To learn more about the Policy Report visit: www.undp.org/srilanka/mvi

🇧🇭 #Bahrain 

HRD Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja has systemically been denied urgent medical treatment while in prison, particularly in the last year, punishing him for protesting to ill-treatment in prison. 

Abdulhadi informed his family of gross ill-treatment by prison guards in relation to serious health complications that he is experiencing. on the evening of 28 February, he experienced intense elevated and rapid heart beats, in addition to laboured breathing, and at the insistence of the prison doctor, he was transferred from Jau Prison to the emergency room at the Bahrain Defence Force (BDF) Hospital. The er doctor stated that he must be immediately referred to a cardiologist. However, he was denied access to a cardiologist and was returned back to Jau Prison. While at the hospital, the security forces attempted to place the human rights defender in handcuffs. Abdulhadi has been facing a systematic denial of medical treatment by the Bahraini prison administration. According to reports between January 2022 and April 2022, necessary medical treatment was actively withheld from him by the Bahraini authorities, and access to medical appointments was denied which has resulted in his worsening health. 

We are deeply concerned about his situation:  

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/human-rights-defender-abdulhadi-al-khawaja-taken-ambulance-emergency-room-urgent-heart-issues?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

Thank you for being partners in our efforts to achieve our vision of a world with economic opportunity for all, where people and communities thrive. We look forward to continuing this important work together.

ஆட்கடத்தல் இலங்கையில் பாலின அடிப்படையிலான வன்முறையின் (GBV) ஒரு வடிவமாகக் கருதப்படுகிறது என்பது உங்களுக்குத் தெரியுமா? (ஆதாரம்: இலங்கையில் பாலியல் மற்றும் பாலின அடிப்படையிலான வன்முறைகளைத் தீர்ப்பதற்கான கொள்கை கட்டமைப்பு மற்றும் தேசிய செயல்திட்டத்திற்கான இணைப்பு.)

ஆட்கடத்தல் மற்றும் பாலின அடிப்படையிலான வன்முறை (GBV) பாதிக்கப்பட்டவர்களுக்கான சேவைகளுக்கான அணுகல் குறித்த புதிய தொடரான "தி டிப்பிங் பாயிண்ட்" அறிமுகப்படுத்தியுள்ளது  ஒவ்வொரு இடுகையும் CEPA ஆல் நடத்தப்பட்ட ஆய்வின் முக்கிய கண்டுபிடிப்புகளைப் பற்றி விவாதிக்கிறது. இதற்கு ஆசிய அறக்கட்டளை மற்றும் அமெரிக்க வெளியுறவுத்துறை நிதியளித்தது.

🎧 NEW PODCAST:

Follow along with sound effects while listening to WHRD Bidya Shrestha Maharjan narrate her story of defending the rights of the Newa Guthi people in the Kathmandu Valley, #Nepal. 

Bidya is a teacher by profession and the women’s president of the World Newa Guthi, an indigenous community organization. She has long been leading the movement to stop illegal road expansions, and has been threatened, physically attacked and arbitrarily detained as a result. 

She shares her story of her community, and the challenges she has faced as a human rights defender defending the rights of the Newa Guthi people from illegal construction. 

[15 min]
