The first two awareness sessions for the members of "Kandiyapita Sobadam surakeeme sanwidanaya" (Kandiyapita Nature conservation society), under the GGF grant was held on 8th and 9th June 2023 at Weli Oya. As part of the training program we delievered lectures on preparing organic fertilizers for different crops and different stages of the plants, preparation of organic pest control mixtures, proper and effective harvesting to prevent losses, and discussed how the group can strengthen the environmental momentum by addressing the plastic pollution along the banks of the Balaharuwa lake and reducing the use of plastic and polythene. The CEJ team also joined the event of the group getting two huts to expand their market opportunities. The members acknowledged the involvement of CEJ in developing the proposal and getting the GGF grant including such a long-term investment.

Today on World Oceans Day 2021 we reflect on the MV X-Press Pearl disaster that is unfolding before us. 

The short-term and long-term impacts of the disaster on marine flora and fauna, overall ecosystem health, people's livelihoods, food and health security, tourism, our nation's economy etc., are too extensive to realistically quantify. The intricate relationships we as humans have with the Ocean and its resources are beyond measure.  For fisher communities who depend on the oceans directly they are facing multiple simultaneous shocks, with few reassurances to restart their livelihoods. They have little or no access to social protection and are in a dire state. 

So today we focus on the fact that any form or scale of destruction to the Ocean is going to have impacts that extend beyond what we can see.

#WorldOceanDay #WorldOceansDay2021 #lk #SriLanka #MVXPressPearl

On August 12, IESC’s USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam, in collaboration with the Agro Processing and Market Development Authority (Agrotrade), organized a workshop on trademarks and branding for 150 representatives of SMEs in the agro-processing sector. The event included 64 business matchmaking sessions between six lead firms and 25 SMEs. It also featured 11 SMEs displaying their products next to the venue. Agrotrade and USAID LinkSME will follow up on this workshop by providing support to participant SMEs where needed to help them meet lead firm requirements.

IPEN: for a toxics-free future has shared some important facts highlighted during Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee 2 on Plastic Pollution which was held in Paris, France from 29th of May to 02nd of June 2023.

During the contact group on control measured there was broad support to regulate chemicals in plastics and no major opposition in principle. Also, there was a very strong support to have transparency measures to trace chemicals in plastics.

The reports from the two contact groups, one on control measures, the other on means of implementation and means of implementation are available online at the following links:

Contact group 1: https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/42621/CG1.pdf
Contact group 2: https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/42622/CG2.pdf

All in session documents are available here: https://www.unep.org/events/conference/second-session-intergovernmental-negotiating-committee-develop-international/documents/in-session

Last month, IESC’s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka facilitated the completion of a week-long hands-on training session in partnership with the University of Florida (UF) and the Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH). This session was attended by 40 veterinary surgeons and livestock development instructors who had previously completed nine virtual technical training modules offered by UF. The training combined classroom learning with farm visits and focused on best practices in milking, farm resource analysis, farm assessment, silage management, and heat stress management, among other topics. MOD, DAPH, and UF will review progress made by the participants in three months to address challenges implementing the best practices that were shared.

ශ්‍රී ලංකාව යනු  ඉන්දියන් සාගරයේ  මනස්කාන්ත මුහුදු වෙරළ වලින් සමන්විත සමකය ආසන්නයේ පිහිටි,  වැලි පර , ගල් පර සහ විසිතුරු කොරල් පර වලින් මෙන්ම විශාල  වශයෙන් මත්ස්‍ය  වර්ග , මුහුදු පැලැටි වර්ග , කැස්බෑවන් , මොරුන්, මඩුවන් ,ඇතුළු ලක්ෂ ගණනක් වූ  ජිවින්ගෙන් සමන්විත  ජෛව විවිධත්වයෙන් ඉහල සාගරයක් සහ ගොඩබිමක් සහිත මනස්කාන්ත දිවයිනක්.   

ලොව මෙතෙක් සාගරකලාපයක් තුල  සිදු වූ විශාලම  නවුකා අනතුර මෙරට මුහුදු සීමාවෙ සිදුවීමත් , එය සිදුවී වසර දෙකක් යනතුරු  හරියාකාරව  ක්‍රියාමර්ග නොගැනීම, ව්‍යසනයේ හානීය පිලිබද වාර්ථා "සමුද්‍රිය පරිසර ආරක්ෂන අධිකාරිය " යටතේ පමණක්  තොරතුරු වසන් කිරීම, හරියාකාරව රාජකරී සිදුනොකිරීම.

මෙරටට නොගැලපෙන වෙරළ  සංවර්ධන ක්‍රම දියත් කර පරිසර හායනය වැඩි කිරීමටත් , විවිධ  තහනම් ධිවර ක්‍රම (bottom trawling) භාවිතා කරමින් සාගර ජීවින් සමුල ඝාතනය කිරීමට ඉඩදීම වර්තමානයේත් සිදුවෙමින් පවති.  
ඒ හරහා, ඉහත අහිතකර තත්වයන් හමුවේ , සාගර ජීවීන්ට අභිජනනය වීමට, ජීවත් වීමට  අවශ්‍ය පරිසර තත්වයන් විනාශවීම, මෙරට ප්‍රධාන කර්මාන්තයක් වන ධීවර කර්මාන්තයට , සංචාරක කර්මාන්තයටත් මෙම ව්‍යසන  හරහා සිදුවන්නේ  යලි යතාතත්වයට පත්කිරීමට නොහැකි වන තරමේ පාරීසරික හා සමාජීය ව්‍යසනයන්ය.

දේශපාලකයින් විසින්  ගනු ලබන මුග්ධ තීන්දු තිරණත් , ඊට එකග වන  ආයතනත්, ඒ නිසා සිදුවන හානිය ඉතාමත් අවමයැයි  පෙන්විමට රජයේ  ආයතන  දරන උත්සාහයත්  ඉතාම පිළිකුල් සහගතය.

අවසන් වශයෙන් මෙරට සාගරය සම්බන්ද රාජ්‍ය ආයතන, අමාත්‍ය දූර හම්බකිරීම සදහා පමනක් කැපවන නිලධාරීන් සහිත ආයතන බව මෙම X-Press Pearl ඛේදවාචකයයේ පශ්චාත් සමයේදී හොදින් පැහැදිලි වෙ.

පාරිසරය ආරක්ෂා කරගකරගැනීමට ඔබ දරන උත්සාහය සහ කැපවීම මත  "නිදහසේ හුස්ම ගැනීම සහ පිරිසිදු පරිසරයක ජීවත්වීම  තීරණය වනු ඇත." ස්තුතියි ...!

✍️Vishwa Sachith Perera

Through the sale of #PegasusSpyware, Israeli companies and govt have been profiting off escalating threats against human rights defenders around the world.  

 Visualizing Palestine  shows us the impact of this through a new visual project, The Pegasus Effect:

''The structures of Israeli settler colonialism, military occupation, and apartheid have enabled Israel to build one of the largest cyber industries in the world. By exporting technologies such as Pegasus spyware, the Israeli government and private Israeli companies are profiting off of escalating threats against human rights defenders, journalists, and political opponents around the world and exporting the Palestinian experience of mass surveillance and state violence under apartheid.

We partnered with Al Haq, Bisan Center, and Mind The Gap Consortium to create “The Pegasus Effect,” a visual that uses the idea of the “butterfly effect” to depict how technologies that uphold Israeli apartheid ripple outward to impact communities thousands of miles away.  ''

https://visualizingpalestine.org/visuals/the-pegasus-effect

International Day of the Disappeared:

''No matter how powerful a country is, no matter what security challenges (real or perceived) they may face, the experts rightfully emphasize: ‘There can never be an excuse to disappear people.’ Enforced disappearances are strictly prohibited under international law under any circumstances, and may constitute a crime against humanity when committed as part of a widespread or systematic attack against any civilian population.

The Chinese government continues to ignore calls for it to ratify the International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance. It has disregarded requests for over nine years by the UN’s Working Group on Enforced and Involuntary Disappearances to visit the country, including its most recent on 7 January 2022. In the meantime, the number of cases of individuals disappeared presented before the Working Group soared, reaching 214 by 2021, out of which 98 remain outstanding.

UN experts and civil society actors have documented many practices used by the Chinese authorities amounting to enforced disappearance. Some are written into Chinese law, or Chinese Communist Party guidance; others happen outside the scope of China’s own laws. Some target individuals for their actions or speech; others are wielded with the intent to terrorize a particular ethnic or religious community.

It is urgent that the UN, governments, and civil society worldwide press China to end, unequivocally, all forms of enforced disappearance.

Today, we remember these human rights defenders who have been forcibly disappeared and call for action to end disappearances.''

🇨🇳 #China 

Enforced disappearances of HRDs is an increasingly worrying trend in #China. On the International Day of the Disappeared, we urge the international community to take meaningful action to put an end enforced disappearance in China.

Just over five years ago, on 13 August 2017, human rights lawyer Gao Zhisheng vanished for the third time. Gao, praised as the ‘Conscience of China’, had long fought for the rights of those who dared to speak out, who belonged to religious minorities, who were evicted from their homes when their land was seized, or who protested against exploitation. For that, he was in and out of prison and separated from his family for nearly a decade. For more than five years, his wife and children have had no idea of his whereabouts, nor even if he is alive.

Gao Zhisheng’s case is severe, and yet represents only the tip of the iceberg: many other activists and lawyers face a similar fate, such as Tang Jitian, disappeared in 2021, tortured, and detained in a secret location. UN experts, including the Working Group on enforced disappearance, have sounded the alarm from as early as 2011 about the use of enforced disappearances against those taking part in China’s human rights movement. 

The Chinese government continues to ignore calls for it to ratify the International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance. It has disregarded requests for over nine years by the UN’s Working Group on Enforced and Involuntary Disappearances to visit the country, including its most recent on 7 January 2022. In the meantime, the number of cases of individuals disappeared presented before the Working Group soared, reaching 214 by 2021, out of which 98 remain outstanding.

It is urgent that the UN, governments, and civil society worldwide press China to end, unequivocally, all forms of enforced disappearance. 

Read more:

https://frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/civil-society-call-end-enforced-disappearances-china

ප්ලාස්ටික් දූෂණය වලක්වා ගැනීමට නිෂ්පාදනය නතර කිරීමට බල කරමු !
ලොව පුරා සෑම වසරකම ප්ලාස්ටික් ටොන් මිලියන 400 කට වඩා නිපදවීමේ ප්‍රතිඵලය හේතුවෙන් ලෝකයට එය දරා ගැනීමට නොහැකි වී ඇති අවස්ථාවක, ලෝක පරිසර දිනයේ තේමාව වශයෙන් එක්සත් ජාතීන්ගේ සංවිධානය විසින් මෙවර තෝරා ගෙන ඇත්තේ Solutions to Plastic Pollution - ප්ලාස්ටික් දූෂණයට විසඳුම් යනුවෙනි. ලෝක පරිසර දිනය ලොව පුරා මිලියන සංඛ්‍යාත ජනතාවකගේ පාරිසරික මහජන ප්‍රවේශය සඳහා වන විශාලතම ගෝලීය වේදිකාව වී ඇත. 

ප්ලාස්ටික් භාවිතය පිළිබදව නැවත සිතා බැලිය යුතුව ඇති අතර රාජ්‍ය ආයතන වලට මේ සඳහා දැඩි වගකීමක් පවතින බව පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍රයේ විධායක අධ්‍යක්ෂ දිලෙන පාත්‍රාගොඩ මහතා පෙන්වා දෙයි. ප්ලාස්ටික් සම්බන්ධයෙන් නීති -රීති ක්‍රියාත්මක නොකොළහොත් , ස්වභාවික පරිසර පද්ධතීන්ට සිදුවන හානියේ වැඩි වීම පාලනය කළ නොහැකි වනු ඇති බවද ඔහු පෙන්වා දෙයි. ලෝක පරිසර දිනය විවිධ මාතෘකා හා සටන් පාඨ උපයෝගී කර ගනිමින් සැමරුවත් ,එය එ් දිනයට පමණක් සිමා වීම අභාග්‍යයක් වශයෙන් පෙන්වා දෙයි. මේ කාලීන මාතෘකාව පිළිබදව මෙවර අවධානයට යොමු කිරීම වැදගත් ය. රටක් විධියට පමණක් නොව ලෝකයා විදියටත් ක්‍රියා කළ යුතු යම් යම් ක්‍රියාමාර්ග මෙහිදී අවශ්‍ය වී තිබෙන බව දිලෙන පාත්‍රාෙගාඩ මහතා සඳහන් කරයි. 

දිරාපත් වන ද්‍රව්‍ය සමග ප්ලාස්ටික් අපද්‍රව්‍ය ද මුසු වීමෙන් පරිසරයට බලපෑම් ඇතිව තිබේ. ගංඟා හා දියපාරවල් තුලින් මහ මුහුදට එකතුවන ප්ලාස්ටික් වලින් අද ප්ලාස්ටික් දූපත් නිර්මාණය වීමට හේතු වී ඇත. ලෝකයේ ප්‍රධාන මුහුදු සාගර පද්ධතීන් ආශ්‍රිතව අඛණ්ඩව ගොඩගැසෙන ප්ලාස්ටික් හේතුවෙන් ප්ලාස්ටික් කඳු නිර්මාණය වී ඇත. අද සිදුවී තිබෙන්නේ මිනිසා විසින් නිෂ්පාදනය කරන ප්ලාස්ටික්වල ප්‍රතිවිපාක මිනිසාටම යළි භූමරංගයක් වී තිබීම බව ඔහු පෙන්වා දෙයි. 

පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍රයේ අධ්‍යක්ෂ මෙන්ම ජ්‍යෙෂ්ඨ උපදේශක හා Friends of the Earth(FOEI) ජාත්‍යන්තර සංවිධානයේ සභාපති හේමන්ත විතානගේ මහතා පෙන්වා දෙන පරිදි, එක්සත් ජාතීන්ගේ සංවිධානය විසින් පලකළ නවතම වාර්තාවන්ට අනුව ප්ලාස්ටික්වල රසායනික ද්‍රව්‍ය 13,000 ක් පමණ අඩංගුව පවතී. මෙයින් 7200ක් පමණ දැනටමත් හඳුනාගත් දූෂ්‍යකාරකයන්ය. එයින් තවත් 3200 ක් හඳුනාගෙන නැතත් දූෂ්‍යකාරකයන් වශයෙන් පෙන්වා දී ඇත. බොහෝ කලක් ජනතාව විශ්වාස කළ ප්ලාස්ටික් යනු නිශ්ක්‍රීය ද්‍රව්‍යයක්ය නැත්නම් අජීවී ද්‍රව්‍යයක්ය යන්න මෙමඟින් බිඳ වැටී ඇත. අද ලෝකය බරපතල ගැටලුවකට මුහුණ දෙමින් සිටී. ඒ මහ මුහුදේ තට්ටු ගණන් ප්ලාස්ටික් පැතිරීයාමයි. ලංකාවට ප්ලාස්ටික් හඳුන්වා දුන්නේ 1977 න් පසුව ආ විවෘත ආර්ථිකයත් සමඟ වන අතර අද එය රටටම ප්‍රශ්න ඇතිවීමට හේතු වී ඇත. ප්ලාස්ටික් දිරාපත් වීමට අධික කාලයක් ගත වන බව සොයා ගෙන තිබේ.බොහෝ විට සිදුවන්නේ පස තුළ තැන්පත්වීමයි.සමහර පොලිතීන් වැනි දේ දිරාපත් වීමට වසර 500 කටත් වඩා ගත වේ. 

අද ගැටලු ගණනාවකට හේතු වන්නේ මයික්‍රොප්ලාස්ටික්. අපේ ආහාරයේ, ජලයේ, මසුන්ගේ,මහ මුහුදේ සහ ඒ වගේම මවගෙන් දරු ගැබ තුළට මේවා ගමන් කර තිබෙනවා.අප හුස්ම ගන්න වාතයේ ඉතාමත් බහුල ලෙස මයික්‍රොප්ලාස්ටික් අඩංගු වනවා. නැනෝ ප්ලාස්ටික් ද මේ ආකාරයෙන් සෑම ස්ථානයකම අඩංගු වනවා. X-Press Pearl නාවුක ඛේදවාචකය හරහා ලංකාවේ සමුද්‍රයට එක්වූ ප්ලාස්ටික් අපද්‍රව්‍ය ප්‍රමාණ ඉතා විශාලය. ප්ලාස්ටික් හදුන්වා දීමේදී කීවේ සියයට සියයක්ම ප්‍රතිචක්‍රීකරණය කරන්න පුලුවන් දෙයක් හැටියටයි. මේ දිනවල ප්‍රංශයේ , පැරිස් නගරයේ පැවැත්වෙන අන්තර්රාජ්‍ය(Intergovernmental) කමිටුවේදී සාකච්ඡා වන්නේ ප්ලාස්ටික් ප්‍රතිචක්‍රීකරණය සාර්ථක දෙයක් නොවන බවයි. ප්‍රතිචක්‍රීයකරණයෙන් සිදුවන්නේද නැවත නැවත ප්ලාස්ටික් පරිසරයට මුදාහැරීමයි. සතුන්ගේ සෞඛ්‍යට මෙය බලපාන අතර විශේෂයෙන්ම මානවයාගේ අන්තරාසර්ග පද්ධතියට බලපෑම් ඇතිකරයි. අද තිබෙන කසළ වලින් 50%ක් ම ප්ලාස්ටික් බවට පත්ව තිබීමෙන් පෙනී යන හේතුව , එක්වරක්  භාවිතයට ගැනෙන ප්ලාස්ටික් වල වැඩිවීමයි. 

ප්ලාස්ටික් සදහා නවතම විසඳුම් අවශ්‍ය වන බව පෙන්වා දිය හැකියි. ප්ලාස්ටික්වලට අනාග ත විසඳුම වන්නේ නිෂ්පාදනය අඩු කිරීමයි. 

මේ ප්‍රශ්නයට අමතරව තවත් පරිසර ගැටලු ගණනාවක් ඇතිව තිබේ. මෙම‍ ගැටලු පිළිබදව සාකච්ඡා කිරීමත් අවශ්‍ය වේ. වනාන්තර මහා පරිමාණයෙන් එළි පෙහෙලි කිරීම, අක්‍රමවත් ඉඩම් පරිහරණය , අවශේෂ වන භූමිවල ආරක්ෂාව සඳහා පනවා තිබූ 5/2001 චක්‍රලේඛය අහෝසි කිරීම, වසර දහස් ගණනක් තුළ නිර්මාණය වූ ජෛවවිවිධත්වයෙන් අනූන අපේ වන පෙත් මහා පරිමාණ සංවර්ධන ව්‍යාපෘතීන් වන බඩ ඉරිඟු වගාවන් වැනි ව්‍යාපෘති සඳහා භාවිතා කිරීමට ඉඩ දෙමින් සිදු කිරීමට යන විනාශය , හම්බන්තොට ප්‍රදේශයේ මෑතකදී සැලසුම් කිරීමට කටයුතු කරන විදේශිකයින්ට ඉඩම් පවරාදීම, ගංඟා ආශ්‍රිතව මහා පරිමාණයෙන් වැලි ගොඩ දැමීම පෙන්වා දිය හැකිය. මේ හරහා පාරිසරික සමතුලිතතාවය බිද වැටීමට ද හේතු වී ඇත. 

පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍රය මේ සම්බන්ධයෙන් නීතිමය කටයුතු සිදු කරමින් පවතී. දේශගුණික විපර්යාස අවම කිරීම ,වනාන්තර විනාශය වැනි පරිසර පද්ධතීන්ට සිදුකරමින් පවතින පීඩාවන් වලක්වා ගැනීම සදහා නීති අණ පනත් යටතේ කටයුතු කිරීමට පෙනී සිටින බව පෙන්වා දිය යුතුය. අද අප ඉදිරියේ පවතින මෙවන් පාරිසරික ව්‍යසනයන් වලට විසඳුම් සෙවීම කළ හැක්කේ සාමූහික ප්‍රයත්නයන් තුළින් පමණක් වන බව පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍ර යේ මතයයි.

පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍රය

කිලිනොච්චිය දිස්ත්‍රික්කයේ, පූනගරි ප්‍රාදේශීය ලේකම් කොට්ඨාශයේ ඉරණතිව් ග්‍රාමනිලධාරී වසමට අයත් ඉරණතිව් දූපත, උතුරු හා දකුණු දූපත් ලෙස කොටස් දෙකක්. ඉරණතිව් උතුරු දූපත වර්ග කිලෝමීටර 4.22 ක් සහ දකුණ කුඩා දූපත වර්ග කිලෝමීටර 1.17 ක ප්‍රමාණයෙන් යුක්තයි. 1992 වසරේ දී යුධමය තත්ත්වය දරුණු මට්ටමකට පත් වීම නිසා සියලූ ම ජනතාව දූපතෙන් ඉවත් වී මන්නාරම, ඉරණමාතා නගර් ප්‍රදේශයේපදිංචියට පැමිණ තිබෙනවා. ඉන් පසුව වරින් වර ධීවර කණ්ඩායම් ඉරණතිව් දූපතට ගොස් ධීවර කර්මාන්තයේ නිරත ව ඇති අතර නාවික හමුදාවවිසින් ධීවරයන් 49 දෙනෙකු බෝට්ටු සමඟ අත් අඩංගුවට ගෙන පහර දී රදවා තබා ගැනීම හේතුවෙන් යුද්ධය පැවති කාලයේ දී ඉරණතිව් දූපතේ ධීවර කටයුතු සම්පූර්ණයෙන් ම අතහැර දැමූ බව සඳහන්.
2009 වසරේ දී යුද්ධය අවසන් වීමෙන් පසු ව නාවික හමුදාව විසින් මෙම සම්පූර්ණ දූපත අත් පත් කර ගෙන ස්ථාන 4 ක කඳවුරු බිම් සහ පොලිස් ස්ථානයක් ද ස්ථාපිත කොට තිබෙනවා. ඉන් පසුව නාවික හමුදාව විසින් ධීවර ජනතාවට උතුරු දූපතට පැමිණීම තහනම්කර ඇති අතර දකුණු දූපතේ පමණක් ධීවර පවුල් 36 කට ස්ථිර පදිංචිය සඳහා අවස්ථා ව ලබා දී තිබෙනවා. 

ඉරණතිව් දූපත, එහි පදිංචිව සිටි ධීවර ජනතාවට සිමා කිරීම පිළිබඳව People’s Alliance for Right to Land - PARL සැකසූ සටහනක්.

Happy International Youth Day! The population in Kenya is dominated by youth, yet unemployment rates among the youth population in the country are high. Over 90% of unemployed youth in Kenya lack formal vocational or professional skills training, as evidenced by their low engagement in the agriculture sector where the average age of workers is 55. To strengthen opportunities for youth to get involved in the agriculture sector, IESC’s Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) program in Kenya has partnered with CAP Youth Empowerment Institute (CAP YEI) (CAP-Youth Empowerment Institute Capacity Building). IESC’s specialized volunteer experts have provided training to youth who are interested in working in agriculture on obtaining access to finance to strengthen and grow their agribusiness endeavors. In honor of International Youth Day, the F2F Kenya program is excited to celebrate the growth of CAP YEI’s work and the growth of the next generation of youth in agriculture.

In June 2022, F2F implementers from countries throughout Africa visited CAP YEI’s demonstration farm and met with aspiring youth farmers to learn more about their work. Two F2F staff members and CAP YEI youth members are pictured here. #InternationalYouthDay #agriculture #youthempowerment #volunteer

Every 5 years, World Bank Sri Lanka analyses the country's understanding of the most important challenges and opportunities faced in its development journey. Now is the time for #SriLankans to make their voice count in our assessment of #SriLanka. Take this survey: http://wrld.bg/qDxR50EIM55  #SCDSL2021

The Centre for Poverty Analysis (CEPA) is conducting a series of stakeholder consultations on behalf of the World Bank Group (WBG) who are carrying their Systematic Country Diagnostic (SCD) update for Sri Lanka, 2021.

This survey will enable the World Bank to engage with the Sri Lankan public and seek their opinions on important development opportunities and challenges faced by the country in achieving the twin goals of eradicating extreme poverty and boosting shared prosperity. 

Lend your voice by participating in this online survey!

This International Youth Day, IESC highlights efforts by the USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, to ramp up skills in the solar technician trade. The Sri Lanka Sustainable Energy Authority (SLSEA) estimates that at least 10,000 new solar technicians will be needed to meet the government’s targets and growing demand for solar energy solutions. In response to nationwide energy shortages and sharp increases in the cost of energy, the Government of Sri Lanka announced a strategy to generate 70% of the country’s power needs from renewable sources by 2030. YouLead is working with SLSEA and the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) on a pilot program to train and find on-the-job placements for 1,200 prospective solar technicians—with up to 70% of participants comprised of youth. IESC trained the first group of 420 prospective solar technicians through a two-day immersion, preparing school leavers for on-the-job training. Each training culminated in a job fair with approximately 100 solar installation companies actively recruiting. Following six months of on-the-job experience, the trainees will be eligible for formal certification. 

International Youth Day showcases the importance of youth engagement to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The launch of the Solar Technicians Training pilot program ties directly to achievement of SDG Goal 7 – improving access to affordable and clean energy. Through this pilot, IESC will ultimately support new employment opportunities for thousands of youth while simultaneously helping to decrease Sri Lanka’s dependence on non-renewable energy sources. #internationalyouthday

ජූනි -05 ලෝක පරිසර දිනයයි - #SolutionstoPlasticPollution (ප්ලාස්ටික් දූෂණයට විසඳුම්)
====================================

"ප්ලාස්ටික් දූෂණය ගැන හැමෝම කතාවෙන අද දවසෙ මේ ගැන වසර 19කටත් එහා ඉඳන් පර්යේෂණ, සමීක්ෂණ, දැනුවත් කිරීම, උපදේෂණය සහ නෛතික කටයුතු වල යෙදෙන ආයතනයක් විදියට පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍රය මතක් කරන්නෙ, ප්ලාස්ටික් දූෂණය, ඒ කියන්නෙ "ප්ලාස්ටික් නිෂ්පාදනය, භාවිතය, අපද්‍රව්‍ය කළමනාකරණය සහ කාන්දු වීම් නිසා ඇතිවන සියලුම විමෝචන සහ අවදානම්" අඩු කිරීමේ වගකීම අපි හැමෝටම තියෙන බව.

පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍රය ප්ලාස්ටික් ගැන කරපු හැම පර්යේෂණයකින්ම ඒවායෙ අහිතකර රසායනික තියෙන බව හෙළි වුනා. ප්ලාස්ටික් කිරි බෝතල් වල හෝමෝන ක්‍රියාකාරීත්වයට හානි කරන රසායනික, රුබික් කැට වල හායනය නොවෙන ඉතා හානිකර රසායනික. ප්‍රතිචක්‍රීකරණය කරපු ප්ලාස්ටික් පෙලට් වලත් හානිකර රසායනික, පුද්ගල සනීපාරක්ෂක ද්‍රව්‍යවල  හිතා මතා අඩංගු කරපු  මයික්‍රොබීඩ් නැත්නම් ක්ෂුද්‍ර ප්ලාස්ටික් පබලු, වගේම කතා කරල ගෙන්න ගත්ත නැවෙන් ආපු පබළු, පිළිස්සුණු ප්ලාස්ටික් කොටස් වලත් ඉතා හානිකර රසායනික තියෙන බව අපිට අනාවරණය වුනා. මේ හැම දේකින්ම අවසානයේ පැහැදිලි වෙන්නෙ, ප්ලාස්ටික් කියන්නෙ අපිට හිතකර දේකට වඩා අහිතකර දෙයක් බව නේද? ඉතින් මේ බව දැන දැනත්, බලධාරීන්ට, දේශපාලකයන්ට, සමාගම්වලට බැන බැන ඉඳල නම් මොකුත් වෙන්නෙ නැහැ. වෙනසක් කරන්න ඕනි පාරිභෝගිකයො.  

දෙන නිසාම පොලිතීන්, ප්ලාස්ටික් ගෙදර ගේන්නෙ නැතුව, හැකි සෑම විටම අනවශ්‍ය ප්ලාස්ටික් එපා කියන්න අපිට පුලුවන්. මොකද එකපාරක් පාරිභෝගිකය අතට පත් වුනාට පස්සෙ, ඝණ, ද්‍රව හෝ වායුව විදියට ඒක යන්නෙ පරිසරයට. "ප්ලැනටරි බවුන්ඩරීස්" එහෙමත් නැත්නම් මේ ග්‍රහලෝකයේ සමතුලුතතාව පවත්වාගන්න වුවමනාකරන සීමා නිර්ණයන් ගැන කතා කරන විද්‍යාඥයෝ කියන්නෙ ප්ලාස්ටික්  ඇතුළු දූෂක වල සීමාව දැනටමත් අපි පහු කරල කියල. අපි මුහුණ දෙන බොහොමයක් ස්වභාවික විපත් වලට හේතුව තමයි ඒක.

තනි භාවිත ප්ලාස්ටික් අද විශාල ගැටළුවක් වෙලා තියෙනවා. "මම විතරනෙ" කියල මිලියනයක් දෙනා බීම බටය ගානෙ ඉවත දැම්මොත්, එතනම මිලියනයක් බීම බට ගොඩ ගැහෙනවා. මේ නිසා පාරිභෝගිකයන් හැමෝටම වගකීමක් තියෙනවා තනි භාවිත ප්ලාස්ටික් හැකි සෑම විටම ප්‍රතික්ෂේප කරන්න. හැකි තාක් විකල්ප වලට යොමු වෙන්න. විකල්ප භාවිතා කරන ව්‍යාපාරිකයන් දිරි ගන්වන්න ඔවුන්ගේ නිශ්පාදන මිලදී ගන්න. සුපිරි වෙලඳසැල් වලදි පොලිතීන් කවර එපා කියන්න, ගෙදරින් කවරයක් ගෙනියන්න අමතක වුනොත් එයාලගෙ ඉවත දාන කාඩ්බෝඩ් පෙට්ටියක බඩු අරන් එන්න, පොල්තෙල් ගේන්න බෝතලයක් අරන් යන්න. මාලු ගේන්න ගෙදරින් පෙට්ටියක් අරන් යන්න....

මේ වගේ පුංචි පුරුදු වලින් පටන් ගමු. අපිට පුලුවන් මේ ප්ලාස්ටික් දූෂණය අඩු කරන්න.

With the effects of the #crisis felt across the island, one of the most affected sectors was the poultry industry. Import restrictions created an urgent need for #maize to be used as poultry feed. 

Through The Facility established by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP #lka, and funding from JICA Sri Lanka/スリランカ事務所 and กระทรวงการต่างประเทศ Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Kingdom of Thailand, 31,700 farmers were provided with seeds for cultivating maize in #SriLanka.

The crop yielded from the seeds also contributed towards the production of #healthy food options for children, reducing levels of #malnutrition in the young. 
.
.
.

On July 11, 2022, Paraguay's DINAVISA launched its digital institutional management system called "DINAVISAPY." This system reduces times in product import processes and facilitates international trade in the chemical-pharmaceutical sector, including key ingredients for fertilizers and other agrochemicals.

The presentation was made in the presence of government authorities, including the Minister of Health, Dr. Julio Borba; DINAVISA National Director, Dr. María Antonieta Gamarra; and Ministry of Foreign Affairs, First Secretary Carrillo. Also in attendance were representatives from 11 trade associations that purchased the base software on which "DINAVISAPY" was built, as well as USDA Food for Progress Program Manager Kevin Alonzo, IESC Associate Vice President Chad Ford, and other prominent businesspeople and media. 

As "DINAVISAPY" is implemented, IESC’s USDA-funded T-FAST project (Proyecto T-FAST) will continue to expand the system until March 2023 when all trade-related processes have been digitalized and then integrated into both single windows of import and export. A short video of the event can be seen at: http://ow.ly/6HUN50KgLL3

🇱🇰 #SriLanka

On 18 August 2022, Sri Lankan police used disproportionate force against peaceful protesters in Colombo including tear gas, water cannons and batons. 20 protesters, including human rights defender Chinthaka Rajapaksa and student leader and education rights defender Wasantha Mudalige were arrested from the protest. 16 of those arrested, were released on bail by the Magistrates Court the following day (19 August). Chinthaka Rajapakse was denied bail and remanded until 26 August. Wasantha Mudalige and two other student activists were held in police custody for well over 72 hours without access to lawyers and in violation of their due process rights. They are currently detained under Detention Orders in terms of the draconian Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). Sri Lankan authorities invoked the PTA, depriving the detainees of basic safeguards, and without recourse to bail, despite appeals against the use of this law against protesters.  

We call for their immediate release and for authorities to respect the right to peaceful protest:

UNFPA partnered with the Colombo Municipal Council to support 600 urban underprivileged households in the city by distributing dignity and maternity kits that provide all essential items that women and girls need to uphold their health and dignity.

With the support of IESC’s USDA-funded Trade Safe (Proyecto Trade Safe) project in the Dominican Republic, a delegation of local business owners visited the World Food Logistics Organization (WFLO) Latin American Institute in México. Participants received training in cold chain practices to apply to their companies to improve operational efficiency. During the visit, they developed tools to design internal and external communications, as well as build leadership and management skills. Additionally, the group networked and learned about new strategies and technologies from industry leaders at WFLO Institute Latin America. With IESC's support, Dominican companies are implementing cold chain solutions to improve food quality and safety for consumers. #ProyectoTraSa #ProyectoTradeSafe #TraSa #TradeSafe

STATEMENT:  🇵🇸 🇮🇱 #OccupiedPalestinianTerritory #Israel

On the morning of 18 August 2022, Israeli security forces raided the offices and confiscated the property of the six Palestinian civil society organisations designated as “terrorist groups” under its Counter Terrorism Law, 2016. Documents, printers and computers were seized and closure orders were issued against the organizations. 

The organisations are Al-Haq Organization مؤسسة الحق  Al-Haq, Addameer Prisoner Support & Human Rights Association  Addameer Prisoners Support and Human Rights Association, Bisan Center for Research & Development  مركز بيسان للبحوث والانماء  Bisan Center for Research and Development, Defense for Children International- Palestine, اتحاد لجان العمل الزراعي (UAWC)  the Union of Agricultural Work Committees (UAWC) and the Union of Palestinian Women’s Committees (UPWC). The offices of the Health Work Committees (HWC) @hwcpal were also raided and closed.

This follows the Israeli government’s move last year to outlaw the six groups designating them as “terrorist” organizations under Israeli law, and as “unlawful associations” under military law, which is applicable in the occupied West Bank. 

Front Line Defenders strongly condemns the raids, closures and the designations of terrorism brought against these Palestinian human rights organisations in response to their peaceful human rights work. Human rights defenders are not terrorists. This development marks a grave expansion of Israel's systematic policies and practices intended to silence Palestinian human rights defenders who seek justice and accountability for violations of Palestinians human rights. 

Front Line Defenders calls on all stakeholders – states, international bodies, corporations and law enforcement authorities to clearly and unequivocally reject the terrorism charges brought against Palestinian human rights organisations and human rights defenders. 

#IStandWithThe6 ⬇️

Capacitating health workers in the Colombo Municipal Council on sexual and reproductive health issues such as teenage pregnancy, HIV prevention, menstrual health and prevention of gender-based violence as part of a UNFPA, FAO & UNV joint project to improve the health and well-being of women and girls. 

Family planning and reproductive health are central for women's empowerment and sustainable development. 

During crises, sexual and reproductive health needs of women and girls are overlooked and neglected, resulting in severe consequences. 

UNFPA is working with government and civil society stakeholders to uphold the health and protection rights of the most vulnerable women and girls.

STATEMENT:

Front Line Defenders condemns the disbarment of human rights lawyers in #Crimea by #Russian authorities for voicing concerns over the on-going human rights violations in Crimea.

Since Russia’s occupation of Crimea in 2014, authorities have relentlessly persecuted Crimean Tatars and others who have been critical of Russia’s human rights violations on the peninsula. In response to the growing abundance of politically motivated cases against Euromaidan activists, representatives of the Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People (banned in Russia in 2016), activists from the Ukrainian cultural center and representatives of the Islamic political party Hizb ut-Tahrir, the human rights initiative “Crimean Solidarity” was launched. This initiative supports victims of political persecution by documenting human right violations, providing legal aid, observing trials and supporting victims’ families. Lawyers working on politically motivated cases in Crimea soon became major targets for the authorities, regularly being subjected to harassment, threats, judicial prosecution, office raids, disciplinary penalties and threats of disbarment. On 15 July 2022, the Bar Association of the Chechen Republic of the Russian Federation disbarred human rights lawyers Lilia Hemedzhy, Rustem Kyamilev and Nazim Sheikhmambetov. Front Line Defenders condemns the disbarment of the lawyers and the increased targeting against human rights lawyers in Crimea by Russian authorities. 

Front Line Defenders condemns the disbarment of human rights lawyers Lilia Hemedzhy, Rustem Kyamilev and Nazim Sheikhmambetov. It believes that their disbarment is a clear reprisal for their legitimate and peaceful work as human rights lawyers and for voicing concerns over the on-going human rights violations in Crimea. The targeting and systemic persecution of human rights lawyers by the Russian authorities forms part of a worrying trend in Crimea since its annexation in 2014. 

See full statement: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/crimea-ukraine-human-rights-lawyers-disbarred

The National Forum Against #GenderBasedViolence co-chaired by UNFPA and IDEA hosted a diverse panel discussion to mark the start of #16Days of Activism 2022, under the theme Unite! Activism to End Violence Against Women and Girls.

Former Minister of Justice Thalatha Atukorale stated that the issue continues to be a timely conversation and she strongly believes that we all have to work together to see violence against women and girls end.

Chief of Party of IDEA/MS Mr. Gowthaman Balachandran highlighted that technology is an enabler of violence as it gives a sense of entitlement for men and even boys to violate the dignity and rights of women and girls.

UNFPA Sri Lanka Country Representative Mr. Kunle Adeniyi emphasized the need to change hearts and minds and engage the new generation to improve how men and boys treat women and girls.

The panel discussion reflected on how women, especially those in the garment and estate sectors are particularly affected by the economic crises, policing and migration policies.

Today marks 12 years in arbitrary detention of indigenous Zapoteco leader, and forest & water rights defender, Pablo López Alavez in Oaxaca, #Mexico.  We come together at the Front Line Defenders office in Dublin, Ireland to plant a tree as a symbol of hope and we call for Pablo's immediate release. 

Prior to his detention, Pablo spent more than two decades working to ensure that the San Isidro Aloápam community’s rights to a safe environment and access to water were guarded and guaranteed.

As a direct consequence of this work, he made powerful enemies and faced many criminal accusations. On 15 August 2010, he was arbitrarily and violently detained. Following 7 years in detention without trial, and despite testimony and the presentation of evidence that Pablo was elsewhere on the day and time of a shooting he was accused of, and despite there being many inconsistencies and contradictions in the witness' testimony, a judge at the trial found him guilty on trumped up murder charges and sentenced him to 30 years in prison.

 #LibertadParaPablo #SeguimosSembrandoEsperanza
#AltoALaCriminalizacióndeDDH #PorLaDefensaDeLosBienesComunes

Princy Mangalika found out she had HIV at the age of 41 in 2001.

After she lost her husband and her home, she escaped the village with her two daughters, only having LKR 840.

“They threw stones at our house, dumped garbage and hooted.”

And even that didn’t stop the stigma. This eventually made her think about attempting suicide. But she decided to live for her daughters. 

After that, she created the Positive Women's Network to assist other HIV victims. She has since raised awareness about HIV/AIDS, driving away the myths and misconceptions.

She was one of the first people to fight to bring down medicine for HIV/AIDS patients in Sri Lanka. 

World AIDS Day is a reminder that the disease and the severe stigma around it still exists. And the more we educate, the more we understand that alienating its victims is not the solution.

Joint Statement: 🇦🇫 #Afghanistan

 One year after Taliban takeover, human rights defenders at greater risk than ever.

One year since the Taliban captured power in Afghanistan, conditions for human rights defenders, especially women, have further deteriorated. A year ago, when the Taliban seized power in Afghanistan, they promised to respect human rights - including the rights of women and girls and media freedom. However, over the past year, they have carried out serious human rights violations and abuses, and sought to suppress civil society, media freedom, and any form of dissent with complete impunity. 

...Despite this grave human rights crisis, the international community has failed to live up to their responsibility for the Afghan human rights defenders they funded and encouraged for two decades . It is time for the international community to take concrete steps to provide practical support to human rights defenders and ensure the Taliban are held accountable.

The Support for Durable Resettlement (#SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, sustainable livelihoods and income generation opportunities. 

Stories of Resettlement: Having resettled in 2015, Sundaralingam began cultivating on a portion of his land that was returned. Puwanachandran's interest in cultivation started at an early age, and he began growing vegetables on a small scale. Gopalakrishnan was faced with issues in transporting his produce, and a lack of water. 

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the British High Commission Colombo, across 4 districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee.

At least thirteen Baha’i activists and defenders of the rights to freedom of religion, including human rights defenders Mahvash Sabet, Fariba Kamalabadi and Afif Naemi have remained arbitrarily detained in Tehran, Karaj, Sari, Qazvin and Shiraz since 31 July 2022. During this period, the homes and businesses of 100 Baha’is across Iran have been raided and the thirteen advocates for the rights of the Baha’i community to freedom of religion have been arrested or imprisoned.

In an attack on 2 August 2022, targeting the Baha’i community in Iran, up to 200 Iranian government agents sealed off the village of Roushankouh in Mazandaran province in north Iran where a number of Baha’is live and demolished their houses with heavy machinery. According to BIC, at least six houses were destroyed and over 20 hectares of land were confiscated. Prior to the raid, roads leading to the village were blocked, mobile devices of almost all people present in the village were confiscated and filming was prohibited. Anyone who tried to challenge the agents was arrested.  

Front Line Defenders urges the Iranian authorities to immediately and unconditionally release all arrested Baha’i human rights defenders including Mahvash Sabet, Fariba Kamalabadi and Afif Naemi. Additionally, Front Line Defenders urges the authorities to carry out an immediate, thorough and impartial investigation into the house raids, demolition of homes and confiscation of properties, including land grab of the members of the Baha’i community, with a view to publishing the results and bringing those responsible to justice in accordance with national and international standards. 

Read more:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/confiscation-properties-and-demolition-houses-bahai-community-following-arrests

🇲🇳 #Mongolia 

It’s time to turn commitments into action. In #Mongolia, human rights defender Sukhgerel is at risk of arrest bc of her NB work protecting the #environment. We stand with her and urge authorities in #Mongolia to support her work! 

Sukhgerel Dugersuren is a Mongolian woman human rights defender who works closely with communities impacted by large scale development projects. She has a long history of exposing human rights abuses and environmental degradation linked to large scale mining, energy and infrastructure projects. She is the Executive Director of Oyu Tolgoi Watch (OT Watch) – a Mongolian NGO monitoring the environmental and human rights impacts of Rio Tinto’s gold and copper mine Oyu Tolgoi – and Director of the Rivers without Boundaries Coalition in Mongolia which helps local communities to protect river ecosystems they depend on. 

On 3 August 2022, during a government briefing, the Minister of Justice and Internal Affairs of Mongolia, H. Nyambaatar, stated that the construction of the power plant had been suspended for two years. On 3 June 2022, an article written by Sukhgerel Dugersuren criticising the Erdeneburen hydroelectric power plant which is planned to be built on the Khovd River in Western Mongolia was published by The Third Pole.1 The article raised concerns about the project, including about the safety of the construction, potential environmental impact given its location in an ecologically sensitive area of Tsambagarav Uul National Park, and the potential displacement of 112 pastoralist households.

 Front Line Defenders condemns the attempt to criminalise Sukhgerel Dugersuren and other human rights defenders in Mongolia. Opposing the negative human rights and environmental impacts of infrastructure, energy and mining projects is not a crime and should not be punished.

We at the Centre for Poverty Analysis are saddened by the demise of Mr V. Sivagnanasothy, Secretary of the Commission of Inquiry and Member of the Public Service Commission.
 
Mr Sivagnanasothy served as a Board Member of the Centre for Poverty Analysis from 2016-2018. He supported our work, especially with his in-depth knowledge and expertise in reconciliation work.

Moreover, we wish to acknowledge with gratitude and appreciate the support rendered by Mr Sivagnanasothy who paved the way to highlight our efforts to influence policy when he served as the Secretary to the Ministry of Prison Reforms, Rehabilitation, Resettlement & Hindu Religious Affairs. His dedication and efforts to revive the plantation sector are humbly appreciated. 

May his soul Rest in Peace.

கப்பல் விபத்தால் மாசு இல்லை என்று நினைப்பவர்களுக்கு, "அறிவியல்" ரீதியான பதில் உள்ளது. இதைத்தான் CEJ IPEN மற்றும் பேராசிரியர் பத்மலால் மற்றும் அவரது ஆய்வுக் குழுவுடன் இணைந்து கண்டறிந்துள்ளனர்.
இந்த ஆய்வு முடிவுகள் பிளாஸ்டிக்கின் பாதுகாப்பான போக்குவரத்தை பரிந்துரைக்க உலகம் முழுவதும் பயன்படுத்தப்படுகின்றன. குளோபல் பிளாஸ்டிக் ஒப்பந்தத்தின் INC2 உட்பட பல சர்வதேச தளங்களுக்கு CEJ இந்த ஆய்வை வழங்கியுள்ளது.

நிலைமாற்றத்திற்கான பயணம் நாடக விழா இன்று மன்னார் நகர சபை மண்டபத்தில் நடாத்தப்படுகின்றது. இந்த நாடக விழா, சட்டம் மற்றும் சமூக நம்பிக்கை அமைப்பினால் அதன் ட்ரான்ஸ்ஃபோர்ம் நிகழ்ச்சித் திட்டத்தின் கீழ் ஏற்பாடு செய்யப்பட்டு வட மாகாணத்தில் உள்ள ஐந்து மாவட்டங்களிலும் நடாத்தப்படுகிறது. "பால்நிலை பாரபட்சமிக்க சமூக நியமங்களும் பெண்களின் உரிமைகள் மற்றும் சுதந்திரங்களில் அவற்றின் தாக்கமும்" என்ற பங்குபற்றுகை ஆய்வினது முடிவுகளின் அடிப்படையில் இந் நாடகங்கள் உருவாக்கப்பட்டுள்ளன.

As Vietnamese SMEs face significant difficulties in their post-COVID-19 business recovery, digital transformation and access to finance are crucial to help them adapt to and recover from emerging challenges and enhance their competitiveness to participate in national and international supply chains. 

On July 26, IESC’s USAID LinkSME Project in Vietnam, in collaboration with Vietnam’s Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), hosted a workshop on Empowering Small and Medium Enterprises through Digital Transformation and Access to Finance. The event was attended by representatives from MPI and USAID/Vietnam, as well as more than 100 representatives from ministries, government agencies, representatives of provinces, business associations, businesses, and the media, and was streamed online to hundreds of businesses across the country. 

Apart from learning about powerful tools and materials, workshop participants were introduced to upcoming support programs and discussed digital transformation and access to finance needs and solutions through face-to-face matching and consultations with solution providers, banks, and credit funds. MPI and USAID LinkSME will continue empowering Vietnamese SMEs through digital transformation and access to finance to help SMEs adapt to the new business environment, overcome challenges, and seize market opportunities.

IESC’s USDA-funded T-FAST project in Paraguay (Proyecto T-FAST) recently supported the training and certification of 33 professionals from the agricultural and food sector representing Paraguay’s National Institute of Technology, Standardization and Metrology (INTN), the Secretary of Agriculture and Livestock (SENACSA), the National Plant and Seed Quality and Health Services (SENAVE), the National Institute of Food and Nutrition (INAN), the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock (MAG), and the National Accreditation Body of the National Council for Science and Technology (ONA-CONACYT). Professors specialized in food safety from T-FAST implementing partner Kansas State University (KSU) delivered the "Food Safety and the Hazard Analysis of Critical Control Points (HACCP) system” training over the course of a three-day workshop, providing the opportunity for participants to obtain official HACCP international certification granted by the Food Safety Net Services (FSNS). This training and international certification was organized by the Working Group for the Facilitation of Trade in Agricultural Goods of the National Committee for Trade Facilitation (NTFC) and coordinated by MAG and the Paraguayan Chamber of Exporters and Marketers of Cereals and Oil Seeds (CAPECO), with the support of the T-FAST project and KSU.

Intergenerational Dialogue Series 

‘Voices of Peace’ on the 6th April 2021 at 4:00pm on Zoom

This is the third dialogue planned for this series is an online discussion with author and activist Sarah Kabir. Sarah will give insights from her book “Voices of Peace”. The format of the event is set to be a book reading followed by a question-and-answer session. Voices of Peace (herein referred to as VOP), is an anthology of stories from a sample of twenty combatants from both sides of the conflict. The book published in 2018 contains narratives that highlight the experience and struggles of combatants during and after the war. Sarah’s work of recording narratives with the view of preserving the multifaceted history of the state emulates the principles of memorialisation. 

Further, the socio-political context of the state provides a backdrop in which revisiting the human aspect of ethnic and civil conflict is pertinent if not imperative. The growing tension between communities as well as the developments vis-a-vis international response to human rights in Sri Lanka revitalises the importance of familiarising with the human cost of conflict in order to move towards a more cohesive society.

Congratulations to the six graduates of the AccelerateHER program, Sri Lanka’s first customized accelerator program for female entrepreneurs implemented in partnership with the US Department of State and Hatch Works and supported by IESC's USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead. The curated three-month program empowered early-stage start-ups and drove gender parity in entrepreneurship, providing support to upskill six women entrepreneurs and their businesses. IESC supported the program with subject matter expertise, technical assistance, and mentoring for the Personal Development module of the program.
 
The graduating class conducted a Demo Day for an audience of potential investors and noteworthy stakeholders. The entrepreneurs had the opportunity to pitch their validated business concept, financial feasibility, go-to-market strategy, and team expansion plan.
 
Since the completion of the AccelerateHER program and Demo Day, participants have achieved significant business milestones, including over 17 strategic and retail partnerships worth over Rs. 20 million ($55,000). In addition, five out of six women entrepreneurs doubled their product lines and increased product quantities by 100%; 70% doubled their sales and revenue; and 90% expanded their teams making them first-time employers and creating much-needed jobs.
 
As its next step, AccelerateHER launched regional bootcamps to support, nurture, and accelerate female-led ventures across Sri Lanka.

IESC’s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka recently hosted a World Milk Day commemoration to create broader awareness of the potential for increasing milk yields even under trying economic conditions. The event was attended by over 200 dairy farmers, processing company representatives, and key officials from the Ministry of Livestock Development and the Department of Animal Production and Health. The event included a walkthrough tour of one of MOD’s progressive dairy farmers, showcasing the low-cost farm model producing 100 liters per day. Through the event, IESC helped to increase awareness of the possibilities of the dairy sector and the support that public officials can provide.

Its been one year since The Pegasus Project exposed cyber surveillance of HRDs - demonstrating chilling effects on human rights and the well-being of HRDs. 

In December, we made a strong call for action to be taken in addressing targeted surveillance of human rights defenders, after Front Line Defenders uncovered surveillance spyware on the devices of six Palestinian human rights defenders 2 month before:   

https://t.co/RE2otuPczX 

We subsequently uncovered a number of targeted surveillance attacks in different contexts:

Palestine: https://frontlinedefenders.org/en/press-release-front-line-defenders-investigation-finds-pegasus-spyware-6-palestinian-hrd-phones

Jordan (w CitizenLab ): https://frontlinedefenders.org/sites/default/files/jordanpegasusreport.pdf

WHRD report (w Access Now ): https://frontlinedefenders.org/sites/default/files/unsafe-anywhere_-women-human-rights-defenders-speak-out-about-pegasus-attacks_en.pdf

El Salvador: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/exposed-civil-society-condemns-use-pegasus-el-salvador-spy-journalists-and 

We continue to call for a global moratorium on the sale, use and transfer of surveillance technologies:

https://www.amnesty.org/en/petition/targeted-surveillance-human-rights-defenders/

Revitalising the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) process in the New Normal

Duryog Nivaran, Janathakshan and the Centre for Poverty Analysis conduct the official kick-off meetings for the project ‘Revitalising the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) process in the New Normal’

Duryog Nivaran – the South Asia Network for Disaster Mitigation recently received a grant from the South Asia Small Grants Program (SAGSP) which is managed by The Asia Foundation (TAF) to implement a project with its partner organisations Janathakshan and the Centre for Poverty Analysis that aims to revitalize the DRM process in the New Normal.

The project was conceived through the recognition of the need for stronger DRM processes, especially at community level, in the New Normal created as a result of COVID19. In the New Normal, the state and communities will have to build resilience and effective response mechanisms for concurrent disaster situations (floods, droughts, cyclones etc. amidst COVID19 limitations), in order to mitigate both their short-term and long-term impacts. The project looks to empower communities and civil society organizations (CSOs) to take a more active role in DRM processes while also strengthening coordination between such structures and local institutions.

Read More - https://www.cepa.lk/blog/revitalising-the-disaster-risk-management-drm-process-in-the-new-normal/

IESC’s USDA-funded Trade Safe (TraSa) project in the Dominican Republic (DR) supported 20 beneficiaries in an observation trip to Bogota and Cartagena. Led by the American Chamber of Commerce Colombia (AmCham Colombia), representatives from DR’s public and private sectors toured port facilities in Bogotá and Cartagena, observing logistics and inspection best practices. The trip included collaboration on port management with LATAM Cargo logistics in Bogotá and the Centro de Distribución Logística de Contecar (DCLI) in Cartagena. This observation trip will play a critical role in advancing the development of port management in Dominican Republic.

On 5 July 2021, 84-year-old Jesuit priest and human rights defender Father Stan Swamy died in judicial custody at the Holy Family Hospital, in Mumbai, India. 

On the first anniversary of his death, we, the 13 undersigned international and national human rights organisations, remember Stan Swamy’s decades-long commitment to realising the rights of Dalit and indigenous peoples in India, especially in Jharkhand State. 

We reiterate our call demanding an independent and effective investigation into his death in custody and for the immediate and unconditional release of the 15 other prominent human rights defenders charged in the same case.

On 5th July, it will be one year since Father Stan Swamy died in custody. Fr. Stan Swamy was an indigenous people’s rights defender. He was the founder of Vistapan Virodhi Janvikash Andolan (VVJA), an all India platform for different movements that are resisting displacement of adivasi people, dalits, and farmers from their lands. The defender spent 9 months in jail under the anti-terror law, the Unlawful Activities Prevention Act (UAPA), denied bail and medical care in jail, and only transferred to a hospital when his condition became critical on 29 May. 

Join us for a discussion on the persecution of religious minorities in India, and to commemorate Fr. Stans death with a number of key speakers:

IESC’s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka recently hosted leaders from the Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) in visits to MOD trained dairy farmers in the North Western Province. IESC and DAPH visited dairy farmers who have doubled, tripled, and even quadrupled their milk production using improved management practices recommended by IESC. IESC also showcased the achievements of entrepreneurs engaged in the commercial fodder and silage sector who are helping to enable dairy farmers to bridge gaps in feed requirements. Following the visits, the DAPH team held a debriefing and brainstorming session where they suggested further improvements to reach maximum productivity at minimum cost.

JOINT STATEMENT:

Iran: Meta Must Protect the Iranian #MeToo Movement

A wide network of Iranian women’s rights defenders, feminist activists and public figures, —who are part of Iran’s #MeToo movement and in the diaspora— have come under coordinated attacks from bots and trolls on Instagram in an effort to stifle their freedom of expression and damage their online presence and influence. The huge numbers of fake followers flooding their accounts are part of a sustained, paid campaign.

ARTICLE 19, Access Now, United for Iran and Front Line Defenders urge Meta, Instagram’s parent company, to immediately investigate and eliminate these fake followers and do more to protect the free expression of these human rights defenders, activists and individuals. 
....

Our organisations urge Meta to prioritise its investigations and hold these paid-for troll farms accountable. We are deeply worried by their potential for being hired by actors associated with states such as the Islamic Republic of Iran who would benefit from stifling the voices of these women’s rights defenders.

These fake followers must be investigated and removed. Meta must act swiftly to stop the harms inflicted on Iranian women’s rights defenders, and urgently ensure the protection of their freedom of expression on the platform.

Life at Home During COVID-19

CEPA’s 63rd Open Forum was held on the 16th of February 2021 via Zoom and Facebook Live. The virtual discussion was centred on two studies, by CEPA and Asha Abeyasekera, both looking at ‘life at home’ during COVID-19.

The presenters at the Open Forum were Gayathri Lokuge, Nadhiya Najab and Asha L Abeyasekera, with Madhavie Gunawardena being the discussant and Chandima Arambepola as the moderator.

The forum brought about fruitful discussions and unique perspectives, ending with an array of questions that each presenter got the chance to answer with their expertise and opinions, drawing ideas from the studies they conducted.

The exploratory research study from CEPA looked at how families with young children were faced with the challenges of care responsibilities brought about by the movement restrictions imposed due to COVID-19. Data for the study were collected in two waves, the study was conceptualised and conducted during wave 1, from March to May 2020, and wave 2 was conducted between November and December. Information was gathered through a quantitative survey, shared on social media, to capture the experiences and perspectives of those with access to web-based platforms. The 1st wave saw a response of 466, while the second wave had 81 respondents. At the forum, the focus was the on the quantitative component but there was also a qualitative component to the study during both waves.

CEPA’s Gayathri Lokuge spoke of the gendered nature of COVID-19 related impacts, the tasks divided, and how individuals coped with the shift to remote working and distance learning. With case studies, examples and statistics, Gayathri explained the mental impact, such as the increase in feelings of tension and anxiety, due to the loss of ‘me-time’, for both men and women.

Nadhiya Najab dived a little deeper highlighted the gendered nature of the division of household and childcare responsibilities and distance learning. The ‘COVID push’, Nadhiya explained, is the term used to illustrate the change in participation in household responsibilities, which saw an increase in male participation during the first lockdown in Sri Lanka, in 2020. Nevertheless, with the arrival of the second wave, Nadhiya showed the audience how the division of labour became bigger and the responsibility of childcare fell back greatly on women.

Read more 

https://www.cepa.lk/blog/life-at-home-during-covid-19/

Increasing access to finance for youth in the agriculture sector is a main objective of IESC’s USAID-funded Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) Program in Tanzania. Youth have what it takes to drive the future of the agricultural sector in Tanzania and increasing their access to finance is an important way to improve food security and agricultural productivity and provide livelihoods to youth. That is why IESC has supported the Mshikamano Youth Group located in the Geita region of Tanzania - to increase their knowledge of lending and to access finance for agriculture activities. Through F2F volunteer expert support and training, Mshikamano Youth Group members were able to pool their shared financial resources to undertake profitable activities as a group and provide individual loans to group members, which is extremely impactful for group members who previously were not able to obtain financing and were excluded from the Tanzanian financial sector. #WYSD2022

Dr. Sakuntala Kadirgamar writes:

We condemn the arbitrary arrest of #Indian WHRD Teesta Setalvad - happening shortly after the dismissal of a petition filed by Teesta and Zakia Jafri, seeking accountability for the 2002 Gujarat riots. 

On 25 June 2022, prominent whrd Teesta Setalvad was arbitrarily detained by the Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS) of Gujarat Police on trumped up charges including forgery, fabricating evidence and criminal conspiracy.

ATS officers forcibly entered her home in Mumbai, and detained her without a warrant - this happened a day after the Supreme Court of India dismissed a petition seeking justice and accountability for the 2002 Gujarat riots filed by Teesta Setalvad and Zakia Jafri, the widow of a person killed in the riots.

Age is no barrier for Entrepreneurship. You only need a clear vision, strong passion & determination to make it happen.

This World Youth Skills Day, IESC highlights efforts by the USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, to build the skills of young entrepreneurs to start and run their own business. Through entrepreneurship development training with the Samurdhi Authority, IESC is supporting young mothers such as 21-year-old Maduwanthi to turn their informal livelihoods into micro or small enterprises. “I realized that we need to be more financially prudent and learn how to keep track of our income and costs. I was still breastfeeding my baby but also didn’t want to miss the opportunity to learn. So, I just brough my baby along,” says Maduwanthi. Through the training, which was accommodating to the needs of this new mother, Maduwanthi and her husband learned skills for managing their cash flow and expanding their business through product diversification. By the end of June 2022, YouLead completed 127 training programs in eight districts, teaching entrepreneurship development skills to more than 5,000 participants. #WYSD2022

Happy World Youth Skills Day! Building the capacity of youth is a key activity of IESC’s USAID Farmer-to-Farmer program in Tanzania. Last year, IESC’s F2F volunteer experts Frank Wertheim and Ernest Jerome delivered a training to the Missenyi Green House Youth Group, which is made up of 100 youth members. In March 2019, they received a greenhouse facility from the Tanzanian Prime Minister’s Office and Ministry of Labor, Employment, and Youth Development to unlock the potential of Tanzanian youth in the agriculture sector and address youth unemployment. The Missenyi Youth Group works on optimizing horticultural production and improving the quality of produce in order to increase the income of its members. The F2F volunteer experts trained Missenyi members on compost making, tomato production and agronomy, and soil health management to enhance their skills in sustainable tomato production. The training provided the youth members with techniques to monitor and regulate the soil pH and improve soil organic matter content and fertility, resulting in greater tomato harvests and higher incomes. #WYSD2022

ලෝක ජෛවවිවිධත්ව දිනය - මැයි 22
==================================

ජෛව විවිධත්වය නැවත ගොඩනැගීම සඳහා වන එකඟතාවයන් ක්‍රියාවට නංවමු!
From Agreement to Action: Build Back Biodiversity

ජෛව විවිධත්වය, මිහිතලයේ පවත්නා ජීවයේ පොහොසත්කම සහ විවිධත්වය විස්තර කරනු ලබයි.එය අපගේ ග්‍රහලෝකයේ වඩාත් සංකීර්ණ හා වැදගත් ලක්ෂණයන්ගෙන් එකක් වන අතර ජෛව විවිධත්වය නොමැතිව ජීවය පවත්වා ගත නොහැක. 

ජෛව විවිධත්වය යන පදය 1985 දී නිර්මාණය කරන ලද්දකි. ස්වභාවධර්මයේ විවිධත්වය, ජෛවගෝලය සමඟ කටයුතු කිරීම පදනම් කර ගනිමිනි. ශාක, සතුන් සහ ක්ෂුද්‍ර ජීවීන් විශේෂ අතර විචල්‍යයන් ගැන මෙහි සඳහන් කරයි.

පරිසර යුක්ති කේන්ද්‍රයේ ජ්‍යෙෂ්ඨ උපදේශක මෙන්ම එහි අධ්‍යක්ෂ හේමන්ත විතානගේ මහතාට අනුව,අද වන විට ලෝකයේ ප්‍රධාන පරිසර ගැටලු 03 ක් ඇති බව පෙන්වා දෙයි. ඒ අතරින් ජෛවවිවිධත්වය විනාශ වීම අපගේ ග්‍රහලෝකයේ පැවතිය යුතු සීමාවන් ඉක්මවා ගොස් ඇති බවත් , මෙයට ප්‍රධාන හේතුව මනිසා විසින් අනෙකුත් සතුන්ගේ පරිසර පද්ධති ආක්‍රමණය කරමින් දේශගුණික විපර්යාස වලට හේතුපාදක වන සෙසු සංකූලතාවයන් වන භූමිය හා සමුද්‍ර දූෂණයට හේතුකාරක ක්‍රියාවන්හි යෙදීම බවද ඔහු අවධාරණය කර සිටී.

පසුගිය මස විද්‍යාඥයින් විසින් සහන් කළේ ලෝකයේ ඇති සම්පත්වලින් 70%ක් මිනිසා විසින් ආක්‍රමණය කොට ඇති බවයි. එලෙසම 2020 වසරේදී පරිසර විද්‍යාඥයින් ප්‍රකාශ කළේ වන ජීවීන්ගෙන් 70% ක් ගෙවී ගිය වසර 50 තුළ විනාශ වී ඇති බවයි. එවන් තත්වයක් තුළ 1992 වසරේදී ලෝකයේ එකඟ වූ ජෛවවිවිධත්වය පිළිබද එකඟතාවයන් නිවැරදි ලෙස අනුගමනය කළේ නම් , මේ වන විට ඉහත කී තත්වයන් ඇතිවීමට කිසි සේත් හේතු නොවනු ඇති බව හේමන්ත විතානගේ මහතාගේ මතයයි.

එසේම බහුතරයක් වන ජීවීන්ට අද වන විට ජීවත් වීමේ අවශ්‍යතා සැපයීමට නොහැකි තත්වයකට පත් වී ඇත. සියයට 29 කට වඩා වනාන්තර ප්‍රතිශතයක් ඇති බවට රජයේ ආයතන විසින් ප්‍රකාශ කලද අලි ඇතුන්,රිලවුන් සහ වඳුරන්ද,මොණරුන්ද,දඬුලේනුන් ඇතුලු වන ජීවින් සමඟ මේ වන විට බරපතල අර්බුදයක් හටගෙන ඇත. මේ අර්බුදයට විසඳුම් ලෙස දේශපාලනඥයින් විසින් රිලවුන් චීනයට යැවීමට ක්‍රියා කිරීම වැනි විසඳුම් ලබාදීමට ගෙනෙන යෝජනා ජෛවවිවිධත්ව සම්මුතියට හා අනෙකුත් ජෛවීය සම්මුතීන්වලට එකඟ නොවන ,එමෙන්ම ශ්‍රී ලංකාවේ වන ජීවී හා සම්බන්ධ ප්‍රතිපත්තිවලට එකඟ විසඳුම් ද නොවේ. 

පසුගිය ජනාධිපති සමයේ හෙක්.ලක්ෂ 5 කට ආසන්න වෙනත් රජයේ වනාන්තර (Other State Forests) සංවර්ධනය සදහා චක්‍රලේඛයක් නිකුත් කිරීමද,වන ජීවී කලාප වටා මාරාන්තික අලි - අගල් ඉදිකිරීම වැනි ජෛවවිවිධත්ව විරෝධී ව්‍යාපෘති ශ්‍රී ලංකාව තුළ දියත් කිරීම අසීරු වනු ඇත. ඒ පසුගිය දෙසැම්බර් මස මොන්ට්‍රියෙල් නගරයේ පැවැති ජෛව විවිධත්වය පිළිබද එක්සත් ජාතීන්ගේ සංවිධානයේ 15 වන සැසිවාරයේදී එකඟ වූ ගෝලීය ජෛවවිවිධත්ව රාමුව උල්ලංඝනය කිරීමට කටයුත් කිරීමක්ද වන හෙයිනි.

එම සමුලුවේදී එකඟ වු ඉලක්ක 23 අතරට ලෝකයේ භූමියෙන්,වෙරළෙන් හා මුහුදු වලින් 30%ක් කාර්යක්ෂම ලෙස කළමනාකරණය සහ සංරක්ෂණය කිරීමට එකඟ වීමත්, 30%ක් ගොඩබිම් සහ මුහුදු පරිසර පද්ධතීන් යළි
ප්‍රකෘතිමත් කිරීමත්,අධික ජෛවවිවිධත්වයකින් හා පාරිසරික අඛණ්ඩතාවයකින් (Integrity) යුත් පරිසර පද්ධතීන්වලට සිදුවන හානිය ශූන්‍ය බවට පත්කිරීමටත්,ආහාර ඉවත දැමීම හරි අඩකින් අඩු කිරීමටත් වූ
එකඟතාවයන් නිසි පරිදි ක්‍රියාත්මක කිරීමට ලෝකය , ඉදිරියේදී කටයුතු කළහොත්, ජෛවවිවිධත්ව විනාශය හේතුවෙන් සිදුවෙමින් පවතින හානියට යම් සහනයක් ලබා ගැනීමට හේතු වනු ඇත.

ලංකාව මේ 2020 ගෝලීය ජෛවවිවිධත්ව රාමුවේ පාර්ශවකරුවෙකු වශයෙන් මෙම ඉලක්ක මගහැර යාමට කිසි සේත්ම හැකියාවක් නැත. එබැවින් පරිසර පද්ධතීන්වලට සිදුකරමින් පවතින විනාශයන් නතර කිරීමට අවශ්‍ය නීතිමය, ප්‍රතිපත්තිමය හා මූල්‍යමය ආයතනික පසුබිම සැකසිය යුතුව ඇත. 2023 වසරේ ජෛවවිවිධත්ව දිනය සමරන මේ මොහොත වෙනත් වසර වලදී සිදුකළ ජෛවවිවිධත්ව දිනවලින් ඔබ්බට ගොස් ඉහත කාර්යයන් සපුරා ලිය හැකි ක්‍රියාකාරී සැලැස්මක් සැකසීමට සියලු රාජ්‍ය ආයතන මෙන්ම දේශපාලන අධිකාරියද එක්ව කටයුතු කරනු ඇතැයි යන්න අපගේ බලාපොරොත්තුවයි.

We are deeply saddened by, and condemn, the murder of HRD Jesuit priests Joaquín César Mora Salazar and Javier Campos Morales in church. The HRDs, dedicated to supporting indigenous communities, were brutally killed while trying to protect Mr. Pedro Elioro from an armed group.

On June 28, 2022, IESC’s USAID-funded Industry-led Skills Development Program in Georgia hosted the second Business Leaders’ Council meeting that gathered 13 CEOs of leading Georgian private sector companies. The meeting was themed “Regulated Professions and Labor Market Implications.” Together with partner PMCG, the Program will analyze the topics discussed and propose follow-up actions to respond to the issues raised by the Council members. The interactive session demonstrated the private sector’s interest in working with the Program to identify challenges and solutions to address skills constraints in Georgia.

IESC’s USDA-funded T-FAST project (Proyecto T-FAST) in Paraguay recently sent a 12-person delegation of key public and private sector decision-makers in the international trade arena, including Paraguay’s National Customs Director, to São Paulo, Brazil. The Paraguayan Customs Director, along with customs authorities from ten other countries in the Americas and the Caribbean, signed a Regional Mutual Recognition Agreement (MRA) to recognize the Authorized Economic Operators (AEO) of every other country, increasing the number of AEO certified companies recognized by Paraguay’s Customs and the Customs authorities of Argentina, Brazil, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Peru, the Dominican Republic, and Uruguay, to 2,009 AEO companies. AEO programs help low-risk trade move through inspections faster, helping businesses and agencies to expedite trade of agricultural goods.

IESC is celebrating the success of the USAID-funded Workforce and Higher Access to Markets Activity (WHAM Activity) in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which officially closed last month. The WHAM Activity was a five-year project (2017-2022) implemented by IESC that stimulated job creation by advancing BiH’s trade integration with and expansion into the EU and regional markets. WHAM focused on accelerating employment for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the metal processing, wood processing, textile/apparel, and information and communications technology (ICT) sectors.

Through 83 grants and in close cooperation with 335 companies and 67 municipalities, IESC helped SMEs achieve 293 transactions with foreign customers, supported 54 companies to attain 94 new certifications, and supported 60 SMEs to obtain new or upgraded technologies. WHAM-supported SMEs reported an 18.2% increase in sales and an 13.6% increase in exports. IESC also supported the training of 2,657 workers and jobseekers, and the creation of 2,333 new full-time jobs, 33% of which were for women and 60% of which were for young people. 

You can watch a summary of the USAID WHAM Activity and its many accomplishments here: http://ow.ly/Qytf50JQMrh

IESC’s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka facilitated the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between USDA and the Sri Lankan Department of Agriculture. This MoU will strengthen the existing partnerships between MOD and the Government of Sri Lanka’s Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) allowing for MOD to broaden its reach and lay the groundwork for the sustainability of project activities after the project ends. In the short time since the MoU was signed, IESC and DAPH have already moved to deepen their partnership, beginning to implement delayed activities focused on building DAPH’s dairy extension capabilities to reach more farmers. Read more here: https://lk.usembassy.gov/the-united-states-contributes-27-million-to-strengthen-sri-lankas-dairy-industry/

දුෂ්කර අභියෝග මැද ,සංරක්ෂණය වෙනුවෙන් බලාපොරොත්තු සහිතව ලොව පුරා පරිසර සංවිධාන, විද්‍යාඥයන් සහ පරිසරවේදීන් එක්ව වඳවීමේ තර්ජනයට ලක්ව ඇති විශේෂ සහ ඔවුන්ගේ වාසස්ථාන ආරක්ෂා කිරීම සඳහා ආරක්‍ෂිත ප්‍රදේශ පිහිටුවීම, තිරසාර ඉඩම් පරිහරණ ක්‍රම ක්‍රියාත්මක කිරීම, පාරිසරික නීතිය ක්‍රියාත්මක කරවීම, සංරක්ෂණ ක්‍රම ක්‍රියාත්මක කරවීමට රජයන්ට බල කිරීම, අභිජනන වැඩසටහන් කිරීම සහ ප්‍රජාව දැනුවත් කිරීම දක්වා පුළුල් පරාසයක මෙම සාමූහික ප්‍රයත්නයන් සිදුවෙමින් පවති.
 
ඒ සදහා ඔබට කලහැකි දේ....

* ඔබේ කලාපයේ සහ ගෝලීය වශයෙන් වඳවීමේ තර්ජනයට ලක්ව ඇති විශේෂයන් සහ තර්ජනයට ලක්ව ඇති පාරිසරික කලාප හදුනා ගන්න, ඒ සම්බන්ධව ඔබේ මිතුරන්, පවුලේ අය සහ ප්‍රජාව දැනුවත් කරන්න.
*පාරිසරික පියසටහන(Carbon foot Print) අඩු කිරීම, බලශක්ති නාස්තිය අවම කිරීම, තිරසාර නිෂ්පාදන තෝරා ගැනීම සහ පාරිසරික වගකීමට ප්‍රමුඛත්වය දෙන ව්‍යාපාරවලට සහාය වීම සංචාරය කරන විට, වන සතුන්ට සහ ඔවුන්ගේ වාසස්ථාන සංරක්ෂණය කරන පරිසර හිතකාමී සහ සදාචාරාත්මක සංචාරක විකල්ප තෝරන්න.
*තර්ජනයට ලක්ව ඇති විශේෂ ආරක්ෂා කරන ශක්තිමත් පාරිසරික රෙගුලාසි සහ නීති සම්පාදනය කිරීමට සහ කඩවී ඇති නීති අණපනත් වෙනුවෙන් ක්‍රියාත්මක කිරීමට කණ්ඩායම් වශයෙන් බලපෑම් කිරීම.
*තිරසාර සංවර්ධනය සහ වනජීවී සංරක්ෂණය ප්‍රවර්ධනය කරන මුලපිරීම් සඳහා සහාය වීම.

සෑම ජීවී විශේෂයකම අතිමහත් වටිනාකම හඳුනාගෙන ඒවා ආරක්ෂා කිරීම සඳහා නිශ්චිත ක්‍රියාමාර්ග ගැනීමෙන්, මිනිසා ස්වභාවික ලෝකය සමඟ සහජීවනයෙන් ජීවත් වන අනාගතයක් සහතික කළ හැකිය. අපි එක්ව, අනාගත පරම්පරා උදෙසා ජෛව ගෝලයේ සංරක්ෂණය වෙනුවෙන් අපගේ පෘථිවියේ වගකිවයුතු භාරකරුවන් වීමට උත්සාහ කරමු.

The odds are in favour of what might just be the best prequel ever!🏹

This is a visual masterpiece, to say the least. Francis Lawrence returned as the director for the fifth installment of The Hunger Games franchise, honouring Suzanne Collins’ already perfect world-building.  The creators tow the thin line between both retro and futuristic settings.
 
Rachel Zegler nailed the free-spirited, rebellious musician archetype as Lucy Gray Baird. Tom Blyth played Coriolanus Snow, staying true to Donald Sutherland's version but adding his own flair. Blyth skillfully captured Snow's transition into a power-hungry tyrant. Hunter Schafer, Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage were excellent in their roles as you might already expect.

While the plot holds its own story, we loved picking up on the subtle Easter eggs and callbacks to the original series – if you know, you’ll know. 

Overall, despite the length of the film, it packs action, emotion and moving soundtracks into, in our opinion, one of the best prequel movies ever made - a rather tricky feat for most blockbuster franchises to pull off.

The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is now screening at Scope Cinemas. Be sure to check it out on the big screen!

By: Kameshi Kohomange

ලියාපදිංචි වන්න : ස්ත්‍රී  පුරුෂ සමාජභාවය හා බැඳී වෙනස් කොට සැලකීමේ සමාජ ප්‍රතිමාන සහ කාන්තාවන්ගේ අයිතිවාසිකම් හා නිදහසට එයින් ඇතිවන බලපෑම සම්බන්ධ 
පර්යේෂණ වාර්තාව එළි දැක්වීම

2022 ජුනි 28 වනදා  පෙරවරු 10.00 සි‌ට පස්වරු 1.00 දක්වා ජානකී හෝටලයේ දී පැවැත්වේ .
( ලිපිනය අංක 43, පයිප් පාර, කොළඹ 08) ඔබ සහභාගී වීමට කැමති නම් මෙහි ලියාපදිංචි වන්න. ලියාපදිංචි වීමේ ප්‍රමුඛතා පිළිවෙල අනුව ‌‌තෝරාගන්නා අයදුම්කරුවන් වෙත ආරාධනා පත්‍රය ඊ මේල් හරහා එවනු ලැබේ. 

அறிக்கை வெளியீடு: பால்நிலை பாரபட்சமிக்க சமூக நியமங்களும், பெண்களின் உரிமைகள் மற்றும் சுதந்திரங்களில் அவற்றின் தாக்கமும்" பற்றிய ஆய்வறிக்கை வெளியீட்டில் பங்கேற்க இப்போதே பதிவுசெய்து கொள்ளுங்கள். 

நிகழ்வு 2022 ஜூன் 28 ஆம் திகதி காலை 10 மணி முதல் நண்பகல் 1 மணிவரை ஹொட்டேல் ஜானகி (இல.43, பயிப் (Fife)  வீதி, கொழும்பு 05) இல் நடைபெறும்.
நீங்கள் நிகழ்வில் பங்குபற்ற விரும்பினால் இங்கே பதிவு செய்து கொள்ளவும். முதலில் பதிவு செய்பவர்களுக்கு முன்னுரிமை வழங்கப்பட்டு தெரிவு செய்யப்பட்ட பங்குபற்றுநர்களுக்கு மின்னஞ்சல் ஊடாக அழைப்பிதழ் அனுப்பி வைக்கப்படும்.

It is with profound sadness that we note the passing of Dr. Malathi De Alwis, formidable anthropologist and CEPA friend. She leaves behind an exceptional legacy, her profound work and understanding on memory, nationalism, humanitarianism and feminism in Sri Lanka will continue to be vital to our society.  

Her last engagement with CEPA was in August 2020, where she presented at our inter-generational dialogue series on ‘Memorialization and Community’. 

She will be remembered as an exemplary scholar and a great inspiration to us all. Rest in peace

The correlation between poverty and inequality

A common assumption is that when levels of poverty decrease, inequality levels go down as well. This is, however, far from reality as inequality and poverty are two different concepts. The effects of inequality on societies are potentially harmful and is a cause for concern in the long run.

Sri Lanka’s poverty levels have seen a significant reduction. The poverty headcount ratio was at 4.1% in 2016, compared to 15.2% in 2006/7 (Department of Census and Statistics). Despite the decline in income poverty, income inequality continues to remain unchanged. More than half the total household income of the country is enjoyed by the richest 20% in Sri Lanka while the bottom decile (poorest 20%) gets only 5%, with the share of household income being just 1.6% for the poorest 10%.

https://www.cepa.lk/blog/the-correlation-between-poverty-and-inequality/

In the first half of 2022, USAID’s youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead collaborated with AccelerateHer, a new accelerator for women-owned businesses, to support the development of women entrepreneurs. AccelerateHER launched a three-month program funded by the US Embassy in Sri Lanka designed to promote gender equality and upskill women entrepreneurs. Seven women-led startups were selected, representing a diverse profile of industries. With support from IESC and AccelerateHER, the entrepreneurs were given access to tailored support from business coaches and experienced mentors, including alumnae from other incubation and acceleration programs, and a network of partners and investors. YouLead supported the program through career development, leadership training, and soft skills— all essential skills to build and manage a successful business. 
Photo credit: AccelerateHER (https://www.accelerateher.asia/)

In recognition of Micro-, Small, and Medium-sized Enterprises (MSME) Day today, we are highlighting the USAID-funded Workforce and Higher Access to Markets Activity (WHAM Activity) in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which closed earlier this month. Supporting small and medium enterprises was central to IESC’s work under WHAM, which helped more than 320 SMEs to attain new certifications, upgrade technologies, increase sales and exports, and find qualified workers to meet labor needs. 

Through a grant provided to the Association of Employers of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, IESC helped young men and women gain the skills needed to obtain meaningful jobs in the textile and footwear industries through practical training with local SMEs. Not only does this support young unemployed people to build their skillsets and find work, but it also supports Bosnian SME employers to find qualified tailors, seamstresses, and assemblers to fill open positions, enabling them to expand production capacities and exports and ultimately hire even more people. 

Watch the video to learn more about the impact of this support: https://youtu.be/9pj0CvaSLh8

USAID Bosnia and Herzegovina #MSMEDAY2022 #USAinBiH #usaidbih

For Micro-, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprises (MSME) Day, IESC celebrates the USAID LinkSME project’s work to strengthen and connect Vietnamese SMEs to global markets. Vietnam continues to attract substantial amounts of foreign investment despite the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. USAID LinkSME is dedicated to ensuring that as much of this foreign investment as possible remains in the domestic economy by strengthening the capabilities of SMEs to meet the demands of foreign investors and domestic lead firms. This allows foreign investors and domestic lead firms to partner with these domestic SMEs for parts, supplies, or other intermediate goods, rather than importing them from abroad. When this investment remains in the country, Vietnamese SMEs are able to innovate, generate jobs, and improve their communities. #MSMEDay #MSMEDay2022

STATEMENT:

Front Line Defenders is profoundly concerned for the health of prominent human right defender and dual Danish-Bahraini citizen, Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja, who is currently serving a life sentence in Bahrain for exercising his rights to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly.

As a direct result of the well-documented torture and mistreatment the human rights defender endured at the hands of the Bahraini authorities1, Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja suffers from a series of chronic and degenerative health problems and requires timely, expert medical treatment. According to recent reports however, between January 2022 and April 2022, necessary medical treatment was actively withheld from the human rights defender by the Bahraini authorities, and access to medical appointments was denied.

Read more:

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/call-immediate-release-ireland-medical-grounds-prominent-human-rights-defender-and

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program in Georgia signed a grant agreement with Caucasus University, a leading educational institution in Georgia. Together with the Spanish Basque Culinary Center and the Gastronomic Tourism Business Association of Georgia, Caucasus University will develop an innovative skills development certificate training program, which will be the first gastronomy training created in collaboration with international partners. The knowledge and experience transfer from one of the leading educational centers in gastronomy in Europe will benefit Georgia’s gastronomical vocational education programs and the hospitality industry overall. The key to sustainability is the program’s integration within the curriculum of the Caucasus Academy of Gastronomy in Gurjaani, Kakheti.

The Support for Durable Resettlement (SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, sustainable livelihoods and income generation opportunities. 

Stories of Resettlement: Niroshan's initial interest in agriculture was piqued by his Muthalali. From that point, the SDR Project provided him with a sprinkler set which allowed him to expand the area in which he cultivated. Since her return from India, Shanthi has been running her own Indian food shop. She has developed her business to include the marketing of her speciality 'sambar powder' which has also been a fast-selling item. Brindhapan, an air condition mechanic also versed in repairing refrigerators and electronic devices learnt his skills from his father. Prarthana's wish for a photocopy machine was granted through the project, and she has been able to continue her father's business successfully. Through the SDR project, each of them was taught how to develop their businesses and save money while continuing to grow. 

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Sri Lanka together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the British High Commission in #Colombo, across 4 Districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee and the Pacific #fundingwindows.

Last month, IESC’s USDA-funded T-FAST project in Paraguay (Proyecto T-FAST) and PROCOMEX presented the results of the exports mapping study for air cargo, which consisted of six workshops with a representative group of decision makers from the private sector and two workshops with a representative group from the private and public sectors, at the Paraguayan Industrial Union (UIP). In total, 56 bottlenecks were identified and discussed, and solutions were agreed upon. Considering just the procedural bottlenecks, which include lack of coordination, norm adaptation, and unnecessary bureaucracy, a potential time reduction of 22% was identified. This unprecedented and comprehensive trade mapping study marks the beginning of a new phase for Paraguay’s National Trade Facilitation Committee (NTFC) as these bottlenecks are being incorporated into the NTFC’s working groups to commit all parties involved to provide long-lasting solutions.
